2016-08-04.snippet: As we rage about Russia’s state-sponsored doping, we might want to recall those decades when doping was a slice of American pie.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Early in 1987, Kerry Lynch, a bright hope of the American ski team for an Olympic medal, boarded a plane for Germany.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Lest We Forget, the U.S., Too, Spent Time in the Doping Wilderness

2016-08-04.abstract: Colombia revised a 30-year-old drug law and embraced medical marijuana; now private companies are betting that cannabis could be a market leader.
2016-08-04.snippet: Colombia revised a 30-year-old drug law and embraced medical marijuana; now private companies are betting that cannabis could be a market leader.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: RIONEGRO, Colombia — Like many drug barons in Colombia, Federico Cock-Correa wants to sell his product globally. Just 15 miles outside Medellín, Mr. Cock-Correa is looking to replace vast acres of flowers with marijuana plants, with plans to export the harvest.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Colombia’s New, Legal Drug Barons Focus on Medical Marijuana

2016-08-04.abstract: This documentary, directed by Deborah Riley Draper, brings racial inequality to the forefront in the Olympics held in Berlin during the Third Reich.
2016-08-04.snippet: This documentary, directed by Deborah Riley Draper, brings racial inequality to the forefront in the Olympics held in Berlin during the Third Reich.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: The Olympic Games have never been immune from politics, and they certainly weren’t in 1936, when Berlin was the host city and Hitler sought to present the Third Reich in a flattering light. That the United States thwarted him is largely because of the black athletes who receive their due in Deborah Riley Draper’s deft and comprehensive documentary “Olympic Pride, American Prejudice.” As the movie makes clear, racial politics played a major role, both domestically and abroad.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Review: ‘Olympic Pride, American Prejudice’ Recalls Black Athletes in 1936

2016-08-04.abstract: Prejudice in science is suffocating a generation of biomedical researchers.
2016-08-04.snippet: Prejudice in science is suffocating a generation of biomedical researchers.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: “You are too smart to be Mexican” and “Congratulations! You probably got the award because you are Latino” are two of many remarks we, as scholars and professionals, heard at some of the top academic centers in the country.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Racism in the Research Lab

2016-08-04.abstract: The structure not only moves with the wind, but also tilts as its inhabitants move across its floor. Here’s what it’s like to live there.
2016-08-04.snippet: The structure not only moves with the wind, but also tilts as its inhabitants move across its floor. Here’s what it’s like to live there.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: For Alex Schweder and Ward Shelley, the term “artist in residence” is often a very literal one: Collaborators since 2007, the pair practice what Schweder describes as “performance architecture,” or the exploration of how inhabiting a space affects us, psychologically. So they build interesting structures, and then move in.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Two Artists Built a Spinning House, and Then Moved In

2016-08-04.abstract: A charmer with a documentary feel, this film follows a man’s return to Buenos Aires to reconnect with his father in a bustling Jewish neighborhood.
2016-08-04.snippet: A charmer with a documentary feel, this film follows a man’s return to Buenos Aires to reconnect with his father in a bustling Jewish neighborhood.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: “The Tenth Man,” a modest charmer from Argentina, breathes considerable life into the rather trite scenario of a man discovering his religious roots, in part because it seems genuinely curious about the community in which it’s set.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Review: In ‘The Tenth Man,’ Contending With a Father and a Traditional Upbringing

2016-08-04.abstract: Mohammad Daleel, 27, wounded 15 people last month, three years after entering Europe illegally through Bulgaria. He received mental health therapy, and his full identity and motives remain unclear.
2016-08-04.snippet: Mohammad Daleel, 27, wounded 15 people last month, three years after entering Europe illegally through Bulgaria. He received mental health therapy, and his full identity and motives remain unclear.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: MUNICH — To the German authorities, he was Mohammad Daleel, a 27-year-old Syrian traumatized by war who arrived in Europe seeking refuge.
2016-08-04.headline_main: How a Suicide Bomber Made His Way From Syria to Strike in Ansbach, Germany

2016-08-04.abstract: Young visitors can get to know the city’s most industrious commuter, one that travels 125 miles from the Catskill Mountains every day to serve New Yorkers.
2016-08-04.snippet: Young visitors can get to know the city’s most industrious commuter, one that travels 125 miles from the Catskill Mountains every day to serve New Yorkers.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: The Children’s Museum of Manhattan is inviting young visitors to get to know the city’s most industrious commuter: one that travels 125 miles from the Catskill Mountains every day, ascends countless high-rise floors to serve New Yorkers and leaves only after long hours, thoroughly dirty.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Wet, Wild and Wholesome: ‘Dynamic H2O’ at the Children’s Museum of Manhattan

2016-08-04.abstract: The reporter Charlie Savage wrote about an ex-Guantánamo inmate’s resettlement; the story didn’t end when the article published.
2016-08-04.snippet: The reporter Charlie Savage wrote about an ex-Guantánamo inmate’s resettlement; the story didn’t end when the article published.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: Times Insider delivers behind-the-scenes insights into how news, features and opinion come together at The New York Times. In this piece, the reporter Charlie Savage describe the impact of an article he wrote about an ex-Guantánamo detainee — on readers, the subject and the writer.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Outstanding Issues: A Yemeni Teenager’s Trip to Estonia, by Way of Guantánamo

2016-08-04.abstract: Derek Jarman’s test footage shot at an East London disco is being shown as a short feature.
2016-08-04.snippet: Derek Jarman’s test footage shot at an East London disco is being shown as a short feature.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: In 1984 the director Ron Peck asked a friend and colleague, Derek Jarman, to record test footage for a proposed feature project. About 100 nightclubbers of all stripes, many of them regular patrons of the East London disco where the test was to be shot, were invited, and presumably instructed to act naturally. For that reason, the material that Mr. Jarman captured — recently rediscovered by Mr. Peck and being shown now as a short feature titled “Will You Dance With Me?” — feels like, well, a night out at a tackily appointed, friendly dance club, documented by a regular who’s not intruding on anybody’s fun.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Review: Dim All the Lights, Again: ‘Will You Dance With Me?’

2016-08-04.abstract: Louis Black’s film is a cozily chronological ramble through a director’s career highlights and personal reminiscences.
2016-08-04.snippet: Louis Black’s film is a cozily chronological ramble through a director’s career highlights and personal reminiscences.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: If you’re not already in the bag for its subject, then “Richard Linklater: Dream Is Destiny” wants to give your arm an extra twist. Maybe its makers, Louis Black and Karen Bernstein, found neither of the two film profiles from 2014 sufficiently enthusiastic about Mr. Linklater’s resolutely outsider talents; whatever the case, they’ve decided to dive deeper into the kudos and the mind that inspired them.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Review: ‘Richard Linklater: Dream Is Destiny’ Lionizes a Maverick Talent

2016-08-04.abstract: International betting firms are offering odds on just about every event at the Summer Games, from archery to yachting.
2016-08-04.snippet: International betting firms are offering odds on just about every event at the Summer Games, from archery to yachting.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — When the Olympics open up in earnest on Saturday, you can marvel at the athletic prowess on display, cheer for your favorite country, or just enjoy the spectacle.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Bettors Can Seek Gold of Their Own During the Olympics

2016-08-04.abstract: A restoration by the Criterion Collection puts this early John Waters film back on the screen — and in theaters — in all its perverted glory.
2016-08-04.snippet: A restoration by the Criterion Collection puts this early John Waters film back on the screen — and in theaters — in all its perverted glory.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: Ah, those stodgy Nixon-era minders of the national morality. Surely they didn’t need to get as worked up as they did about the early John Waters film “Multiple Maniacs.” Or did they? It does, after all, feature rosary beads as a sex toy. And there’s the rape scene involving a giant lobster.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Review: The Lobster Scene in ‘Multiple Maniacs’? It Still Startles

2016-08-04.abstract: Preparing for two intimate Mostly Mozart Festival performances, Mr. Frost talks about silence, vibration, his instrument and Mozart’s early influence.
2016-08-04.snippet: Preparing for two intimate Mostly Mozart Festival performances, Mr. Frost talks about silence, vibration, his instrument and Mozart’s early influence.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: Think of musical virtuosity, and the qualities that most likely come to mind are speed, rhythmic complexity, and extremes of volume and pitch. Long, placid lines sound as if they should be as restful for the player as they are to the listener.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Martin Frost Explores the Soul of the Clarinet

2016-08-04.abstract: In Maris Curran’s delicate drama, a man whose wife has died goes to visit her mother, and the two slowly examine their grief.
2016-08-04.snippet: In Maris Curran’s delicate drama, a man whose wife has died goes to visit her mother, and the two slowly examine their grief.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: Maris Curran had plenty of opportunities to insert a cheesy plot twist into “Five Nights in Maine,” her delicate drama about loss and its aftermath. Yet she stayed true to her intentions, and the result is a believable character study that may not draw crowds but certainly challenges its two lead actors.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Review: ‘Five Nights in Maine’ Probes the Pain of Loss

2016-08-04.abstract: A report by Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International said Australia appeared to be subjecting migrants to abuses at an offshore processing site as "a deliberate policy to deter further asylum seekers from arriving in the country by boat."
2016-08-04.snippet: A report by Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International said Australia appeared to be subjecting migrants to abuses at an offshore processing site as "a deliberate policy to deter further asylum seekers from arriving in the country by boat."
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: A report by Human Rights Watch and Amnesty International said Australia appeared to be subjecting migrants to abuses at an offshore processing site as "a deliberate policy to deter further asylum seekers from arriving in the country by boat."
2016-08-04.headline_main: Advocacy Groups Allege Abuses on Nauru

2016-08-04.abstract: In this omnibus work about the individuality of interpretation, five filmmakers transcribed their dreams, which were then directed by others in the group as shorts.
2016-08-04.snippet: In this omnibus work about the individuality of interpretation, five filmmakers transcribed their dreams, which were then directed by others in the group as shorts.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: A throwback to the Surrealists and exquisite corpse games, the omnibus film “collective:unconscious” began from a simple premise: Five filmmakers transcribed their dreams; each description was then given at random to one of the others to direct as a short. (The film bears no relationship to the theater organization Collective:Unconscious.)
2016-08-04.headline_main: Review: ‘collective:unconscious,’ the Stuff of Dreams Reinterpreted

2016-08-04.abstract: The designer Rachel Comey and the artist Leanne Shapton have collaborated on an exhibition featuring Shapton’s abstractions of chairs, lights and tables designed by women.
2016-08-04.snippet: The designer Rachel Comey and the artist Leanne Shapton have collaborated on an exhibition featuring Shapton’s abstractions of chairs, lights and tables designed by women.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: The designer Rachel Comey and the artist Leanne Shapton have collaborated on an exhibition featuring Shapton’s abstractions of chairs, lights and tables designed by women.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Seven Female Furniture Designers

2016-08-04.abstract: Rachel Comey and Leanne Shapton have collaborated on an exhibition that celebrates the work of the sometimes-overlooked women in the field.
2016-08-04.snippet: Rachel Comey and Leanne Shapton have collaborated on an exhibition that celebrates the work of the sometimes-overlooked women in the field.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: One day this spring, Rachel Comey and Leanne Shapton were having lunch when it occurred to them that there was a blind spot in their knowledge of midcentury furniture designers: women. Comey, a fashion designer, was looking for chairs for her new store in L.A. She wanted something designed by a woman — which turned out to be a tall order. On a whim, they went to a few nearby furniture dealers in NoLIta. “We were like, ‘What have you got by women?” Shapton recalls. “And they were like: nothing.”
2016-08-04.headline_main: Rediscovering Great Female Furniture Designers

2016-08-04.abstract: A student of Gothic literary monsters assesses Donald Trump’s allure.
2016-08-04.snippet: A student of Gothic literary monsters assesses Donald Trump’s allure.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: It’s all the rage in the news media at the moment to dig into Donald J. Trump’s psyche. What mix of narcissism, psychosis and the like could possibly generate such a nonstop series of seeming miscalculations? In The Guardian, thankfully, Dean Burnett, a neuroscientist, standup comic and author of “The Idiot Brain,” has tried to tamp things down, explaining why diagnosing Trump is “likely to do more harm than good.”
2016-08-04.headline_main: An Analyst of Gothic Monsters Explores Trump’s Appeal

2016-08-04.abstract: The author of “Between the World and Me” will bring French and American thinkers together to discuss what national, social and cultural labels mean today.
2016-08-04.snippet: The author of “Between the World and Me” will bring French and American thinkers together to discuss what national, social and cultural labels mean today.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: The writer Ta-Nehisi Coates, fresh from a year living in Paris, will be the curator of the third annual Festival Albertine, a free five-day event in New York in November bringing together French and American artists and thinkers.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Ta-Nehisi Coates to Curate French-American Festival

2016-08-04.abstract: An inflammation-fighting drug for rheumatoid arthritis may offer protection against Alzheimer’s, a study suggests.
2016-08-04.snippet: An inflammation-fighting drug for rheumatoid arthritis may offer protection against Alzheimer’s, a study suggests.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: A drug used to treat rheumatoid arthritis may have benefits against Alzheimer’s disease, researchers report.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Arthritis Drug May Have Benefits Against Alzheimer’s

2016-08-04.abstract: Syrian children burned tires in Aleppo, Syria, in hopes of creating a smoke curtain to deter airstrikes.
2016-08-04.snippet: Syrian children burned tires in Aleppo, Syria, in hopes of creating a smoke curtain to deter airstrikes.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: Syrian children burned tires in Aleppo, Syria, in hopes of creating a smoke curtain to deter airstrikes.

2016-08-04.abstract: There isn’t a man in the 10-member cast of this rollicking history pageant by Jaclyn Backhaus.
2016-08-04.snippet: There isn’t a man in the 10-member cast of this rollicking history pageant by Jaclyn Backhaus.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: The Clubbed Thumb Summerworks’ production of “Men on Boats” played through the summer of 2015. Following are excerpts from Ben Brantley’s review, which appeared in The New York Times on June 24, 2015. The full text is here. The play opened on Monday at Playwrights Horizons’ Peter Jay Sharp Theater, 416 West 42nd Street, Manhattan; 212-279-4200, ticketcentral.com.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Review: A Journey Through Uncharted Waters in ‘Men on Boats’

2016-08-04.abstract: This documentary powerfully uses footage to track a group of American soldiers during a tour of duty in Afghanistan in 2011.
2016-08-04.snippet: This documentary powerfully uses footage to track a group of American soldiers during a tour of duty in Afghanistan in 2011.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: The tension in “Citizen Soldier” is enough to make you gnaw through your fingernails. This documentary, which follows a group of American G.I.s in Afghanistan in 2011, uses footage taken during their missions, sometimes via their own helmet cams. The sense of danger is palpable, as is the sense of misery after the most dreadful scenes.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Review: War Made Terrifyingly Palpable in ‘Citizen Soldier’

2016-08-04.abstract: Mr. Gulen, who lives in a self-imposed exile in Pennsylvania, is accused of plotting the July 15 coup attempt that left more than 250 people dead.
2016-08-04.snippet: Mr. Gulen, who lives in a self-imposed exile in Pennsylvania, is accused of plotting the July 15 coup attempt that left more than 250 people dead.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey issued an arrest warrant on Thursday for Fethullah Gulen, a Muslim cleric based in the United States, who was accused last month of orchestrating a failed coup against the government of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Turkey Issues a Warrant for Fethullah Gulen, Cleric Accused in Coup

2016-08-04.abstract: The latest entry in the gangster genre, this drama concerns a number cruncher who proves more useful for local gangsters than is healthy.
2016-08-04.snippet: The latest entry in the gangster genre, this drama concerns a number cruncher who proves more useful for local gangsters than is healthy.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: It’s 1973 in Brooklyn, and Santo (Troy Garity) is in a tough spot. A young man with a head for numbers, he’s married with two kids and a third on the way, and has a bright future as a vice president for a local bank. He has stayed in the neighborhood and away from the mob ties that entangle his friends and family. At least until his father-in-law, Benny (Paul Sorvino), a lieutenant for the neighborhood don, brings him to the boss, Manny, who needs a favor. “This is good for us,” Benny promises.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Review: In ‘The Brooklyn Banker,’ Troy Garity Shows Promise (With the Mob)

2016-08-04.abstract: From rousing speeches to resolutions and songs, material related to an activist phenomenon that began in the 1830s is being explored by a team at the University of Delaware.
2016-08-04.snippet: From rousing speeches to resolutions and songs, material related to an activist phenomenon that began in the 1830s is being explored by a team at the University of Delaware.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: Long before they could take any actual roles in government, black political activists sent thousands of delegates to advocacy events called “colored conventions” that were held starting in the 1830s. The activists drafted legislative petitions demanding better schools and job opportunities and legal protections from bigotry and violence.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Colored Conventions, a Rallying Point for Black Americans Before the Civil War

2016-08-04.abstract: An exhibition at Galerie Perrotin showcases the work of an innovative French designer at home with ’60s Pop and the presidential palace.
2016-08-04.snippet: An exhibition at Galerie Perrotin showcases the work of an innovative French designer at home with ’60s Pop and the presidential palace.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: Something happened to midcentury modernism in the last couple of years: It got boring. Once, the furniture of the Eameses, Eero Saarinen or a clutch of Danes still stood for design innovation; now you can order a tulip chair with one click from Design Within Reach, or head to Overstock.com for a knockoff. Maybe that’s why we’re seeing a revived interest in flashier design from the 1960s and especially the 1970s — the geometric patterns, the shag carpeting, the brass and Lucite. Heck, even “Match Game” is back.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Hanging Out on Pierre Paulin’s Recliner

2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: Capt. Antarès Bonassieu, the hero of Clément Cogitore’s debut feature, “Neither Heaven Nor Earth,” seems like a guy we’ve met before, at least in other war movies. Lean and muscular, with a thoughtful countenance under his blond brush cut, he is a seasoned soldier and a natural commander, tough on his men but capable of sensitivity when circumstances require it. (He is played by Jérémie Renier, a graceful chameleon who you may not recognize from Olivier Assayas’s “Summer Hours” or Jean-Pierre and Luc Dardenne’s “L’Enfant.”
2016-08-04.headline_main: Review: ‘Neither Heaven Nor Earth’ Engages the Horrors of War

2016-08-04.abstract: A gray corporate world rendered in computer graphics enfolds the stop-motion universe of Antoine de Saint-Exupéry’s tender tale.
2016-08-04.snippet: A gray corporate world rendered in computer graphics enfolds the stop-motion universe of Antoine de Saint-Exupéry’s tender tale.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: The masterstroke of “The Little Prince,” Mark Osborne’s reimagining of Antoine de Saint-Exupéry’s 1943 children’s classic, is its side-by-side use of two styles of animation. Today’s cold, corporate world, in which gray-faced, hunched-over adults grimly slog through life, is depicted in severe, rectilinear computer-generated animation. The magical universe of Saint-Exupéry’s wistful, poetic novella is rendered in stop-motion animation, with pastel shades that evoke his original watercolor illustrations.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Review: Fanciful Classic ‘The Little Prince’ Is Turned Into Modernist Fable

2016-08-04.abstract: In the last episodes, running on PBS, a new chief superintendent wants to cut costs, and Inspector Lewis is always in the position of proving himself.
2016-08-04.snippet: In the last episodes, running on PBS, a new chief superintendent wants to cut costs, and Inspector Lewis is always in the position of proving himself.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: When “Inspector Morse” ended — 15 years ago! — the Oxford detective Endeavour Morse keeled over in the middle of campus, his dramatic collapse and subsequent death the appropriate capstone for a series about a self-centered snob. When its spinoff “Inspector Lewis” ends in a few weeks, no one of importance will die. Call that a spoiler, but if you’ve watched Morse’s onetime sergeant, Robbie Lewis, over his nearly 30 years on television, you know that he’d find being killed off far too immodest, too attention-grabbing a fate.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Review: In Final Season of ‘Inspector Lewis,’ Solving Mysteries While Navigating a New Boss

2016-08-04.abstract: New research has revealed that the plant’s internal clock and ability to detect light work together to allow the flower to face east as the sun rises and bend to the west.
2016-08-04.snippet: New research has revealed that the plant’s internal clock and ability to detect light work together to allow the flower to face east as the sun rises and bend to the west.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: At dawn, whole fields of sunflowers stand at attention, all facing east, and begin their romance with the rising sun. As that special star appears to move across the sky, young flowers follow its light, looking up, then over and westward, catching one final glance as the sun disappears over the horizon.
2016-08-04.headline_main: How Sunflowers Follow the Sun, Day After Day

2016-08-04.abstract: In an adventure story edged with unspoken risks, the young actors take the kind of chances that their more careful elders have been trained to avoid.
2016-08-04.snippet: In an adventure story edged with unspoken risks, the young actors take the kind of chances that their more careful elders have been trained to avoid.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: There is hardly a shortage of buddy movies about mismatched men bonding under duress, but films that chart the emotional weather of everyday male friendship are rare. Literature has more to offer, at least as far as boys are concerned. Tom Sawyer and Huckleberry Finn have a rich and renewable legacy. And it may be that association that imparts a novelistic vibe to Ira Sachs’s “Little Men,” beyond the Louisa May Alcott echo in the title. It’s a subtle movie, alert to the almost imperceptible currents of feeling that pass between its title characters.
2016-08-04.headline_main: Review: In ‘Little Men,’ Boys Develop a Bond That Is Threatened by Money

2016-08-04.abstract: Though other shows featured independent women, Ms. Moore’s series really stuck with viewers, during its run, from 1970 to 1977, and after.
2016-08-04.snippet: Though other shows featured independent women, Ms. Moore’s series really stuck with viewers, during its run, from 1970 to 1977, and after.
2016-08-04.lead_paragraph: If Hillary Rodham had gone home and flipped on the TV after she delivered her Wellesley commencement address in the spring of 1969, how might she have seen the changing roles of American women reflected in popular entertainment? She could have watched Mary Tyler Moore — but it would have been in reruns of “The Dick Van Dyke Show,” where Rose Marie was the wisecracking career woman and Ms. Moore still the TV housewife, albeit the first to swap her aproned skirt for capri pants. It was not until a year after Mrs. Clinton’s classmates tossed their mortarboards that Mary Richards first tossed her tam in “The Mary Tyler Moore Show.”
2016-08-04.headline_main: Looking Back (and Learning From) ‘The Mary Tyler Moore Show’

2016-08-05.abstract: United States Coast Guard cadets and two cast members from the popular musical “Hamilton” observed Coast Guard Day aboard an 80-year-old ship in New York Harbor.
2016-08-05.snippet: United States Coast Guard cadets and two cast members from the popular musical “Hamilton” observed Coast Guard Day aboard an 80-year-old ship in New York Harbor.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: It was the morning rush in New York Harbor on Thursday when the Eagle, a majestic, 295-foot, three-masted Coast Guard ship, set sail from beneath the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. On the Eagle’s starboard side, a Staten Island Ferry chugged toward Lower Manhattan, while on its port side, a Fire Department fireboat shot plumes of water in front of the Statue of Liberty.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Celebrating a Lesser-Known Role of Hamilton: Father of the Coast Guard

2016-08-05.abstract: The Mets and Yankees’ shared angst, all in one ballpark, can be suffocating.
2016-08-05.snippet: The Mets and Yankees’ shared angst, all in one ballpark, can be suffocating.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: The Mets and the Yankees now go their separate ways, and it is just as well. They split their four-game series, two victories apiece, meaning nobody won. How fitting. The season has discouraged both teams, and their shared angst can be suffocating.
2016-08-05.headline_main: This Year’s Subway Series Is Ending Just in Time

2016-08-05.abstract: There are no checks on a president’s power to wage nuclear war, though history suggests that there may be ways to slow down or derail the process.
2016-08-05.snippet: There are no checks on a president’s power to wage nuclear war, though history suggests that there may be ways to slow down or derail the process.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: Hillary Clinton has fueled a debate over whether her rival for the presidency, Donald J. Trump, is fit to command America’s atomic forces. “Imagine him in the Oval Office facing a real crisis,” she said in her address at the Democratic convention last week. “A man you can bait with a tweet is not a man we can trust with nuclear weapons.”
2016-08-05.headline_main: Debate Over Trump’s Fitness Raises Issue of Checks on Nuclear Power

2016-08-05.abstract: The veteran cornerback brings versatility to the Giants’ secondary rotation.
2016-08-05.snippet: The veteran cornerback brings versatility to the Giants’ secondary rotation.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — During each of their three previous losing seasons, the Giants have paid the price when multiple defensive backs have been sidelined with injuries. In a pass-happy league, not having enough depth in the secondary can be the biggest roster mistake of all.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Leon Hall Signs a One-Year Pact With the Giants

2016-08-05.snippet: The playwright Lucy Teitler brings tangy wit and barbed portraiture to this tale of multiple engagement parties.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: If there’s anyone you definitely do not want at a party celebrating your coming wedding, it’s the mean-girl central character in “Engagements,” a bitingly funny but overly sour comedy by Lucy Teitler that opened on Thursday at the McGinn/Cazale Theater as part of Second Stage Theater’s Uptown summer series.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Review: In ‘Engagements,’ Meet Me in the Gazebo for Spite and Hauteur

2016-08-05.abstract: Friday themeless fun with Brendan Emmett Quigley.
2016-08-05.snippet: Friday themeless fun with Brendan Emmett Quigley.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — I think of Friday crosswords as an opportunity for the constructor to show off. Without any constrictions set by a theme (although we have seen some themed Fridays), puzzle makers can seed their Friday grids with all sorts of outrageous entries, puff up the crossings and sprinkle lots of questions marks in the clues. You get the idea. You should leave a Friday puzzle slightly bruised, but with a goofy grin on your face.
2016-08-05.headline_main: The Way the World Moves

2016-08-05.abstract: A network that included four of New York’s five Mafia families committed crimes including extortion, arson, and health care and credit card fraud, prosecutors said.
2016-08-05.snippet: A network that included four of New York’s five Mafia families committed crimes including extortion, arson, and health care and credit card fraud, prosecutors said.

2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: In my future life, I will spend entire weekends lying in a hammock by some idyllic lakeside, coolly reading thriller after thriller. As it is, I sacrificed two entire days of my Dominican Republic vacation this spring to Noah Hawley’s “Before the Fall,” and have marked Kate Summerscale’s “The Wicked Boy” (a true murderous mystery) for my vacation later this month.
2016-08-05.headline_main: 9 Thrillers (One True) That Times Editors Think You Should Read This Summer

2016-08-05.abstract: Apple, which has been criticized for not paying outside hackers who point out bugs, says it will pay as much as $200,000 to people who flag critical vulnerabilities.
2016-08-05.snippet: Apple, which has been criticized for not paying outside hackers who point out bugs, says it will pay as much as $200,000 to people who flag critical vulnerabilities.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Apple, which has been criticized in recent years for failing to pay outside hackers who report bugs in its products, said on Thursday that it would begin offering a so-called bug bounty to technologists who alert the company to flaws.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Apple Will Pay a ‘Bug Bounty’ to Hackers Who Report Flaws

2016-08-05.snippet: Dallas pursued the free agent Nick Foles after Kellen Moore was injured this week, but Foles agreed to a deal with the Kansas City Chiefs on Thursday.

2016-08-05.abstract: Fire is a rarer element than even gold at the Olympic Games. Usually, just one athlete is selected to close the opening ceremony.
2016-08-05.snippet: Fire is a rarer element than even gold at the Olympic Games. Usually, just one athlete is selected to close the opening ceremony.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Sometimes it is one of the most famous athletes in the world, like Muhammad Ali in 1996. Other times it is an archer or a cross-country skier whose name you will never hear again. But whoever it is, the person who lights the caldron at the opening ceremony is given one of the highest honors at an Olympics.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Who Will Light the Olympic Caldron in Rio? It Won’t Be Pelé

2016-08-05.abstract: The archmodernist Parisian architect Dominique Perrault went underground to create an elegant new visitors’ center that he calls a hyphen between centuries.
2016-08-05.snippet: The archmodernist Parisian architect Dominique Perrault went underground to create an elegant new visitors’ center that he calls a hyphen between centuries.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Louis XIV waged architecture as he waged war — with total commitment, huge resources and soldiers from his army — and his greatest architectural campaign was, of course, Versailles, the sprawling baroque palace he wrapped around his father’s original hunting chateau outside Paris. When his army wasn’t at war, he enlisted soldiers to help build the palace, moving in with his court in 1682.
2016-08-05.headline_main: How Do You Add to Versailles? Bravely

2016-08-05.abstract: Conservative backers of Gov. Sam Brownback, whose brand of trickle-down economics has failed, were defeated in a number of Republican primaries.
2016-08-05.snippet: Conservative backers of Gov. Sam Brownback, whose brand of trickle-down economics has failed, were defeated in a number of Republican primaries.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: Moderate Republicans who have been fighting off extinction ventured onto the primary ballot this week in the deeply red state of Kansas and scored a dozen impressive victories. The insurgents knocked off conservative loyalists of Gov. Sam Brownback, whose disastrous experiment in trickle-down economics has busted the state budget and angered voters suffering from slashed services.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Moderation Rears Its Head in Kansas

2016-08-05.abstract: She is well prepared to be our commander in chief. Donald Trump, in contrast, is a national security threat.

2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: During a 33-year career at the Central Intelligence Agency, I served presidents of both parties — three Republicans and three Democrats. I was at President George W. Bush’s side when we were attacked on Sept. 11; as deputy director of the agency, I was with President Obama when we killed Osama bin Laden in 2011.
2016-08-05.headline_main: I Ran the C.I.A. Now I’m Endorsing Hillary Clinton.

2016-08-05.abstract: Hillary Clinton shouldn’t give disaffected Republicans a less progressive agenda.
2016-08-05.snippet: Hillary Clinton shouldn’t give disaffected Republicans a less progressive agenda.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: All the experts tell us not to pay too much attention to polls for another week or two. Still, it does look as if Hillary Clinton got a big bounce from her convention, swamping her opponent’s bounce a week earlier. Better still, from the Democrats’ point of view, the swing in the polls appears to be doing what some of us thought it might: sending Donald Trump into a derp spiral, in which his ugly nonsense gets even uglier and more nonsensical as his electoral prospects sink.
2016-08-05.headline_main: No Right Turn

2016-08-05.abstract: His behavior has left them no more middle ground to keep dancing between embracing him and disowning him.
2016-08-05.snippet: His behavior has left them no more middle ground to keep dancing between embracing him and disowning him.

2016-08-05.abstract: Donald Trump’s troubling pre-emptive attack on the electoral process may be just the first move in a scheme to discredit November’s outcome.
2016-08-05.snippet: Donald Trump’s troubling pre-emptive attack on the electoral process may be just the first move in a scheme to discredit November’s outcome.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: After a week in which Donald Trump insulted babies and their mothers and war heroes and their families, and threw in fire marshals for good measure, the scariest thing to come out of his team of thugs and political mercenaries is this: the suggestion that civil unrest could follow if he’s denied the presidency.

2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: Two years ago, Kenneth Goldsmith, the University of Pennsylvania poet and conceptual artist, taught a creative writing course he called “Wasting Time on the Internet.” Students would do just that, probing the tedium of the internet. 2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: Nothing stirs passions quite like the debate over the Chinese school system. Critics say it is a test-obsessed bureaucracy that produces students who excel at reciting facts but not much else. Others argue that it is equipping children with exceptionally strong skills, particularly in math and science. Scott Rozelle, a Stanford University economist who runs a rural education program in China, is an author of a new study that challenges popular conceptions of Chinese schools. In a recent conversation, he discussed the strengths and weaknesses of the Chinese education system, as well as the advice he would offer the country’s leaders.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Weighing the Strengths and Shortcomings of China’s Education System

2016-08-05.abstract: Figuring out how to make fire was no doubt an evolutionary boon to our ancestors. But it may have led to our smoking habit and the emergence of tuberculosis.
2016-08-05.snippet: Figuring out how to make fire was no doubt an evolutionary boon to our ancestors. But it may have led to our smoking habit and the emergence of tuberculosis.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: When early humans discovered how to build fires, life became much easier in many regards. They huddled around fire for warmth, light and protection. They used it to cook, which afforded them more calories than eating raw foods that were hard to chew and digest. They could socialize into the night, which possibly gave rise to storytelling and other cultural traditions.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Smoke, Fire and Human Evolution

2016-08-05.abstract: From Eritrea, to Israel, to Rwanda, to Uganda, in search of a home.
2016-08-05.snippet: From Eritrea, to Israel, to Rwanda, to Uganda, in search of a home.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: When I first came to Israel from Eritrea four years ago, I went to a hospital and told them that I was a midwife, and that I had come to apply for a job. But they told me that I didn’t have the papers needed to do that job in their country, so I went to work in a shawarma restaurant instead. I started out cleaning dishes and washing the place. It was not easy. The money was small, and four of us lived in two rooms. I had to go every two months to renew my asylum papers. For four years, I could never be permanent. Waiting in those queues, I could think only: I have to leave here. I cannot stay.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Looking for Legal Status

2016-08-05.snippet: Announce your hearing loss. Don’t just look at the face.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: It is possible to listen with your eyes. Neuroimaging studies show that even when tested in silence, lip readers’ primary auditory cortex, the part of the brain that processes sound, is active. If you have lost some or all of your hearing, Molly Berry, a lip-reading tutor and chair of Britain’s Association of Teachers of Lipreading to Adults, suggests you start by announcing you have what she calls the invisible disability. “No one will know you’re deaf unless you tell them,” says Berry, who, like most of her students, lost her hearing after childhood: She began going deaf in her 30s and now has a cochlear implant.
2016-08-05.headline_main: How to Read Lips

2016-08-05.abstract: Patrick Cowley’s music, some of which is just now being released, reflected and later stimulated the rites of gay life in 1970s San Francisco.
2016-08-05.snippet: Patrick Cowley’s music, some of which is just now being released, reflected and later stimulated the rites of gay life in 1970s San Francisco.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: On Oct. 9, 1982, the songwriter and producer Patrick Cowley observed the release event for his third solo album, “Mind Warp,” from the mezzanine of the glamorous Galleria event space at the San Francisco Design Center. Mr. Cowley, the disco innovator who spawned hi-NRG — an up-tempo, mechanized strain of dance music calibrated for the peak of the party — wore black patent-leather pants and a matching jacket. The sickly-sweet smell of the inhalant club drug known as poppers wafted up from the dance floor, where gay men dressed in jeans and white T-shirts churned to the album’s breathless pulse. But the revelry belied the grim content of “Mind Warp,” a meditation on the body besieged that Mr. Cowley created while withering from the effects of a mysterious affliction.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Waking the Spirit of a Disco Innovator

2016-08-05.abstract: For a claustrophobe, it’s tough to get around a city that relies on elevators and subways.
2016-08-05.snippet: For a claustrophobe, it’s tough to get around a city that relies on elevators and subways.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: Every claustrophobe will tell you that it’s the elevator riders who are the crazy ones. That’s what I am muttering as I haul myself up the winding staircase to the Grand Ballroom on the third floor of the Plaza Hotel in a gown on my way to a black-tie wedding. A few minutes earlier, I had taken one look at the elevator in the lobby and determined: No way. If there was an alternate route up, I would find it. My husband shot a knowing look my way and piled into the metal box with too many other guests — an image, even as I write this, that makes me uneasy — riding what The New York Times in 1891 called the “vertical railway.”
2016-08-05.headline_main: Boxed In, Freaked Out: A Claustrophobe Navigates a Crowded City

2016-08-05.snippet: Lisa McInerney’s “The Glorious Heresies” and more.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: Irish sons are brought up to honor their mothers. To Jimmy Phelan, the most feared gangster in the city of Cork, that means cleaning up his mother’s kitchen after she bashes an intruder to a bloody pulp with a gaudy religious artifact she calls her “holy stone.” This tragicomic scene captures the wonderfully offbeat voice of Lisa McInerney, whose irreverent first novel, THE GLORIOUS HERESIES (Tim Duggan, $27), descends into the city’s seedy underworld and finds a community of alcoholics, prostitutes, drug dealers and their customers, who live like rats but speak like street poets. Ireland is gripped in a recession, and a lot of people have no jobs — but not down here, where everyone’s working in the shadow economy, selling drugs or sex or someone else’s stuff.
2016-08-05.headline_main: The Latest and Best in Crime Fiction

2016-08-05.abstract: J. D. Vance, whose memoir “Hillbilly Elegy” is No.9 on the hardcover nonfiction list, says, “It’s amazing how much just knowing other people changes the way you think and talk about them.”
2016-08-05.snippet: J. D. Vance, whose memoir “Hillbilly Elegy” is No.9 on the hardcover nonfiction list, says, “It’s amazing how much just knowing other people changes the way you think and talk about them.”
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: Moving On Up: Any way you look at it, J. D. Vance is a member of the elite — a Yale Law graduate and former biotech executive who is now, in his early 30s, a principal at a San Francisco investment firm. But it wasn’t always thus. In the memoir “Hillbilly Elegy,” new at No. 9 on the hardcover nonfiction list, Vance details his childhood in a poor Ohio town among a chaotic extended family with a mother who turned to drugs and a string of unstable relationships. Along the way, he takes a cleareyed look at some vexing and intractable problems facing the white underclass, which in my reading makes his book a kind of Appalachian version of Ta-­Nehisi Coates’s ­“Between the World and Me” (at No. 6 after 55 weeks on the list) and a more intimate companion volume to Nancy Isenberg’s cultural study “White Trash” (at No. 10 after six weeks).
2016-08-05.headline_main: Inside the List

2016-08-05.abstract: With the help of Rem Koolhaas, the designer Gaia Repossi‘s new flagship boutique is an architectural feat — not unlike her own designs.
2016-08-05.snippet: With the help of Rem Koolhaas, the designer Gaia Repossi‘s new flagship boutique is an architectural feat — not unlike her own designs.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: Micro architectures. That is how Gaia Repossi describes the fine jewelry she designs. Not as multi-carat baubles. Or haute fantasias — the provenance of most high-end jewelers. But strict architectural works conceived as human adornment. A series of segmented rings joined by a simple line across the phalanx references the Brutalist lines of Le Corbusier. Delicately looping squiggles suggest, simultaneously, the world of Calder and the spectral images of radio waves.
2016-08-05.headline_main: The Most Stunning New Store in Paris’s Haute Jewelry Mecca

2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: We’re in tomato thrall. Real tomatoes are back, in all their tomatoey glory. The cherry tomatoes at the greenmarket are so riotously colorful — bright little spheres in yellow, red, burgundy, orange and green — that I keep a big bowl of them on the kitchen table. It’s hard to pass by without grabbing a couple, as if I were reaching for a few juicy grapes or berries.

2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The Brazilian police arrested the Moroccan Olympic boxer Hassan Saada on Friday morning on charges of sexually assaulting two workers at the Olympic Village. He is to be held for 15 days, according to a court statement, making it likely that he will miss his fight scheduled for Saturday.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Moroccan Olympic Boxer Arrested on Sexual Assault Charges

2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: Some of the world’s rudest and most obnoxious people can be found on airplanes: the line jumpers, the overhead-bin hogs, the incessant talkers, the seat recliners and the armrest appropriators. And don’t forget the shrieking children and the parents who can’t or won’t keep them quiet.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Flying With Shrieking Children? Give Your Neighbors a Goody Bag

2016-08-05.snippet: Marley’s Cafe is something of a mini island paradise along the Connecticut River in Essex. The menu is almost beside the point.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: I’ll wager that most of us have enjoyed at least one memorable meal in our lives that had very little to do with food. I know I’ve been lucky enough to attend several such occasions — all of which left me with only a vague recollection of what I ate, but an indelible impression of the experience: the company I kept, the environment we shared.

2016-08-05.abstract: The operators pay homage to the traditions of the Eternal City with a modern twist, serving up dishes that are hardly parochial.
2016-08-05.snippet: The operators pay homage to the traditions of the Eternal City with a modern twist, serving up dishes that are hardly parochial.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: Pax Romana, an eating emporium that opened last February in White Plains, is a smart salute to the culinary traditions of Rome. In a city where Bloomingdale’s must stand in for the Coliseum, and the gushing water feature in front of Trump Tower at City Center is as close as you’ll get to anything remotely like the Trevi Fountain, the team at Pax Romana is valiantly turning out plates of cacio e pepe and spaghetti carbonara for an appreciative pubblico (public).
2016-08-05.headline_main: Review: At Pax Romana in White Plains, Eating as the Romans (Mostly) Do

Was it possible that the immensely popular Tutto had fallen victim to the Hamptons restaurant scene’s revolving-door epidemic?

The next in the series is the writer and National Book Award winner Andrew Solomon, who shares his list exclusively with T.

2016-08-05.abstract: Steeve Mackaya, a native of Gabon, sets up shop in Chelsea each morning, always decked out in a colorful, eye-catching suit, to sell newspapers.
2016-08-05.snippet: Steeve Mackaya, a native of Gabon, sets up shop in Chelsea each morning, always decked out in a colorful, eye-catching suit, to sell newspapers.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: Steeve Mackaya arrives each morning before rush hour with three stacks of newspapers, two milk crates and, rain or shine, a different boldly colored suit. The photographer Moshe Katvan noticed him sitting in his wheelchair and was mesmerized. “He was like a piece of New York street art, totally unbelievable and amazing,” the photographer said. “You won’t see it anywhere else in the world. I asked him what he wanted, if he wanted money. He said he wanted nothing. He just wanted to say his piece.”
2016-08-05.headline_main: The Ever-So-Stylish Newspaper Salesman

2016-08-05.abstract: A book examines the city’s conflicted role in the Civil War, which threatened lucrative partnerships between Wall Street and the South.
2016-08-05.snippet: A book examines the city’s conflicted role in the Civil War, which threatened lucrative partnerships between Wall Street and the South.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: “Because of cotton, no city in the North was more pro-South, anti-abolition or anti-Lincoln,” John Strausbaugh writes in justifying the title of his new book, “City of Sedition: The History of New York City During the Civil War” (Twelve Books, $30).
2016-08-05.headline_main: When New York, Leery of Losing Business, Leaned Dixie

2016-08-05.abstract: The birds’ population plummeted in the late 1880s as a result of plume-hunting, an inspiration for the Migratory Bird Treaty Act. They are again common in summer.
2016-08-05.snippet: The birds’ population plummeted in the late 1880s as a result of plume-hunting, an inspiration for the Migratory Bird Treaty Act. They are again common in summer.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: There is nothing as white as a snowy egret, and few things are as graceful. Watching one hunt in the shallow waters of Hamilton Beach, Queens, one early morning, I was held rapt for almost an hour by the bird’s search for prey. Its image reflected perfectly in the dark mirror of the Hawtree Creek, it was as if two birds hunted. The scene was like a masterful Japanese print; minimal, carefully rendered and capturing an ancient truth. I pitied the school of killifish the bird had targeted.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Snowy Egrets, Once Fashion Victims, Always Elegant Predators

2016-08-05.abstract: For Mr. John, Sundays are about escaping Manhattan and relaxing at his cabin in Dutchess County, where he fishes, grills, flips tires and throws knives.
2016-08-05.snippet: For Mr. John, Sundays are about escaping Manhattan and relaxing at his cabin in Dutchess County, where he fishes, grills, flips tires and throws knives.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: Daymond John, an investor on the ABC reality series “Shark Tank,” travels roughly 280 days a year. When he is in New York, chances are he is in Midtown. From the Empire State Building, Mr. John, 47, runs Fubu, an apparel company he founded with three friends in Queens nearly a quarter-century ago. After work, he simply crosses the street to get home, where he lives with his partner, Heather Taras, and their 5-month-old daughter, Minka, in a high-rise. It is a convenient setup for work, but when it is time to play he prefers woodpeckers and grass to concrete and pigeons. On weekends, he sometimes skips town and drives north to his cabin in Dutchess County, which sits on several hundred acres.
2016-08-05.headline_main: How Daymond John, a ‘Shark Tank’ Investor, Spends His Sundays

2016-08-05.abstract: There has been a surge of interest in travel to Britain following its vote to leave the European Union — and low prices may be a reason.
2016-08-05.snippet: There has been a surge of interest in travel to Britain following its vote to leave the European Union — and low prices may be a reason.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: It has not been even two months since Britain voted to leave the European Union, and already, the travel industry is seeing the effects of the decision. While it’s too soon to determine how travel to Britain will be affected in the long term, for the time being, with the exchange rate of the pound at a more than 30-year low  compared with the dollar, the region seems to be a more appealing destination for travelers from the United States.
2016-08-05.headline_main: After ‘Brexit’ Vote, a Burst of Interest in Travel to Britain

2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: SALZBURG, Austria — Thomas Adès’s new opera, “The Exterminating Angel,” based on the surreal 1962 Luis Buñuel film, had its premiere at the Salzburg Festival on July 28; it arrives at the Metropolitan Opera next year. One of the great composers of his generation, Mr. Adès, 45, has written only two previous operas — “Powder Her Face” (1995) and “The Tempest” (2003) — so this was a major event.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Thomas Adès on His Tricky Opera Adaptation of a Buñuel Film

And with prominent Republicans saying they will back Hillary Clinton and others announcing this week that they won’t endorse Mr. Trump, there has been yet another round of speculation about how the party could get rid of him.

2016-08-05.abstract: Known as the Weeds, the reed-choked interior of Spring Creek Park in the Howard Beach neighborhood, where the body of Karina Vetrano was found, has long been a part of local lore.
2016-08-05.snippet: Known as the Weeds, the reed-choked interior of Spring Creek Park in the Howard Beach neighborhood, where the body of Karina Vetrano was found, has long been a part of local lore.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: Local residents call it the Weeds. Or the Baja, because it is a dirt-filled peninsula. It is the reed-choked interior of Spring Creek Park in Howard Beach, Queens, where Karina Vetrano, 30, went alone for an evening jog on Tuesday and never came out.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Where a Queens Jogger Died, Residents Warn: Don’t Go There Alone

2016-08-05.abstract: Digital music has eaten into the record industry’s profits from album sales, but it also gives artists something appealing: more creative control.
2016-08-05.snippet: Digital music has eaten into the record industry’s profits from album sales, but it also gives artists something appealing: more creative control.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: As the music world eagerly awaits the inscrutable R&B singer Frank Ocean’s sophomore album, “Boys Don’t Cry” — which could arrive digitally at any moment via Apple Music — it’s worth considering how we got to this point of nail-chewing uncertainty about big records’ release dates.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Why Frank Ocean and Other Big Names Prefer the Sudden Digital Drop

2016-08-05.abstract: NBCUniversal’s broadcast strategy for the Rio Games will show a media giant more than ever straddling two approaches to attract viewers to is prized sports property.

2016-08-05.headline_main: NBC’s Rio Plans: A Focus on Prime Time and a Flood of Streaming

2016-08-05.abstract: Thousands of glass bottles, central to accounts of rampant cheating at the last Olympics, are set to be used at the Rio Games.
2016-08-05.snippet: Thousands of glass bottles, central to accounts of rampant cheating at the last Olympics, are set to be used at the Rio Games.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Most of the key figures involved in Russia’s elaborate doping scheme at the 2014 Sochi Olympics will not participate in the Rio Games. The lab director who blew the whistle is living in the United States, and implicated government officials were told not to attend.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Doping Sample Bottles, No Longer Seen as Tamper-Proof, Endure

2016-08-05.abstract: Readers solve the mysterious case of the little boy from Minnesota with fevers and night sweats.
2016-08-05.snippet: Readers solve the mysterious case of the little boy from Minnesota with fevers and night sweats.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: On Thursday we asked Well readers to take on the case of a 7-year-old boy who’d been having fevers and drenching sweats nightly for over a month. More than 300 of you wrote in, and although 20 of you came up with the right diagnosis, only three of you figured out both the diagnosis and the test needed to confirm it.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Think Like a Doctor: The Boy With Nighttime Fevers Solved!

2016-08-05.abstract: Members of the Turkish parliament explain how the July 15 coup attempt is seen in Turkey.
2016-08-05.snippet: Members of the Turkish parliament explain how the July 15 coup attempt is seen in Turkey.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: Turkey is making a full-court press to get the United States to extradite Fethullah Gulen, a Muslim cleric who has lived in exile in Pennsylvania for nearly 20 years and is accused by the government of masterminding the July 15 aborted coup. As part of that effort, a delegation of Turkish parliament members held talks with American officials in Washington, D.C., this week. Three of them – Taha Ozhan, chairman of the foreign affairs committee, delegation leader and a member of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s AK Party; Oguz Kaan Salici of the main opposition Republican People’s Party; and Kamil Aydin, of the Nationalist Movement Party, another opposition party — also met The New York Times Editorial Board, which recently published an editorial criticizing Turkey for accusing the United States of complicity in the insurrection and fueling a new wave of anti-Americanism.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Conversations: Why Many Turks Blame the United States for the Coup

2016-08-05.abstract: The actor Michael Cerveris describes the resonance of a special performance the cast gave in Florida to honor the victims of the Pulse nightclub massacre.
2016-08-05.snippet: The actor Michael Cerveris describes the resonance of a special performance the cast gave in Florida to honor the victims of the Pulse nightclub massacre.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: Six weeks after the mass shootings at the Pulse nightclub in Orlando, Fla., the cast of “Fun Home” left Broadway to put on a special benefit performance there. “Fun Home,” which won the Tony Award for best musical last year, is a poignant exploration of family relationships, sexuality and suicide adapted from a graphic memoir by the cartoonist Alison Bechdel, who is represented in the show by three actresses playing her at different stages of her life.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Taking ‘Fun Home’ to Orlando, for a Catharsis Onstage and Off

2016-08-05.abstract: A combination of computer-generated animation, paper cutouts and stop-motion effects gave dimension to the story.
2016-08-05.snippet: A combination of computer-generated animation, paper cutouts and stop-motion effects gave dimension to the story.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: When the director Mark Osborne was asked to adapt Antoine de Saint-Exupéry’s popular 1943 novella “The Little Prince” into a computer-generated animation film, he was skeptical about the chances of success.

2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: MENLO PARK, Calif. — When Dell first announced its $67 billion deal to buy the fellow technology giant EMC last year, the transaction faced no small amount of skepticism — in large part because it was simply so expensive.

2016-08-05.abstract: It was the first major assault in nearly two years in a restive part of the state of Assam, where an ethnic group has been clamoring for autonomy.
2016-08-05.snippet: It was the first major assault in nearly two years in a restive part of the state of Assam, where an ethnic group has been clamoring for autonomy.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Militant separatists armed with grenades and assault rifles attacked a crowded market in the northeast state of Assam on Friday, killing at least 13 people and wounding 16, police officials said. It was the first major assault in the restive region in nearly two years.
2016-08-05.headline_main: 13 Killed in Separatist Attack in Northeastern India

2016-08-05.abstract: Tatiana Baganova’s Provincial Dances Theater and the Rosie Herrera Dance Theater aimed for surreal effects in performances at the Joyce Theater.
2016-08-05.snippet: Tatiana Baganova’s Provincial Dances Theater and the Rosie Herrera Dance Theater aimed for surreal effects in performances at the Joyce Theater.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: The American Dance Festival, six weeks of performances and classes in Durham, N.C., wrapped up in July. But this summer, the festival has had a New York coda of sorts, presenting two artists from its 82nd season at the Joyce Theater: Tatiana Baganova and her company Provincial Dances Theater, from Yekaterinburg, Russia, and the Cuban-American choreographer Rosie Herrera, whose troupe is based in Miami.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Sandbaths, a Huge Butterfly Net and More Choreographed Whimsy

2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Importing Jesse Eisenberg’s “The Spoils” to this city was not exactly a no-brainer. Written by and starring Mr. Eisenberg, this lacerating comedy of humiliation — about a whiny, rich, hyper-articulate and terminally narcissistic young New Yorker who impulsively sabotages his own life and that of his Nepalese roommate — appeared destined to be lost in translation.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Jesse Eisenberg on the Surprising Success of ‘The Spoils’ in London

2016-08-05.abstract: Thousands of teachers and university deans were purged after the attempted coup, but the ripple effects to American academics are just starting to emerge.

2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: Kevin Spacey, Jennifer Garner and Christopher Walken at least chose to be in “Nine Lives.” The cast member you really feel bad for is the cat. It presumably was forced into the job by its manager, or agent, or whatever. Its résumé may never recover.
2016-08-05.headline_main: Review: In ‘Nine Lives,’ a Man’s Life Is Like a Litter Box

2016-08-05.abstract: The 13-member team includes several billionaire bankers and investment managers, but no women and few economists.
2016-08-05.snippet: The 13-member team includes several billionaire bankers and investment managers, but no women and few economists.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump may rail against Wall Street and business elites at his campaign rallies, but that has not stopped him from turning to many of them for economic advice. On Friday, Mr. Trump announced his economic team, just days before he is expected to give a speech in Detroit on Monday about what he would do to improve American growth.

2016-08-05.abstract: The seven additions could include swimmers, cyclists and a wrestler with previous doping violations who have served their punishments.
2016-08-05.snippet: The seven additions could include swimmers, cyclists and a wrestler with previous doping violations who have served their punishments.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: After weeks of debate over Russia’s participation in the Rio Games, Olympic officials announced Thursday — less than 24 hours before the opening ceremony — that 271 Russian athletes would compete in Rio. They excluded more than 100 others, branding them tainted by a government doping program.

He went into a vegetable market and got so caught up recording the sound of birds in its rafters that he almost got hit by a cabbage-laden forklift hurtling toward him.

2016-08-05.snippet: The work of grass-roots organizations to make streets safer doesn’t get news media attention.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: IT has become a standard conservative talking point: Black activists focus on police brutality but ignore violent crime in black neighborhoods. Last month Rudy Giuliani said on Fox News: “If they meant ‘Black Lives Matter,’ they would be doing something about the way in which the vast majority of blacks are killed in America, which is by other blacks.”
2016-08-05.headline_main: Black Activists Don’t Ignore Crime

2016-08-05.abstract: A guide to the day’s major competitions.
2016-08-05.snippet: A guide to the day’s major competitions.
2016-08-05.lead_paragraph: Women’s Soccer: The United States figures to get an early challenge from France in its second preliminary game. The French were in line to face the Americans in the semifinals of last year’s World Cup with six minutes to go in France’s match with Germany. France had a 1-0 lead, but a controversial hand-ball call enabled Germany to tie the score on a penalty kick. Germany then went on to win in a shootout, 5-4, delaying France’s coming-out party.
2016-08-05.headline_main: The Olympic Events to Watch: Saturday

2016-08-06.abstract: Mark Teixeira had two hits and scored twice on Friday night. Andrew Miller did not play in his return to New York after being traded last Sunday.
2016-08-06.snippet: Mark Teixeira had two hits and scored twice on Friday night. Andrew Miller did not play in his return to New York after being traded last Sunday.
2016-08-06.lead_paragraph: During parts of two seasons with the Yankees, reliever Andrew Miller kept with tradition and stayed perpetually clean-shaven. When he returned to the Bronx on Friday as a member of the Cleveland Indians, Miller sported a noticeable swath of facial hair, looking more relaxed.
2016-08-06.headline_main: Starlin Castro Hits His First Grand Slam as the Yankees Top the Indians

2016-08-06.abstract: Mr. Trump, who had caused a rift by withholding support for Mr. Ryan, also called for the re-election of Senator Kelly Ayotte as he sought to move past a tumultuous week.
2016-08-06.snippet: Mr. Trump, who had caused a rift by withholding support for Mr. Ryan, also called for the re-election of Senator Kelly Ayotte as he sought to move past a tumultuous week.
2016-08-06.lead_paragraph: GREEN BAY, Wis. — Donald J. Trump belatedly endorsed the re-elections of Speaker Paul D. Ryan and Senators John McCain and Kelly Ayotte on Friday, moving to heal a deepening rift within the Republican Party touched off by Mr. Trump’s feud with the parents of a slain American soldier.
2016-08-06.headline_main: Donald Trump Endorses Paul Ryan and John McCain in Bid for G.O.P. Unity

2016-08-06.abstract: It’s because of President Nixon, who did turn out to be a “crook.”
2016-08-06.snippet: It’s because of President Nixon, who did turn out to be a “crook.”
2016-08-06.lead_paragraph: Boston — Lost in the debate over Donald J. Trump’s refusal to release his tax returns is the story of where the custom of disclosure comes from — and why it can be so valuable as a measure of character. It’s a tale of presidential tax shenanigans, political scandal and one of the most famous quotations in American history: Richard M. Nixon’s “I am not a crook.”
2016-08-06.headline_main: Why We Ask to See Candidates’ Tax Returns

2016-08-06.abstract: Omar Mateen, whose June 12 shooting at an Orlando nightclub left 49 dead, was shot at least eight times by responding police officers.
2016-08-06.snippet: Omar Mateen, whose June 12 shooting at an Orlando nightclub left 49 dead, was shot at least eight times by responding police officers.
2016-08-06.lead_paragraph: The authorities in Florida said Friday that Omar Mateen, whose June 12 rampage  at an Orlando nightclub left 49 other people dead, was shot at least eight times by police officers who responded to the deadly mass shooting.
2016-08-06.headline_main: Orlando Gunman Was Shot at Least 8 Times, Autopsy Finds

2016-08-06.abstract: Addressing the global exodus of refugees and migrants will require concrete, binding commitments.
2016-08-06.snippet: Addressing the global exodus of refugees and migrants will require concrete, binding commitments.
2016-08-06.lead_paragraph: Diplomats at the United Nations spent several months trying to come up with a comprehensive plan to address today’s flow of refugees and migrants, the largest since World War II. So far they have failed, as became clear last month when they released a platitude-laden blueprint for a discussion of the crisis by world leaders who will convene in New York in September.
2016-08-06.headline_main: Stuck in Platitudes on Migration Crisis

2016-08-06.abstract: Remembering the days when kids were free to roam.
2016-08-06.snippet: Remembering the days when kids were free to roam.

2016-08-06.headline_main: Paris Attraction

2016-08-06.abstract: Politicians, educators and advocates of every stripe have offered clashing views on the results of this year’s standardized exams.
2016-08-06.snippet: Politicians, educators and advocates of every stripe have offered clashing views on the results of this year’s standardized exams.
2016-08-06.lead_paragraph: When the New York State Education Department announced scores last week from this year’s standardized tests, it led with the good news — nearly 38 percent of students statewide were proficient in English and about 39 percent were proficient in math, up from the previous year’s results. But it also warned that the scores could not be compared with previous results “apples to apples,” because of changes in the way the tests were written and given.
2016-08-06.headline_main: New York State Test Scores Inspire Conflicting Interpretations

2016-08-06.abstract: The government always seems to be making, neglecting, forgetting and rediscovering its covenant with veterans.
2016-08-06.snippet: The government always seems to be making, neglecting, forgetting and rediscovering its covenant with veterans.
2016-08-06.lead_paragraph: Speaking to disabled veterans on Monday in Atlanta, President Obama discussed his administration’s efforts to end “the tragedy, the travesty” of veteran homelessness. He proudly declared the glass half full. “We have now reduced the number of homeless veterans by 47 percent,” he said. The number of homeless veterans is now under 40,000.
2016-08-06.headline_main: Broken Promises to Homeless Vets

2016-08-06.abstract: Beisel, who won two medals at the 2012 Games, was a prodigy on the piano and violin and still has aspirations when her Olympic career reaches its conclusion.
2016-08-06.snippet: Beisel, who won two medals at the 2012 Games, was a prodigy on the piano and violin and still has aspirations when her Olympic career reaches its conclusion.
2016-08-06.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — This city pulses with an energy that compels a bus driver to fill the silence with song as he sits idly in traffic. It pulses with a rhythm that prompts a woman on a custodial crew in Olympic Park to thrum on a garbage can lid to music only she can hear as an elevator sweeps her off the ground floor. Like her Brazilian hosts, the United States Olympian Elizabeth Beisel has the music in her, too.
2016-08-06.headline_main: Olympic Swimmer Elizabeth Beisel Has Music Dripping From Her Fingertips

2016-08-06.abstract: A mauling death brought new attention to the issue of unattended dogs, with a study finding that dog bites in the city had increased 15 percent a year since 2013.
2016-08-06.snippet: A mauling death brought new attention to the issue of unattended dogs, with a study finding that dog bites in the city had increased 15 percent a year since 2013.
2016-08-06.lead_paragraph: As consultants drove through the streets of southern Dallas this summer to document the city’s increasing population of loose dogs, they found some residents walking with sticks in hand, in case they had to fend one off.

2016-08-06.lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — The Jets have practiced eight times this training camp, which means that eight times — in the humidity of their field house inside, or the scorching temperatures outside — they have competed against one another for balls, for attention, for roster spots. Five of those practices, including Friday’s, were conducted in pads.
2016-08-06.headline_main: Jets’ Practice Turns Testy as Two Stars Get Into a Skirmish

2016-08-06.abstract: The opening ceremony, when it finally arrived on tape delay, was firmly in the approved, Cirque du Soleil style. But NBC couldn’t obscure the parts that took on larger concerns.
2016-08-06.snippet: The opening ceremony, when it finally arrived on tape delay, was firmly in the approved, Cirque du Soleil style. But NBC couldn’t obscure the parts that took on larger concerns.

2016-08-06.lead_paragraph: Sulu, gho, kera, kalpak, dishdasha and dashiki sound more like crossword puzzlers than words in common parlance. Yet they are the names of elements of costumes that, for centuries, denoted national identity and are now taken out of cultural mothballs for the Olympics.

Prime-time coverage of the Rio Olympics dives in with swimming, beach volleyball and men’s gymnastics. And some Scandinavian films show off the darker sides of Alicia Vikander and Noomi Rapace.

2016-08-06.abstract: A hygiene problem, damage from a contractor, and tracking work on a co-op’s exterior.
2016-08-06.snippet: A hygiene problem, damage from a contractor, and tracking work on a co-op’s exterior.
2016-08-06.lead_paragraph: In recent months, an overwhelming smell of cat urine has been seeping into my co-op apartment from the adjacent one. I can smell it emanating from the floor in every part of my space that shares a wall with the neighboring unit. I can also hear a cat crying all day. I warned the neighbor twice, in writing, to rectify the situation, but received no response. Eventually I’d like to sell the apartment, but I can’t until this situation is resolved. So I need to build a case against the neighbor to bring to the co-op board or to initiate a lawsuit. How do I begin? What sort of professional could give me an estimate for the damage done to my wood floors? Should I call the Queens County health inspector?
2016-08-06.headline_main: The Smell of Cat Urine From Next Door

2016-08-06.abstract: Mutual membership in the European Union had helped Britain and Ireland repair their relationship. Now, Britain’s vote to leave the union promises to redefine it.
2016-08-06.snippet: Mutual membership in the European Union had helped Britain and Ireland repair their relationship. Now, Britain’s vote to leave the union promises to redefine it.
2016-08-06.lead_paragraph: DUNDALK, Ireland — Gerard McEvoy’s daily commute across the border between his home in the United Kingdom and his workplace in Ireland takes just 10 minutes, and the only hint that he is in a different country is when the road signs change from miles to kilometers.
2016-08-06.headline_main: A Question Lingers on the Irish Border: What’s Next?

2016-08-06.abstract: It was only a matter of time before Cox and Rathvon put this in a puzzle.
2016-08-06.snippet: It was only a matter of time before Cox and Rathvon put this in a puzzle.
2016-08-06.lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — The Broadway musical “Hamilton” has captured the imaginations of many people, including our constructors Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon. One of the characters in the play by Lin-Manuel Miranda, HERCULES MULLIGAN, appears in today’s acrostic quote as a hero who never made it to the history books, but whose contributions to the founding of our nation should be remembered.
2016-08-06.headline_main: Variety Puzzle: Acrostic

2016-08-06.abstract: The original K.G.B. chief’s diaries, long hidden, state outright for the first time that Mr. Wallenberg, a Swedish diplomat and war hero, was executed in a Moscow prison.
2016-08-06.snippet: The original K.G.B. chief’s diaries, long hidden, state outright for the first time that Mr. Wallenberg, a Swedish diplomat and war hero, was executed in a Moscow prison.
2016-08-06.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The 1945 disappearance of Raoul Wallenberg — a Swedish diplomat who  saved thousands of Hungarian Jews from Nazi gas chambers — ranks among the most enduring mysteries of World War II.
2016-08-06.headline_main: From a Dacha Wall, a Clue to Raoul Wallenberg’s Cold War Fate

2016-08-06.abstract: Miles Chamley-Watson’s splashy maneuver, in which he whips his sword around the back of his head to score a point, has come to be known as the Chamley-Watson.
2016-08-06.snippet: Miles Chamley-Watson’s splashy maneuver, in which he whips his sword around the back of his head to score a point, has come to be known as the Chamley-Watson.
2016-08-06.lead_paragraph: A fencing bout, even at the Olympics, is generally fairly straightforward. The two combatants face each other, a tone sounds, they lunge, and a few seconds later someone has scored a point.
2016-08-06.headline_main: U.S. Fencer Attacks and Parries. Then, Whoa, What Was That?

2016-08-06.abstract: Some Republican strategists are prepared to create ads that concede the White House to Hillary Clinton and urge voters to support down-ballot candidates who would keep the party in charge of Congress.

Trump is a threat to the party’s fortunes and have begun discussing how soon their endangered candidates should explicitly distance themselves from the presidential nominee.

Trump last week, Priorities USA, a Democratic “super PAC” supporting Hillary Clinton, piled on with two ads, one featuring a former prisoner of war, and one, showing prominent Republicans denouncing their party’s standard-bearer, entitled “Danger.”
2016-08-06.headline_main: Ad Paints a Portrait of a Republican Party in Disarray

2016-08-06.abstract: A blast tore apart a car carrying Igor V. Plotnitsky, the president of the self-proclaimed Luhansk People’s Republic.

2016-08-06.snippet: The scandals are casting a pall over the achievements of the Front for Victory, the political party of the former president, Cristina Fernández de Kirchner.
2016-08-06.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — One former minister was caught in a convent with about $9 million in cash and luxury watches stuffed into duffel bags. Two others have been indicted on corruption charges, as has a former vice president. Then there is Cristina Fernández de Kirchner, the former president, whose hotel and real estate businesses are being investigated for alleged involvement in a kickback scheme.
2016-08-06.headline_main: Air of Graft Around Ex-Argentine Government Arouses Fury

2016-08-06.abstract: The campaign against legal activists is part of a pattern that’s dismally familiar in the annals of authoritarian governments.
2016-08-06.snippet: The campaign against legal activists is part of a pattern that’s dismally familiar in the annals of authoritarian governments.
2016-08-06.lead_paragraph: Thursday was Zhou Shifeng’s turn to take the stage in the Chinese inquisition. Mr. Zhou, a lawyer who worked with people who challenged the Communist Party, was charged with “spreading subversive thoughts” under the influence of “anti-China forces” and sentenced to seven years in prison.
2016-08-06.headline_main: Show Trials in China

2016-08-06.snippet: Readers discuss the lifesaving benefits of naloxone to treat a heroin overdose versus the risk that it may encourage addiction.
2016-08-06.lead_paragraph: Naloxone saves lives after a heroin overdose, but does it also encourage addiction?
2016-08-06.headline_main: Treating Heroin Addicts
