2016-08-08.abstract: In Toronto, Binu Binu makes sculptural bars packed with nourishing oils that take inspiration from the Korean bathhouse.
2016-08-08.snippet: In Toronto, Binu Binu makes sculptural bars packed with nourishing oils that take inspiration from the Korean bathhouse.
2016-08-08.lead_paragraph: A Korean body scrub is a spa experience not easily forgotten — the intensely exfoliating rubdown requires a certain amount of grit and courage. For the Toronto native Karen Kim, 36, the memory of her Korean grandmother buffing her body when she was 5 years old left a lasting impression: “The vigor and determination!” she says of the sloughing technique. “It was painful but effective.” Years later, when she was in her 20s, Kim traveled to Seok Mo Do, a fishing island off the coast of South Korea, with her mother and five aunts. Most days revolved around trips to the public baths and cleansing rituals. “Every morning, we’d take our sponges and buckets, and sit in the bath all day,” she says. “My Korean isn’t very good, so it was hard to communicate, but this was an intimate bonding moment.”
2016-08-08.headline_main: Brand to Know: Traditional Soap, Made Modern

2016-08-08.abstract: For a look inside Creative Artists Agency, the author has simply organized more than 700 pages of raw interviews in more or less chronological order.
2016-08-08.snippet: For a look inside Creative Artists Agency, the author has simply organized more than 700 pages of raw interviews in more or less chronological order.
2016-08-08.lead_paragraph: With the fall of the studio system, when actors labored under long-term employment contracts, came the rise of the talent agents, those mysterious professionals whose job is to procure employment for artists. The mystery extends from what agents actually do to the economics of the agencies where they work, as all the major industry players are private and notoriously secretive. In “Powerhouse: The Untold Story of Hollywood’s Creative Artists Agency,” James Andrew Miller has taken on the formidable task of lifting the veil on the sector.
2016-08-08.headline_main: Review: ‘Powerhouse’ Lifts Veil on Secretive Hollywood Agency

2016-08-08.abstract: In a new book, Luke Dittrich looks at the relationship between Dr. William Scoville and a patient and finds a dark history of mental health experimentation.
2016-08-08.snippet: In a new book, Luke Dittrich looks at the relationship between Dr. William Scoville and a patient and finds a dark history of mental health experimentation.
2016-08-08.lead_paragraph: As a boy growing up in Massachusetts, Luke Dittrich revered his grandfather, a brain surgeon whose home was full of exotic instruments. Later, he learned that he was not only a prominent doctor but had played a significant role in modern medical history.
2016-08-08.headline_main: A Brain Surgeon’s Legacy Through a Grandson’s Eyes

2016-08-08.abstract: Humberto Leon and Carol Lim have collaborated with Calvin Klein on a T-shirt of a Kate Moss ad from that year — and reminisce about the decade with T.
2016-08-08.snippet: Humberto Leon and Carol Lim have collaborated with Calvin Klein on a T-shirt of a Kate Moss ad from that year — and reminisce about the decade with T.
2016-08-08.lead_paragraph: The Opening Ceremony founders Humberto Leon and Carol Lim agree that 1993 was a formative year. For one, they both graduated from suburban Los Angeles high schools. “That summer was pivotal,” Lim says. “I could really enjoy myself because I’d gotten into college, so I backpacked through Europe for four months.” And that fall, they enrolled at University of California, Berkeley, where they met and, Leon recalls, quickly bonded over their shared affinity for polyester outfits. “At the time, we looked to magazines and what our favorite actors and musicians were wearing,” he remembers. “As an 18-year-old kid, you’re trying to emulate the people you admire.” In the pre-internet era, the pair had to conduct nondigital “research,” as Lim calls it — queuing for the latest issue of Interview or the Face, or scrutinizing 10,000 Maniacs music videos.
2016-08-08.headline_main: The Opening Ceremony Founders on the Importance of 1993

2016-08-08.abstract: Roy Scranton’s first novel builds on themes he has raised in essays, that focusing on the trauma of soldiers neglects the destruction they caused.
2016-08-08.snippet: Roy Scranton’s first novel builds on themes he has raised in essays, that focusing on the trauma of soldiers neglects the destruction they caused.
2016-08-08.lead_paragraph: In a controversial essay published in the Los Angeles Review of Books in 2015, Roy Scranton, a United States Army veteran who served in Iraq, argued that our perception of war has been warped by modern war literature’s preoccupation with what he called “the trauma hero myth.”
2016-08-08.headline_main: Review: ‘War Porn’ Widens the Field of Vision About the Costs in Iraq

2016-08-08.abstract: The Turkish president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, is visiting his Russian counterpart, Vladimir V. Putin, to discuss Syria and trade.
2016-08-08.snippet: The Turkish president, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, is visiting his Russian counterpart, Vladimir V. Putin, to discuss Syria and trade.
2016-08-08.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and his Turkish counterpart, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, are expected to reconsider their dispute over Syria at a meeting on Tuesday in St. Petersburg, with both leaders interested in a public display of affection to show the West that strained ties have not left them isolated.
2016-08-08.headline_main: Putin and Erdogan, Both Isolated, Reach Out to Each Other

2016-08-08.abstract: A movement toward largely nonmedical approaches, focused on holistic recovery rather than symptom treatment, is growing in the United States.
2016-08-08.snippet: A movement toward largely nonmedical approaches, focused on holistic recovery rather than symptom treatment, is growing in the United States.
2016-08-08.lead_paragraph: HOLYOKE, Mass. — Some of the voices inside Caroline White’s head have been a lifelong comfort, as protective as a favorite aunt. It was the others — “you’re nothing, they’re out to get you, to kill you” — that led her down a rabbit hole of failed treatments and over a decade of hospitalizations, therapy and medications, all aimed at silencing those internal threats.
2016-08-08.headline_main: An Alternative Form of Mental Health Care Gains a Foothold

2016-08-08.snippet: Deputy Sports Editor Jay Schreiber observed his colleague Karen Crouse as she watched pre-Olympic swimming activity.

2016-08-08.abstract: Thirty years after the release of her album “Control,” Janet Jackson remains essential to the development of pop and the integration of MTV.
2016-08-08.snippet: Thirty years after the release of her album “Control,” Janet Jackson remains essential to the development of pop and the integration of MTV.
2016-08-08.lead_paragraph: The standard for planet-stopping artistic statements in pop music is now so high that you need a pilot’s license to compete with the Beyoncés, Kanyes and Kendricks of the world. But when Janet Jackson craved ascent, she didn’t go to flight school. She went to Flyte Tyme. That was the Minneapolis production company Jimmy Jam and Terry Lewis operated and where the three came up with “Control,” Ms. Jackson’s third record and the first of their subtly strange, sonically complex thematic carnivals. The album turned 30 in February, peaked in popularity right about this time that year (hitting No. 1 in July) and still sounds today as much like 1986 as it does 2056. Some producers make hooks. These three made wedgies.
2016-08-08.headline_main: Sorry, Ms. Jackson: You’re Underrated. ‘Control’ at 30

2016-08-09.abstract: This episode’s final glimpse of Quinn and Rachel tells us that the show remembers what matters. But some serious questions remain for “UnREAL.”
2016-08-09.snippet: This episode’s final glimpse of Quinn and Rachel tells us that the show remembers what matters. But some serious questions remain for “UnREAL.”
2016-08-09.lead_paragraph: A show as meta as “UnREAL” faces the problem that often confronts satire: if you skewer a genre well enough, you might eventually become it. This season has struggled, partly by aiming for network-drama polish rather than self-aware pulp. “Everlasting” is a show about people seeking triumph amid inescapable falsity; everything in “UnREAL” echoes that, with an edge. Adding tertiary love interests and subplots just provided the season with stumbling blocks. This finale, more than anything, needed to put what mattered — Rachel, Quinn, behind-the-scenes satire, occasional heartbreak — back in the center and trust it to hold.
2016-08-09.headline_main: ‘UnREAL’ Season 2 Finale: Trust Me

2016-08-09.abstract: Yulia Efimova, King’s rival who served a 16-month doping suspension, secured silver.

2016-08-09.abstract: The team of producers behind “The Complete Concert by the Sea” are putting together a compilation of the pianist’s studio work from 1967 to 1971.
2016-08-09.snippet: The team of producers behind “The Complete Concert by the Sea” are putting together a compilation of the pianist’s studio work from 1967 to 1971.
2016-08-09.lead_paragraph: Last fall the pianist Erroll Garner achieved a rare posthumous distinction when “The Complete Concert by the Sea” entered the Billboard Jazz Albums chart at No. 1. A restored and expanded version of “Concert by the Sea” — the 1956 release that solidified Garner’s popular image, and one of the best-selling jazz albums in history — it featured 11 previously unissued tracks and a greatly improved sound mix in a three-CD boxed set.
2016-08-09.headline_main: Erroll Garner Recordings Unearthed for a New Album

2016-08-09.abstract: Opdivo didn’t help my wife, or almost anyone else. So why can Bristol-Myers Squibb market it on TV?
2016-08-09.snippet: Opdivo didn’t help my wife, or almost anyone else. So why can Bristol-Myers Squibb market it on TV?
2016-08-09.lead_paragraph: TOWSON, Md. — Two days into a long-dreamed-of family vacation to Italy in August 2013, my wife, Ronna, became nauseated, unusually tired and short of breath. One of the great non-complainers in American history, she insisted that it was no big deal and valiantly tried to join in on various outings in the Italian countryside. But, after a few increasingly difficult days, even Ronna knew that it was time to go to the emergency room.
2016-08-09.headline_main: Cancer-Drug Ads vs. Cancer-Drug Reality

2016-08-09.abstract: Service members who have been assaulted shouldn’t have to add “other-than-honorable” discharge to their injustices.
2016-08-09.snippet: Service members who have been assaulted shouldn’t have to add “other-than-honorable” discharge to their injustices.
2016-08-09.lead_paragraph: LA CROSSE, Wis. — When my daughter, Carri Leigh Goodwin, joined the Marine Corps in July 2007, she was a shy, quiet 18-year-old who loved reading and writing poetry. She joined the Marines to make me proud — I’m a former Marine — and to her surprise, she turned out to be good with a gun.
2016-08-09.headline_main: What the Military Owes Rape Survivors Like My Daughter

2016-08-09.abstract: The United Nations Security Council should impose an embargo on arms shipments as part of a solution to end the killing and other abuses.
2016-08-09.snippet: The United Nations Security Council should impose an embargo on arms shipments as part of a solution to end the killing and other abuses.
2016-08-09.lead_paragraph: Since the founding of the nation of South Sudan five years ago, its citizens have gone from a brief moment of exhilaration and promise to the cruel reality of tribal violence, depredation and despair. Their leaders have failed them, and so has the United Nations Security Council, which is once again scrambling for a solution to end rampant killing and other abuses. One move the Council could make immediately is to impose a long-overdue embargo on arms shipments, especially to the government forces that have been largely responsible for the bloodshed.
2016-08-09.headline_main: Time to Get Serious With South Sudan

2016-08-09.abstract: Money can buy privacy, but privacy often makes life worse.
2016-08-09.snippet: Money can buy privacy, but privacy often makes life worse.
2016-08-09.lead_paragraph: In 18th-century America, colonial society and Native American society sat side by side. The former was buddingly commercial; the latter was communal and tribal. As time went by, the settlers from Europe noticed something: No Indians were defecting to join colonial society, but many whites were defecting to live in the Native American one.
2016-08-09.headline_main: The Great Affluence Fallacy

2016-08-09.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump has laid out his economic vision, and it included deep tax cuts for the wealthy, tearing up climate change agreements and abandoning trade deals. He insisted, “We can’t fix a rigged system by relying on the people who rigged it in the first place,” highlighting the fine line that he has to tread between between being anti-elite and yet absolutely elite. It’s tough to be seen as a successful billionaire businessman who is also an outsider trying to work for the little guy.

2016-08-09.abstract: A simple trick can make it easier to stick to a budget: Insert some time between your impulse to purchase and the moment you pull out the credit card.
2016-08-09.snippet: A simple trick can make it easier to stick to a budget: Insert some time between your impulse to purchase and the moment you pull out the credit card.
2016-08-09.lead_paragraph: I’m going to assume for a minute that you’re one of the millions of people who have a recurrently frustrating relationship with spending. It probably starts with a commitment to sticking to your budget, and you do for a few days. Then, despite your resolve, you break down, pull out the credit card and do something that you promised you wouldn’t. You wake up in the morning ashamed and resolve never to do it again.
2016-08-09.headline_main: One Secret to Cutting Spending: Wait 72 Hours Before You Buy

Four days later, a 17-year-old man attacked passengers with an ax on a train near Würzburg, Germany. Four days after that, an 18-year-old man shot dead nine people in a Munich shopping mall.

2016-08-09.lead_paragraph: What do literary tourists look for when they visit the British Isles? Often it’s the quaint, old-fashioned bookshops that provide the perfect excuse to browse uninterrupted and to disconnect from the world. Until recently, the trend for barista-made coffee and high-speed Wi-Fi was considered by some in the city’s bookish crowd to be ruining London’s centuries-old tradition of disconnected browsing.
2016-08-09.headline_main: London Bookstores Go Rogue as No Wi-Fi Zones

2016-08-09.lead_paragraph: The notion of nodding off under the stars to the crackle of a fire in the shadow of ancient ponderosa pines sounds dreamy. Here’s the catch. Though I love communing with nature, I detest discomfort. This includes interacting with moist soil and insects as well as partaking in tiresome camp chores like tent pitching, fire making, food schlepping and foraging for makeshift, leave-no-trace toilets.

2016-08-09.abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: A school for war victims opens in Neuilly-sur-Marne in August 1916.
2016-08-09.snippet: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: A school for war victims opens in Neuilly-sur-Marne in August 1916.
2016-08-09.lead_paragraph: PARIS — M. Justin Godart, Under-Secretary of State for the Military Health Service, inaugurated yesterday afternoon [Aug. 8] at the Maison-Blanche, Neuilly-sur-Marne, a new institution for ‘‘re-educating’’ maimed soldiers. Its organization is due to the initiative of the Union des Colonies Etrangères en France, which comprises eighteen groups of friendly foreign colonies. The school is divided into two sections, one for teaching French, English, book-keeping, shorthand, typewriting, etc., and the other for manual labor, with workrooms devoted to a large variety of trades and occupations. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Aug. 10, 1916
2016-08-09.headline_main: 1916: A School for War Victims

2016-08-09.lead_paragraph: LONDON — A British prime minister confirmed for the first time today [Aug. 9] what has long been alleged — that the evidence points to collusion between Britain, France and Israel during the Suez crisis ten years ago. In response to a question in Parliament, Harold Wilson said that far from the British entering the fight only to separate the Egyptians and Israelis, ‘‘the whole thing was a put-up job.’’ Mr. Wilson’s comments this afternoon followed the recent disclosure by Christian Pineau that a secret agreement was reached prior to Suez among the three countries. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 10, 1966

2016-08-09.abstract: The latest iteration is more nostalgic indulgence than rebellious statement. But it still has a defiant power.
2016-08-09.snippet: The latest iteration is more nostalgic indulgence than rebellious statement. But it still has a defiant power.
2016-08-09.lead_paragraph: “Insensitive to red,” a heartbreaking phrase, is technically a description of early black-and-white film, which converted the colors of blood and red lipstick to black. Elsa Lanchester’s lips were painted redder than her auburn hair for 1935’s “The Bride of Frankenstein”; the makeup artist on the film based her look on a 3,300-year-old bust of Nefertiti, who announced her power by blackening her eyes, reddening her lips and dyeing her nails with dark henna. But when Lanchester appeared on screen as the Bride — “She’s alive!” — her overdrawn mouth looked dark as hell: Et voilà, the modern gothic lip was born. Robert Smith of the Cure, whose lipstick emphasized not the Cupid’s bow but the corners of his mouth, giving him the moue of a dissatisfied cannibal, was said to inspire the almost-black “goth lip” of the 1990s; he only, in fact, wore the ’60s designer Mary Quant’s Crimson Scorcher. But what are facts when it comes to what we see? Color depends on perception, and our perception, so dependent on lighting, changes over the years the way light does over the course of a day. Sometimes we’re desensitized to red, and so to get a look as fresh as red lipstick used to give, we turn to shades that look more like ink.
2016-08-09.headline_main: The Return of the Gothic Lip

2016-08-09.lead_paragraph: CASA NETA MEZCALERIA AND TEQUILERIA Nothing says Mexico like bright wall murals pulsing with energy. Those by Tracy Ahumada, a graphic designer, add spice to this Flatiron-district setting for classic Mexican fare on small plates and agave-based spirits. The list of dishes, including tacos, quesadillas, ceviche and salads, is as brief as the selection of tequilas and mezcals stretches long, to more than 100. The chef, Joel Zaragoza, a native of Mexico City, seeks ingredients from local farms. The space, which once housed the Champagne bar Flûte, has a downstairs lounge, the Sugar Skull Room, a year-round nod to the Day of the Dead with a mural by Derrick Turner, the bartender: 40 East 20th Street, 212-529-7870, casanetanyc.com.

2016-08-09.abstract: The arctic mining city of Norilsk is one of the most polluted in the world — but many residents are still proud to call it home.
2016-08-09.snippet: The arctic mining city of Norilsk is one of the most polluted in the world — but many residents are still proud to call it home.
2016-08-09.lead_paragraph: Not many people have heard of Norilsk, an industrial cityin an isolated part of Arctic Russia. No roads or trains lead there; internet is severely limited; and it is it closed to foreigners. Getting there, I would find out, is very difficult. Yet despite its obscurity, Norilsk has one of the largest mining and metallurgical complexes in the world and produces most of the earth’s palladium, an essential mineral in electronics and automobiles. Most of us probably have a bit of Norilsk in our pockets, bags or homes.
2016-08-09.headline_main: My Deadly, Beautiful City

(From the first book: “Corrine was getting so tired of parties: dinner parties, birthday parties, pre-publication parties, housewarming parties; holiday and theme and opening-night parties, closing-night parties.…”) He followed them through the crisis of 9/11. And now he is back to watch them reach 50 and hit amplified fiscal, marital and existential crises.

2016-08-09.abstract: An ambitious new restaurant in Honolulu’s still pleasantly seedy Chinatown is serving small plates that re-envision the islands’ staples.
2016-08-09.snippet: An ambitious new restaurant in Honolulu’s still pleasantly seedy Chinatown is serving small plates that re-envision the islands’ staples.
2016-08-09.lead_paragraph: For decades, Hawaii’s high-end restaurants have been dominated by outsiders. At first glance, Senia, serving ambitious small plates in Honolulu’s still pleasantly seedy Chinatown, might seem like more of the same: It’s co-owned by the chef Anthony Rush, a Brit who arrived from London mere months ago. But Rush’s partner is Chris Kajioka, a Honolulu native with intimate knowledge of local ingredients. Together the chefs, who met working at Per Se, have created a menu that centers on the islands’ most elemental staples, re-envisioned as haute cuisine. Red snapper, which in Hawaii is often served simply with ginger and soy sauce, is baked in a sourdough crust and cracked tableside; backyard fruits like mountain apples and guavas are prepared with traditional French techniques; and lowly starches like taro, sweet potatoes and breadfruit are given center stage. “This is not meant to be intellectual food,” Kajioka says. “We really want to represent Hawaii — just in a different way.”
2016-08-09.headline_main: Redefining Hawaiian Fine Dining

2016-08-09.abstract: Emperor Akihito’s oblique appeal poses a problem for Japanese politicians.
2016-08-09.snippet: Emperor Akihito’s oblique appeal poses a problem for Japanese politicians.
2016-08-09.lead_paragraph: It says a lot about Japan’s constitutional monarchy that Emperor Akihito, 82 and in failing health, would be stepping out of bounds if he were to say he wanted to retire. Under the Constitution laid down by the victorious United States after World War II, the emperor’s role is strictly restricted to being the “symbol of the state and of the unity of the people,” and since the law says the monarch rules until he dies, to utter words like “abdicate” or even “retire” would be seen as a forbidden sortie into politics. Yet in a televised address on Monday remarkable for its circumlocution, the emperor was clear about what he couldn’t say. And if it wasn’t clear, we’ll say it for him: He’d really, really like to retire.
2016-08-09.headline_main: Let the Emperor Retire

2016-08-09.lead_paragraph: “An Art That Nature Makes: The Work of Rosamond Purcell” is the portrait of an artist who is not interested in portraits. If Rodriguez had his way, he would go out like Kobe Bryant, shooting and shooting and shooting until the clock ran out on his career.

2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — The term “Scrabbly” has been applied to certain crosswords that make prolific use of the high-value Scrabble letters, like J, K, V, Q, W, X and Z, but today’s puzzle by David C. Duncan Dekker is Scrabbly on steroids. It’s not only a pangram, which, for those of you just joining us, is a crossword where every letter of the English alphabet is used at least once. This is a QUINTUPLE pangram, which means that each letter is used, at minimum, five times. That’s quite a feat.

2016-08-10.abstract: The Museum of London is commemorating the 350th anniversary of the Great Fire with an exhibition that traces the fire and how it determined the city’s future.
2016-08-10.snippet: The Museum of London is commemorating the 350th anniversary of the Great Fire with an exhibition that traces the fire and how it determined the city’s future.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In the early hours of Sept. 2, 1666, a small fire broke out in a London bakery owned by Thomas Farriner. Stoked by easterly winds, the blaze engulfed timber-framed houses and warehouses stocked with brandy, wine and oil. By the time it was extinguished four days later, about 13,000 buildings had been destroyed — including the 500-year-old St. Paul’s Cathedral — and nearly 80 percent of the ancient city of London had been wiped out. As many as 100,000 people were left homeless.
2016-08-10.headline_main: The Fire That Shaped London

2016-08-10.abstract: In an aspirational life on the edges of power, Mrs. Clinton shouldered her family’s financial burdens but has been accused of going against her principles.
2016-08-10.snippet: In an aspirational life on the edges of power, Mrs. Clinton shouldered her family’s financial burdens but has been accused of going against her principles.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: LITTLE ROCK, Ark. — Losing the governor’s race here in 1980 so shattered a young Bill Clinton that he could not face his supporters, so he sent his wife around to thank campaign workers instead. He later gathered with close friends for dinner but quietly sulked, playing the country song “I Don’t Know Whether to Kill Myself or Go Bowling” on the jukebox.
2016-08-10.headline_main: Stress Over Family Finances Propelled Hillary Clinton Into Corporate World

2016-08-10.abstract: A Justice Department report showing that officers systematically stopped, searched and arrested blacks is a step toward a settlement to overhaul police training and practices.
2016-08-10.snippet: A Justice Department report showing that officers systematically stopped, searched and arrested blacks is a step toward a settlement to overhaul police training and practices.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — As a black man and a lifelong resident of this city, Ray Kelly has been stopped by the police more times than he can count. And as a community organizer who tried to document police bias after the death of Freddie Gray, Mr. Kelly, 45, had always expected that a federal investigation would uncover a pattern of racial discrimination.
2016-08-10.headline_main: Findings of Police Bias in Baltimore Validate What Many Have Long Felt

2016-08-10.abstract: What does it actually feel like to be in Rio de Janeiro? The answer is that it is odd, sometimes maddening, possibly dangerous and frequently a hoot.
2016-08-10.snippet: What does it actually feel like to be in Rio de Janeiro? The answer is that it is odd, sometimes maddening, possibly dangerous and frequently a hoot.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — At the women’s 3-meter synchronized diving final on Sunday, there seemed to be two events occurring at once. There was the one displayed on a large video screen at the outdoor arena, and there was the live one in front of your eyes. The events were identical except for one notable detail: On the screen, the sun appeared to be shining, and in real life, it was not.
2016-08-10.headline_main: Many Soldiers, Few Signs, Long Lines: The Rio Games Beyond the TV Screen

2016-08-10.snippet: Professional musicians and talented amateurs at the migrant camp in France teamed up for a benefit world music project.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: PARIS — “I am happy, like a myna/Life in a caravan, thinking about my friends/Let’s go to the garden,” go the upbeat lyrics from “Khandahar,” a poem first written in English and then translated to Farsi by two Afghan sisters, ages 9 and 12, who were living in a trailer in the sprawling migrant and refugee camp in Calais, France, that is known as the Jungle.

2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: Many of us watching the Olympics are feeling inspired now to exercise harder and more often. But exercise scientists have long been intrigued — and worried — by the question of whether, over months and years, someone can exercise too much. It has not been clear if there is a safe upper limit to exercise beyond which you can irreparably injure your body, and in particular your heart.
2016-08-10.headline_main: Do Olympians Get Too Much Exercise?

2016-08-10.abstract: So much of what we associate with the word “modernism” has roots in a small, early-20th-century German art school that existed for only 14 years.
2016-08-10.snippet: So much of what we associate with the word “modernism” has roots in a small, early-20th-century German art school that existed for only 14 years.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: The Bauhaus Building rises over Dessau, a small, postindustrial city in eastern Germany, like a futuristic message from the past. With its suspended glass facades, exposed steel gridding and asymmetrical layout, the three-wing complex feels both modern and familiar. But when it was finished in 1926, it was downright alien.
2016-08-10.headline_main: On the Bauhaus Trail in Germany

2016-08-10.abstract: The once mighty newspapers of Fleet Street still aim for sound and fury, but what do they signify?
2016-08-10.snippet: The once mighty newspapers of Fleet Street still aim for sound and fury, but what do they signify?
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: LONDON — Last week, two reporters for a small Scottish newspaper left Fleet Street for good. Their departure means that the London home of Britain’s unseemly press since 1702 now no longer houses any newspaper offices at all. A neighborhood once dominated by printers and reporters, all working and (more often) drinking within half a mile of one another, has become the haunt of lawyers, insurers and other soulless creatures.
2016-08-10.headline_main: Britain’s Paper Tigers

2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Bowing to days of passionate street protests, a city government in eastern China said Wednesday that it had halted any plans to build a nuclear fuel plant there. The reversal was the latest indication of how public distrust could hold back China’s ambitious plans for expanding its nuclear power industry.
2016-08-10.headline_main: Chinese City Backs Down on Proposed Nuclear Fuel Plant After Protests

2016-08-10.abstract: Many Poles are questioning whether the European identity and freedom that meant so much after the fall of Communism hold the same value today.
2016-08-10.snippet: Many Poles are questioning whether the European identity and freedom that meant so much after the fall of Communism hold the same value today.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: WROCLAW, Poland — Mayor Rafal Dutkiewicz of Wroclaw has presided over city hall in the magnificent old center since 2002. As he watches Poland’s politics take a rightward and nationalistic turn — a phenomenon playing out to varying degrees across much of Europe — Mr. Dutkiewicz, an early supporter of Solidarity, cites history ancient and modern to argue that Europe is good for Poland.
2016-08-10.headline_main: 'We Don’t Need to Be Alone’: A Political Shift Has Poland Assessing Its Values

2016-08-10.snippet: We’re all professionals or trying to become professionals and we don’t know what we’re going to eat tomorrow.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: CIUDAD GUAYANA, Venezuela — I was hanging out with some neighbors in the hallway recently. We live in one of the short turquoise buildings of a mixed commercial-residential complex in this northeastern city, supposedly a model of urban development.
2016-08-10.headline_main: Middle Class and Hungry in Venezuela

2016-08-10.abstract: Mary Knowlton, 73, was participating in a role-play exercise hosted by the Punta Gorda Police Department when she was shot with live rounds.
2016-08-10.snippet: Mary Knowlton, 73, was participating in a role-play exercise hosted by the Punta Gorda Police Department when she was shot with live rounds.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: Mary Knowlton knew that the key to enjoying retirement in Punta Gorda, Fla., was to stay active, her friends say, and they had no idea how she kept so busy. When she signed up for a citizens academy held by the local police department, she and her husband were among 35 people hoping to learn more about law enforcement tactics.
2016-08-10.headline_main: Woman Is Accidentally Killed by Police Officer Playing ‘Bad Guy’ at Training Academy in Florida

2016-08-10.abstract: The Netflix documentary series, debuting Aug. 19, focuses on professional bull riding.
2016-08-10.snippet: The Netflix documentary series, debuting Aug. 19, focuses on professional bull riding.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: If bull riding were an Olympic event, the Brazilians might sweep the medals and win bonus points for bravery. Adriano Moraes, Ednei Caminhas, Guilherme Marchi, Renato Nunes and Silvano Alves: Each has been a world champion of what are considered the most dangerous eight seconds in sports. “Fearless,” a Netflix documentary series debuting Friday, Aug. 19, depicts wiry cowboys straddling tornadoes of muscle, horn and hoof more than 10 times their weight and hanging on as if their existence depended on it.
2016-08-10.headline_main: The Most Dangerous Eight Seconds in Sports, on ‘Fearless’

2016-08-10.abstract: Some 160 performers from around the world will be appearing at the annual gathering.
2016-08-10.snippet: Some 160 performers from around the world will be appearing at the annual gathering.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: The stage for the Battery Dance Festival, in its 35th year, faces spectacular views of New York’s harbor. That’s appropriate as the free performances there this summer include 35 companies, 38 choreographers and an estimated 160 performers who embrace the world.
2016-08-10.headline_main: An Olympics of Spirit at the Battery Dance Festival

2016-08-10.abstract: Migos and Lil Yachty are among the acts scheduled to perform at this event in Manhattan. Local rappers are also on the bill.
2016-08-10.snippet: Migos and Lil Yachty are among the acts scheduled to perform at this event in Manhattan. Local rappers are also on the bill.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: Two distinct tangents of Atlanta’s flamboyant, overflowing rap scene will take over the Manhattan waterfront on Saturday, Aug. 20: Migos, the three-headed hydra of euphoric, rapid-fire catchphrases, and Lil Yachty, the self-proclaimed “king of the teens,” with his singsong flow and constantly bouncing red-beaded braids. Both will bring the joyful youth contingent to the seventh annual Fool’s Gold Day Off party, which also features the promising local rappers Leaf, Meyhem Lauren and Dave East.
2016-08-10.headline_main: Atlanta Rappers Join Fool’s Gold Day Off Party

2016-08-10.abstract: More than 140 works by 35 artists, each one priced under $750, will be featured at this Brooklyn gallery.
2016-08-10.snippet: More than 140 works by 35 artists, each one priced under $750, will be featured at this Brooklyn gallery.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: Part of the mission of Anthony Philip Fine Art in Bushwick, Brooklyn, is to connect emerging artists with aspiring collectors. So the gallery’s latest show, opening Friday, Aug. 12, aims specifically at young and novice collectors. “Life Sized: A Small Works Invitational” features more than 140 artworks that are under 12 inches by 12 inches and priced under $750. “Our hope is that there will be something here for anyone looking to jump-start their collection,” Mr. Philip said. The 35 artists in the show work in a range of media, including painting, sculpture, photography, abstract art and traditional drawing. Among them are Kristen Balouch, Jonathan Quinn and Tariku Shiferaw from New York; Amy Lottes, Jeff Kapfer and Barb Flunker from Missouri; and artists from Kansas, South Carolina and Washington. (Through Sept. 3; anthonyphilipfineart.com.)
2016-08-10.headline_main: Collector Helper at Anthony Philip Fine Art

2016-08-10.abstract: The museum has a partnership with the new-music collective Bang on a Can, which is bringing the American Contemporary Music Ensemble to the sculpture garden.
2016-08-10.snippet: The museum has a partnership with the new-music collective Bang on a Can, which is bringing the American Contemporary Music Ensemble to the sculpture garden.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: There are few lovelier places to hear music in New York City than in the sculpture garden of the Noguchi Museum in Queens. The museum has a partnership with the new-music collective Bang on a Can, which on Sunday, Aug. 14, brings the American Contemporary Music Ensemble to the garden. On the program are string quartets by Philip Glass and Meredith Monk as well as the premiere of a cello solo by Caleb Burhans, played by Clarice Jensen, the ensemble’s artistic director. (3 p.m., 718-204-7088, noguchi.org.)
2016-08-10.headline_main: In the Garden, With Strings, at the Noguchi Museum

2016-08-10.abstract: The star of “Not Safe With Nikki Glaser” on Comedy Central will headline six shows, beginning on Thursday, Aug. 18.
2016-08-10.snippet: The star of “Not Safe With Nikki Glaser” on Comedy Central will headline six shows, beginning on Thursday, Aug. 18.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: The dynamic stand-up comic Nikki Glaser has produced a popular podcast, co-hosted a short-lived talk show on MTV and starred in several memorable sketches on “Inside Amy Schumer.” But the best example of her wry and raunchy sense of humor may be in “Not Safe With Nikki Glaser,” a cheerfully sex-obsessed series on Comedy Central. The show, which includes high-concept videos that take her places like a porn shoot (where she feeds lines to actors) and a foot fetish party, helps Ms. Glaser come off as forever game, if also a little startled by her own chutzpah. This tension between her bluntness and her anxiety has long been the engine fueling her charismatic, assured stand-up, the bedrock of her prolific young career. She headlines six shows at Carolines on Broadway, starting on Thursday, Aug. 18. (212-757-4100, carolines.com.)
2016-08-10.headline_main: The Comic Nikki Glaser at Carolines on Broadway

2016-08-10.abstract: The IFC Center and Socrates Sculpture Park are featuring the films of Federico Fellini and Werner Herzog.
2016-08-10.snippet: The IFC Center and Socrates Sculpture Park are featuring the films of Federico Fellini and Werner Herzog.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: In its Weekend Classics series, the IFC Center has been hosting a stealth Federico Fellini festival this summer, with screenings at the un-Fellinilike hour of 11 a.m. “Amarcord,” the director’s most nostalgic memoir, evoking the small coastal Italian town where he grew up, is on Sunday, Aug. 14; on Friday and Saturday is “Roma,” a valentine to the city to which he is eternally wed. (ifccenter.com.)
2016-08-10.headline_main: A Fellini Summer. A Conquistador’s, Too.

2016-08-10.abstract: Many of summer’s tentpole movies (“Suicide Squad,” “Star Trek Beyond”) offer workplace allegories, with rivalries and power plays.
2016-08-10.snippet: Many of summer’s tentpole movies (“Suicide Squad,” “Star Trek Beyond”) offer workplace allegories, with rivalries and power plays.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: In summertime, you can count on two things. There will be a lot of sequels and reboots in theaters, and there will be a lot of critics complaining about that. It’s just part of the job. And after 2015, when a handful of reboots and sequels landed on Top 10 lists, we’re back to a familiar routine. The movies range from pretty good to outright terrible, they open to mixed reviews and big box-office numbers, and before we know it, the Oscar race is heating up. It’s the end of civilization, and it’s also business as usual.

2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: CAPE KENNEDY, Florida — The United States today [Aug. 10] rocketed the Lunar Orbiter spacecraft toward an intended orbit about the moon, hoping to obtain clear pictures of the hidden farther side and nine potential astronaut landing sites. An Atlas-Agena rocket thundered away from Cape Kennedy to start flying on its planned 235,446-mile journey.

2016-08-10.abstract: An island-ravaging cyclone hasn’t been able to keep the lifter Apolonia Vaivai from competing in the Olympics.
2016-08-10.snippet: An island-ravaging cyclone hasn’t been able to keep the lifter Apolonia Vaivai from competing in the Olympics.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: On a Wednesday morning in July, the weight lifter Apolonia Vaivai leaned against the cinder-block wall of a crowded bus stall in the South Pacific port city of Suva, Fiji. Vaivai, who is 25 and just over five feet tall and thick with muscle, was wearing turquoise workout shorts and a matching T-shirt and cap bearing a Monster energy-drink logo that covered the tips of her ears. She had come to town to arrange a visa for the Rio Olympic Games, even though she was not yet sure if she was going. Fiji had earned one spot in the women’s weight lifting program, but Weightlifting Fiji, the country’s governing body for the sport, had yet to reveal who would fill it. Rather than wait in Suva for the announcement, Vaivai decided to make the jarring, four-hour bus-and-ferry trip home to Ovalau, a nearby island. “In three days,” she told me later on the ferry, “I’ll find out if I’m going to the Olympics.”
2016-08-10.headline_main: Weight Lifting Her Way From Fiji to Rio

2016-08-10.abstract: Ryan McGinness breaks down some of the iconography in his striking series of “Signals” paintings.
2016-08-10.snippet: Ryan McGinness breaks down some of the iconography in his striking series of “Signals” paintings.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: The paintings in the artist Ryan McGinness’s new series, “Signals,” immediately invite interpretation — and then, just as quickly, elude it. Each of the pieces is a circular wood panel, 18 inches in diameter and ringed by a thick red outline. Inside are a handful of stark, graphic black-and-white symbols (a bomb with a seedling sprouting from it; a string tied around a middle finger) that strongly evoke meaning, without giving it all away. “They use the visual language of universal sign systems and therefore give the illusion that they are communicating blunt pedestrian information,” McGinness notes, “but they undermine that same visual language by evading elucidation.”
2016-08-10.headline_main: One Artist’s Very Symbolic New Work, Explained — Sort of

2016-08-10.abstract: This peaceful haven for expat surfers has lately seen an uptick in hip new options like vegan cafes, music bars and housewares shops.
2016-08-10.snippet: This peaceful haven for expat surfers has lately seen an uptick in hip new options like vegan cafes, music bars and housewares shops.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: Tucked between beaches and rolling green rice paddies north of the flashy tourist hub of Seminyak, the bohemian enclave of Canggu (pronounced “CHANG-oo”) has always lived below the radar. A peaceful haven for expat surfers, Canggu’s mellow vibe and surf breaks have been luring backpack-toting travelers since the ’80s. Recently however, hip new options including vegan cafes, music bars and housewares shops have sprouted among the local staples like Old Man’s bar, Betelnut Café and Deus Ex Machina, a cafe and motorcycle shop. Don’t wait too long before heading this way. With a smattering of hotels in the pipeline, this laid-back area may soon see more bustle.
2016-08-10.headline_main: Five Places to Go in Bali

2016-08-10.snippet: A Boucheron capelet took over 900 hours to hand-fabricate and is embroidered with more than 800 round diamonds.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: Part cloak, part exquisite body armor, this Boucheron capelet woven from 18-karat gold drapes around the shoulders like a jewel version of haute couture. The Art Deco-inspired pattern, which took over 900 hours to hand-fabricate, is embroidered with more than 800 round diamonds and clasped by a dangling pear-shaped citrine of 82 carats. Engineered to move with the body, this hybrid masterpiece conjures the bold glamour of the 1930s screen sirens and the technical wizardry of today.
2016-08-10.headline_main: An Elegant Piece That’s Part Jewelry — and Part Cape

The car headlights swept the glass sliders of our modern house, illuminating a reconfiguration of the living room furniture so curious, I half-suspected slippage on the Ventura Fault.

2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: In late July, The American Conservative ran an interview with J. D. Vance that drew so much traffic it briefly crippled the central nervous system of the magazine’s website. The interviewer’s last line implored readers to have a look at Mr. Vance’s publishing debut, “Hillbilly Elegy: A Memoir of a Family and Culture in Crisis.” Ever since, his book has hovered at high altitude on Amazon, seldom dipping below No. 10.

Their “Take My Wife” isn’t the most polished show in the genre, but it has a D.I.Y. charm and a perspective that have long been underrepresented on the small screen.

So far, she has lived up to the hype, placing more than 1.5 points ahead of her closest competitor, American Aly Raisman, in the qualifying round, and leading the U.S. team to gold on Tuesday in the team competition.

2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — The problem of the suddenly green water in the Olympic diving pool worsened Wednesday as whatever was ailing the pool migrated (albeit in a lighter shade of green) to the nearby pool used for water polo and synchronized swimming. But Olympic officials said that after extensive tests, they had finally pinpointed the reason: a chemical imbalance caused by too many people using the water.

2016-08-10.abstract: From the founder of Gastronomica and the media company behind “Mind of a Chef” comes Cured, a publication all about curing, pickling and fermenting.
2016-08-10.snippet: From the founder of Gastronomica and the media company behind “Mind of a Chef” comes Cured, a publication all about curing, pickling and fermenting.
2016-08-10.lead_paragraph: Last fall, the founder and editor of the James Beard Award-winning journal Gastronomica, Darra Goldstein, was busy “constructing a life without obligation.” She had left her own publication after closing the Fall 2012 issue; finished producing three books (“High Society Dinners: Dining in Tsarist Russia,” “The Oxford Companion to Sugar and Sweets” and “Fire and Ice: Classic Nordic Cooking”); and was phasing into her 2017 retirement from Williams College, where she has been teaching since 1983 and is the Willcox and Harriet Adsit professor of Russian. But an invitation from Joe Caterini, the managing partner at Zero Point Zero Production, the media company responsible for shows like “Anthony Bourdain: Parts Unknown” and the wildly popular “Mind of a Chef,” got in the way.

2016-08-11.abstract: Reforming the Baltimore Police Department has begun, but it will be a long and difficult process, requiring better training and federal oversight.
2016-08-11.snippet: Reforming the Baltimore Police Department has begun, but it will be a long and difficult process, requiring better training and federal oversight.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: The scathing federal report this week on the reality of racist abuse by the police in Baltimore was hardly news to the African-American neighborhoods most victimized by ironhanded law enforcement. Community leaders have been complaining for years about police policies that swept up innocent black citizens beyond all bounds of constitutional justice — stopping, frisking and arresting residents without justification, then releasing them without criminal charges or so much as an apology.
2016-08-11.headline_main: A Policing Culture Built on Racism in Baltimore

2016-08-11.snippet: The broken-windows style of policing that New York evangelized is increasingly seen as a source of community tensions, not a successful crime-fighting strategy.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: The Justice Department has criticized a string of police departments nationwide for unfairly targeting blacks, but in its report on the Baltimore police, issued Wednesday, it used its most scathing language to date to denounce the zero-tolerance policing approach that has spread from New York to many departments big and small.
2016-08-11.headline_main: In Baltimore Report, Justice Dept. Revives Doubts About Zero-Tolerance Policing

2016-08-11.snippet: Timothy Polin is a man of letters.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: THURSDAY PUZZLE — One reason people resist learning to solve crosswords, I believe, is because they have a fundamental misunderstanding of what crossword puzzles are. People resistant to solving look at a crossword puzzle and assume that the main action and maximum reward come merely from reading a clue and dutifully entering in the synonymous equivalent of the answer. Or they believe that the information the puzzle contains is beyond their ken, or some combination of the two.
2016-08-11.headline_main: Better to Give Than to Receive

2016-08-11.abstract: Elliot’s retreat into a fantasy world is a sign of a show that believes in itself, and has a confidence that is breathtaking to watch.
2016-08-11.snippet: Elliot’s retreat into a fantasy world is a sign of a show that believes in itself, and has a confidence that is breathtaking to watch.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: To truly appreciate how good Rami Malek is on “Mr. Robot,” you just might need to see him on the least “Mr. Robot”–like television show imaginable. Improbably, disturbingly, delightfully, that’s precisely how this week’s episode of “Mr. Robot” begins. After vintage USA Network bumpers touting the “Word Up Wednesday” programming block on “America’s Favorite TV Network” roll, we suddenly see Mr. Malek’s Elliot Alderson dropped into an 1980s family sitcom, with all the VHS picture quality and canned laughter that entails. Excised from the show’s painstaking, painterly cinematography — explicitly developed to capture Mr. Malek’s every facial nuance, right down to using curved lenses to accentuate his beautifully bulbous eyes — Elliot finally looks as out of place in the world as he feels.
2016-08-11.headline_main: ‘Mr. Robot’ Season 2, Episode 6: I Love Elliot

2016-08-11.abstract: Why do we still single out these creatures for destruction?
2016-08-11.snippet: Why do we still single out these creatures for destruction?
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: One morning in the late 1930s, the biologist Adolph Murie stood near a game trail in Yellowstone National Park and watched a passing coyote joyously toss a sprig of sagebrush in the air with its mouth, adroitly catch it, and repeat the act every few yards. At the time, Mr. Murie was conducting a federal study intended to prove, definitively, that the coyote was “the archpredator of our time.” But Mr. Murie, whose work ultimately exonerated the animals, was more impressed by that sprig-tossing — proof, he believed, of the joy a wild coyote took in being alive in the world.
2016-08-11.headline_main: Stop Killing Coyotes

2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: The first word uttered in “Sausage Party” is a popular synonym for excrement, which is a bit counterintuitive. In a movie about food, you’d expect that to come at the end. But while the next 88 minutes supply plenty of scatology — including a blessedly discreet toilet-paper joke — this potty-mouthed movie has higher matters in mind. You will come for the kind of humor promised in the title and the well-earned R rating, but stay for the nuanced meditations on theology and faith.

2016-08-11.abstract: While their economic platforms are markedly different, both candidates promise to create jobs but have said little about helping people while they are not working.

2016-08-11.abstract: Planetary destruction and other uses of mathematics in a far-future society; women in geekdom; and shapeshifters who prey on humans in the Mughal Empire, and today.
2016-08-11.snippet: Planetary destruction and other uses of mathematics in a far-future society; women in geekdom; and shapeshifters who prey on humans in the Mughal Empire, and today.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: It’s easy to get lost in the kaleidoscopic world-­building of NINEFOX GAMBIT (Solaris, paper, $9.99), the first ­novel by the well-regarded story writer Yoon Ha Lee. Lee submerges readers without explanation into the hexarchate — a star-spanning far-future society whose culture relies on advanced mathematics to produce “exotic effects” that are nigh magical. A sort of unearthly physics, these can make select individuals functionally immortal, even as exotic generators churn forth monstrous ­vector-scrambling storms that disintegrate enemy soldiers down to component atoms. At the core of the technology is the high calendar. More than just a measurement of time, this calendar shapes the mathematical base of the exotic effects. Yet by changing the calendar and thus the underlying math of reality, dissidents can cripple hexarchate technology — a heresy to those in control, who punish dissenters by destroying them whole planets at a time. The disproportionate reprisals inevitably beget more heresy, so the hexarchate exists in a perpetual state of war in which it is too beneficially invested ever to end.
2016-08-11.headline_main: The Latest in Science Fiction and Fantasy

2016-08-11.abstract: Historically, the appearance of cancer was (wrongly) attributed to the repressed anger of patients. In fact, contagious rage is not the cause but may be an effect.
2016-08-11.snippet: Historically, the appearance of cancer was (wrongly) attributed to the repressed anger of patients. In fact, contagious rage is not the cause but may be an effect.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: While dealing with lung cancer, my friend Nancy K. Miller seethed in her blog at pharmaceutical advertisements and hospital commercials that bombard us daily with pictures of joyous cancer patients supported by doting intimates. These jubilant characters have nothing to do with the frustrated people we know who periodically erupt in righteous indignation. I often must remind myself that anger needs to be understood as the flip side of the roiling fear that cancer instills in patients and also in caregivers.
2016-08-11.headline_main: The Anger of Cancer

2016-08-11.snippet: For the first time, researchers have figured out how to cultivate comb jellies in large quantities, a development that could lead to new discoveries.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: Comb jellies, or ctenophores, are wildly different from humans and, in fact, most other animals. They’re not even in the same group as common jellyfish. These gelatinous, hermaphroditic sea creatures come in various shapes — eggs, ribbons and bells — and can be as short as a grain of rice or as long as a broomstick. They use their “combs,” rows of tiny paddlelike structures, to swim.
2016-08-11.headline_main: Growing Comb Jellies in the Lab Like Sea-Monkeys

2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: PARIS, France — U.S. racial violence and the increasing immigration of foreign workers are beginning to inspire serious public concern in France. Hirtherto an all but taboo subject, the French attitude on racism is now being questioned in an important segment of the press. In the past two weeks, these observations have been made here: The respected, middle-class ‘‘Figaro,’’ under the ‘‘Harlem-sur-Seine’’ headline: ‘‘The most optimistic estimates of some high functionaries indicate that the Negro population of France will go up to 650,000 in 1980. Others, more ‘pessimistic,’ advance the figure of a million.’’ — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 12, 1966

2016-08-11.abstract: The fashion-photographer-turned-director Sean Ellis shares beautiful photos from the set of “Anthropoid.”
2016-08-11.snippet: The fashion-photographer-turned-director Sean Ellis shares beautiful photos from the set of “Anthropoid.”
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: “I just don’t think period dramas work very well when they’re shot on the waxy, clean, sort of digital format,” says Sean Ellis, the director, co-writer and cinematographer of the new World War II thriller “Anthropoid.” “There’s too much detail, and it doesn’t feel real to me. Film is a little bit more forgiving and has a little bit more soul in it; there’s something beautiful in the grain.” Few would know better. As a fashion photographer, Ellis has shot for some of the world’s biggest brands and publications — among them Vogue, French Vogue and i-D — projects he prefers to capture the old-fashioned way. Ellis got his start with photography early on, after realizing the images in his head weren’t making it to paper when he tried to draw. “Something was lost in translation from my brain to my pen,” says Ellis. Instead, he photographed G.I. Joes, capturing imagined combat with the family camera.
2016-08-11.headline_main: Behind the Scenes of the Season’s Most Stylish Thriller

2016-08-11.abstract: The twin brothers have a runaway hit in their Netflix series, which wears the influences of an era on its small-screen sleeve.
2016-08-11.snippet: The twin brothers have a runaway hit in their Netflix series, which wears the influences of an era on its small-screen sleeve.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: On paper, the plot of the series “Stranger Things,” a runaway summer hit from Netflix, reads like a Dungeons & Dragons campaign. And an early scene takes place in a suburban Indiana basement in 1983, with four adolescent boys debating the best way to defeat a mythical Demogorgon. When a version of that creature enters their world, the show unfolds into an interdimensional tribute to classic ’80s fantasy, sci-fi and horror, with nods to “Alien”; “E.T.: The Extraterrestrial”; “A Nightmare on Elm Street”; and Stephen King’s 1986 novel, “It.” Since its release in July, the series has attracted a wave of internet attention, with detailed examinations of its cinematic and cultural references — including a deep dive into the characters’ corduroy wardrobes.
2016-08-11.headline_main: Matt and Ross Duffer Discuss ‘Stranger Things,’ a Nightmare on ’80s Street

2016-08-11.abstract: Aurélie Dupont, the new director of dance at the Paris Opera, shares her secrets.
2016-08-11.snippet: Aurélie Dupont, the new director of dance at the Paris Opera, shares her secrets.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, Aurélie Dupont took over for Benjamin Millepied as director of dance at the Paris Opera — making her, in an industry that is still surprisingly male-dominated, one of the few women in the world directing a ballet company. Her credentials are impeccable: She’s a former étoile ballerina and was one of the most sought-after dancers in the world until ending her performance career in May 2015. As a dancer, Dupont called the Paris Opera home for 32 years — and with a 350-year-old legacy that makes it the oldest of its kind, the company is where ballet was born. But Dupont argues that in no way does this prevent it from remaining relevant to contemporary audiences. “Classical dance is an extraordinarily precise and physical art form,” she says. “It’s like a Chanel handbag — it endures through the generations. The old steps of ‘Swan Lake’ can be danced in ways which make them new. Just like your grandmother’s Chanel can be worn with sneakers in order to keep it modern.”
2016-08-11.headline_main: Wellness, Beauty and Style — According to a French Ballet Star

2016-08-11.abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Italy’s army takes the Doberdo plateau in August 1916.
2016-08-11.snippet: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Italy’s army takes the Doberdo plateau in August 1916.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: BERLIN, Germany — Following the capture of Gorizia and the rout of the Austrian army driven beyond the town, the Italians have scored another magnificent triumph by hurling back the enemy from the area extending from south of Gorizia almost to the sea. The towns of Rubbia and San Martino and the whole of the Doberdo plateau are in the possession of the Italians, and their cavalry has at places driven back the enemy’s troops in disorder as far as the Vippacco torrent. The Austrians driven beyond Gorizia are in more or less complete rout over an 18-kilometre front. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 12, 1891
2016-08-11.headline_main: 1916: Italians Take Doberdo Plateau

2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: My single mother, 65, is selling the house where I grew up. She told me the buyers asked if they could buy a picture  my late grandmother stitched for my nursery. It’s always meant a lot to me. Still, she gave it to them. I didn’t say anything because she  added, “It felt like Grandma was telling me to.” Plus, it was already done. Would it be rude to go to the house after the buyer has moved in and offer to buy it back? I know you’ll say I shouldn’t, but it would help to hear it from you.

2016-08-11.headline_main: Meet the Greenland Shark. It Could Be the Longest-Living Vertebrate.

2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: Four white busts rest on pedestals with plaques that say, “When I was young I wanted to be a policeman.” They look as though they are wearing black masks; up close, it’s clear that the masks are really photographs of police brutality applied to the faces. A fifth bust, in the center, spins. A small image of Rodney King appears on its brow, like a target. This plaque is different: “A loss of faith brings vertigo.”
2016-08-11.headline_main: Revisiting Michael Richards’s Art in the Age of Black Lives Matter

2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: Washington — As a college student in Virginia, Corey Jacobs started selling drugs with the help of a group of friends to make some extra money. A Bronx native, Mr. Jacobs was no kingpin, and no aspect of their drug conspiracy involved violence. Now age 46, Mr. Jacobs has served 16 years of a sentence of life without parole in the federal system.
2016-08-11.headline_main: Eric Holder: We Can Have Shorter Sentences and Less Crime

2016-08-11.headline_main: STX, Hollywood Start-Up Behind ‘Bad Moms,’ Gains Chinese Investors

2016-08-11.abstract: Artists in the New York International Fringe Festival used their creativity to secure rehearsal locations that wouldn’t break the bank.
2016-08-11.snippet: Artists in the New York International Fringe Festival used their creativity to secure rehearsal locations that wouldn’t break the bank.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: FOR audiences, the New York International Fringe Festival experience has improved over the years to include some truly civilized amenities — air-conditioned theaters, for one. But artists with shows in the festival, which begins on Friday, still face a perennial challenge: finding a suitable rehearsal space on what is usually a pretty tight budget. Here are edited excerpts from conversations about how four productions made it work this year at no additional cost.
2016-08-11.headline_main: How 4 Fringe Festival Shows Found Free Rehearsal Space

2016-08-11.abstract: The year-old brand Alumnae, from a Sigerson Morrison founder, offers a host of loafers and slippers in luxe materials.
2016-08-11.snippet: The year-old brand Alumnae, from a Sigerson Morrison founder, offers a host of loafers and slippers in luxe materials.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: The designer Kari Sigerson is more than just a flat enthusiast; rather, she calls herself a “student of the flat.” In 1991, she launched the brand Sigerson Morrison along with co-designer Miranda Morrison. Now she’s teamed up with Eliza Axelson-Chidsey, another colleague from the label, to found Alumnae, a shoe brand that launched last year. “It’s a celebration of both my and Kari’s wealth of experience designing shoes,” Axelson-Chidsey says of Alumnae. “It’s not an of-the-moment, disruptive type of start-up. Its emphasis is really crafting well-made, wearable footwear” — something not the norm in an industry that has for years been dominated by men fashioning high heels for what the designers call “fantasy women.” “The difference with Alumnae, and of course, Sigerson Morrison, is that we as women can come in and correct our own prototypes on our own feet. We know what we desire and can make it ourselves,” Sigerson says.
2016-08-11.headline_main: A Shoe Line That Finds Creativity in Flats

2016-08-11.abstract: Kadiza Sultana, one of three British schoolgirls who left home last year to join the Islamic State, is believed to have been killed in Syria.
2016-08-11.snippet: Kadiza Sultana, one of three British schoolgirls who left home last year to join the Islamic State, is believed to have been killed in Syria.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: One of the three London schoolgirls who made headlines last year when they fled their homes to join the Islamic State extremist group in Syria is believed to have been killed by a Russian airstrike, a British television channel reported on Thursday.
2016-08-11.headline_main: British Girl Who Joined ISIS Is Reported Killed in Airstrike

2016-08-11.abstract: Adam H. Weinert’s “Monument” program at Jacob’s Pillow blends pioneering solos from 1930 to 1970 with a challenging group piece of his own.
2016-08-11.snippet: Adam H. Weinert’s “Monument” program at Jacob’s Pillow blends pioneering solos from 1930 to 1970 with a challenging group piece of his own.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: BECKET, Mass. — The history of dance is best experienced in live performance, yet there’s awfully little of it for audiences to see. Modern dance became a nationwide phenomenon in America between 1915 and 1940, entering the education system, producing dances that inspired many. Most present-day American dancegoers, however, have never seen any of it.
2016-08-11.headline_main: Review: A Rare Dive Into the History of Dance Pioneers

2016-08-11.abstract: We will always have the breaststroke, and long may it reign. But here’s a modest case for the discreet charm of a sport with some bounce.
2016-08-11.snippet: We will always have the breaststroke, and long may it reign. But here’s a modest case for the discreet charm of a sport with some bounce.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: Wherever you are, whatever time it is, it is the Olympics. The events in Rio de Janeiro feel constant and inescapable, a furious relay of competition and striving. It is as if the Olympic torch itself were a flaming baton, passed from archer to swimmer to gymnast to triathlete.
2016-08-11.headline_main: Amid the Fury of the Olympics, the Zen of the Trampoline

2016-08-11.abstract: Collins, the Mets’ manager, delivered a four-minute speech challenging his players’ attitudes after the Mets’ record fell to its lowest since April 20.
2016-08-11.snippet: Collins, the Mets’ manager, delivered a four-minute speech challenging his players’ attitudes after the Mets’ record fell to its lowest since April 20.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: The words had clearly been stewing inside Terry Collins for some time, and not simply during the agonizing three hours of Thursday’s 9-0 loss during which the Mets fell to .500 because of an embarrassing three-game sweep at Citi Field by the lowly Arizona Diamondbacks.
2016-08-11.headline_main: Boiling Over, Terry Collins Lights Fire Under Mets After Team Falls to .500

2016-08-11.headline_main: Thailand Bombings Kill 4 and Wound Dozens, Most at Tourist Sites

2016-08-11.headline_main: What to See in New York Art Galleries This Week

2016-08-11.abstract: Biles joins Mary Lou Retton, Carly Patterson, Nastia Liukin and Gabby Douglas as American all-around gold medalists.
2016-08-11.snippet: Biles joins Mary Lou Retton, Carly Patterson, Nastia Liukin and Gabby Douglas as American all-around gold medalists.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Simone Biles, already considered the world’s greatest female gymnast before even competing in the Olympics, emphatically confirmed her standing on Thursday by winning the women’s individual all-around gold medal at the Rio Games.
2016-08-11.headline_main: It’s Official: Simone Biles Is the World’s Best Gymnast

2016-08-11.abstract: During a concert at Madison Square Garden, the singer Tyler Joseph said that performing at the arena was a fantasy come true.
2016-08-11.snippet: During a concert at Madison Square Garden, the singer Tyler Joseph said that performing at the arena was a fantasy come true.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: Twenty One Pilots is not known for subtlety, so the signals to the crowd Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden, where the duo played the first of two sold-out shows to close the United States leg of its Emotional Roadshow tour, were bold.
2016-08-11.headline_main: Review: For Twenty One Pilots, Time to Shine on a Stage of Dreams

2016-08-11.abstract: Paintings from the most private royal chambers are on view at the Clark Art Institute.
2016-08-11.snippet: Paintings from the most private royal chambers are on view at the Clark Art Institute.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass. — “Splendor, Myth and Vision: Nudes From the Prado,” a weighty but also steamy exhibition at the Clark Art Institute here, makes a tricky demand: Can you look at art with both a historian’s detachment and a lover’s intimacy? Stripped-down white cube galleries have conditioned us to look with dispassion upon paintings like the large-scale ones here, which depict goddesses and nymphs, heroines and victims, with full breasts and bountiful thighs. (There are a few boys, too, in the homestretch.) We look at the handling of figures, at angles and light, at the development of painterly style, or else at the political and social context that gave rise to them.
2016-08-11.headline_main: Now Showing: Porn Fit for Spanish Kings

2016-08-11.abstract: This historic art colony at the tip of Cape Cod has cause for celebrating its centennial.
2016-08-11.snippet: This historic art colony at the tip of Cape Cod has cause for celebrating its centennial.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: PROVINCETOWN, Mass. — Squint and it could still be 1916. On a walk through Provincetown’s East End one recent Friday evening, the brick sidewalks, unruly rosebushes, gray shingle-lined cottages, and streets barely big enough for a horse-driven carriage recalled an earlier era. Even more pleasantly jarring were the throngs of artgoers flowing in and out of dozens of galleries nestled along the water’s edge here at the tip of Cape Cod. The mood still evokes the setting of 100 years ago, when Provincetown established its reputation as the nation’s largest art colony.
2016-08-11.headline_main: Provincetown: Still the Place to Paint and to Party

2016-08-11.abstract: Two exhibitions at the American Folk Art Museum show the inner workings of a mind concerned with its own survival and that of the whole world.
2016-08-11.snippet: Two exhibitions at the American Folk Art Museum show the inner workings of a mind concerned with its own survival and that of the whole world.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: Ronald Lockett, whose emotionally raw and politically trenchant paintings and assemblages are featured in “Fever Within: The Art of Ronald Lockett” at the American Folk Art Museum, did not have a lot going for him.
2016-08-11.headline_main: In Sheet Metal and Scraps, Ronald Lockett Evokes Struggle and Survival

2016-08-11.abstract: Arthur Dove and Helen Torr lived in Centerport, on Long Island, and the Heckscher Museum of Art is restoring the home where they experiment with their art.
2016-08-11.snippet: Arthur Dove and Helen Torr lived in Centerport, on Long Island, and the Heckscher Museum of Art is restoring the home where they experiment with their art.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: CENTERPORT, N.Y. — Nestled among parking lots, a pond, a brick hotel and a divorce lawyer’s office, a clapboarded one-room cottage in this Long Island hamlet on the North Shore played a role in American art history. The artist couple Arthur Dove and Helen Torr, who were among the earliest American experimenters with abstraction, lived there in the 1930s and ’40s, and based their abstract and semiabstract canvases on nearby harbors, lighthouses and foghorns.
2016-08-11.headline_main: New Life for a Cottage That Doubled as an Artists’ Laboratory

2016-08-11.abstract: Meryl Streep stars in an enjoyable look back at a would-be singer and a Carnegie Hall concert remembered for how awful it was.
2016-08-11.snippet: Meryl Streep stars in an enjoyable look back at a would-be singer and a Carnegie Hall concert remembered for how awful it was.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: Meryl Streep will get most of the attention accorded the crowd-pleasing “Florence Foster Jenkins” thanks to a performance that may single-handedly set off a boom in the earplug industry. But the actor you should keep your eye on is Simon Helberg. It is his reactions to her vocal travesties that really make the movie sparkle.
2016-08-11.headline_main: Review: ‘Florence Foster Jenkins,’ Singing So Wretched It’s Legendary

2016-08-11.abstract: Little about Hong Un-jong has been shared outside North Korea despite her Olympic gold in the vault in 2008 and her hero status at home.
2016-08-11.snippet: Little about Hong Un-jong has been shared outside North Korea despite her Olympic gold in the vault in 2008 and her hero status at home.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — In a selfie that has spread quickly online, the North Korean gymnast Hong Un-jong smiles brightly as a South Korean competitor at the Rio Olympics, Lee Eun-ju, 17, holds up her smartphone and snaps a picture of them hugging.
2016-08-11.headline_main: North Korean Gymnast’s Selfie Goes Viral, but Her Bio Is Sparse

2016-08-11.abstract: A lens that gave users slanted eyes was criticized as an Asian caricature. It wasn’t the first time the app has faced a backlash.
2016-08-11.snippet: A lens that gave users slanted eyes was criticized as an Asian caricature. It wasn’t the first time the app has faced a backlash.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: With its lens tool, Snapchat allows some 150 million daily users to alter reality and play with identity in ways that border on the absurd.
2016-08-11.headline_main: Snapchat Finds Itself on the Wrong Side of a Racial Lens. Again.

2016-08-11.abstract: This movie from Alice Winocour follows a veteran returning to France from Central Asia who takes what seems to be a fairly straightforward security job.
2016-08-11.snippet: This movie from Alice Winocour follows a veteran returning to France from Central Asia who takes what seems to be a fairly straightforward security job.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: Alice Winocour’s “Disorder” is a tightly wound spring of a movie, a tour de force of sound design and sly editing that implies much more than it shows. The premise is simple. A twitchy, traumatized veteran returns to France from a Central Asian war zone and picks up some security work during what he hopes will be a short interval between tours of duty. A fairly straightforward assignment “babysitting” the wife and son of a well-connected rich guy turns out to be more complicated and dangerous than anyone expected.
2016-08-11.headline_main: Review: In ‘Disorder,’ Danger Lurks in Many Corners, or None at All

2016-08-11.abstract: This oral history by James Andrew Miller enlists many voices in describing the rise of Creative Artists Agency and its former chairman Michael Ovitz.
2016-08-11.snippet: This oral history by James Andrew Miller enlists many voices in describing the rise of Creative Artists Agency and its former chairman Michael Ovitz.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: James Andrew Miller’s “Powerhouse” is an oral history of Creative Artists Agency, the bigfooting talent agency that was once the Tyrannosaurus rex of the entertainment industry. Right from the get-go, there are two enormous things wrong with it. The first is “oral history”: Sometimes this means a seamless narrative pieced together from the words of many speakers, but not here. In “Powerhouse,” it means a 700-page string of skips, jumps, tangents and otherwise dizzying non sequiturs.
2016-08-11.headline_main: Review: ‘Powerhouse’ Recalls a Heyday of Matched Jaguars and Packaged Films

2016-08-11.abstract: The Netflix series takes the strivers, spitfires and gang bangers of that film and repurposes them in a tale of the origins of hip-hop.
2016-08-11.snippet: The Netflix series takes the strivers, spitfires and gang bangers of that film and repurposes them in a tale of the origins of hip-hop.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: There are, perhaps, less likely pairings than Baz Luhrmann and the story of hip-hop’s beginnings  in the South Bronx in the 1970s. Britain and the European Union. Jackie Kennedy and Aristotle Onassis. Red wine and fish.
2016-08-11.headline_main: Baz Luhrmann’s ‘The Get Down’ Is ‘West Side Story’ With Rappers and Disco Queens

2016-08-11.abstract: The United States Central Command altered its analysis to portray a more optimistic picture of the war than events in Iraq and Syria warranted, a report concluded.
2016-08-11.snippet: The United States Central Command altered its analysis to portray a more optimistic picture of the war than events in Iraq and Syria warranted, a report concluded.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Officials from the United States Central Command altered intelligence reports to portray a more optimistic picture of the war against the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria than events on the ground warranted, a congressional panel said in a report issued Thursday.
2016-08-11.headline_main: Military Officials Distorted ISIS Intelligence, Congressional Panel Says

2016-08-11.abstract: Told in flashback, this film follows the collision and decade-long duel between a guarded lawyer and an impulsively charismatic restaurateur.
2016-08-11.snippet: Told in flashback, this film follows the collision and decade-long duel between a guarded lawyer and an impulsively charismatic restaurateur.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: Your first thought on seeing Tony (Emmanuelle Bercot), the mentally shredded heroine of “My King” (“Mon Roi”), recuperating from a skiing calamity might well be “If I have to break a limb, please let me do it in France.” Cocooned in a gleaming rehab center by the ocean, Tony is recovering from more than a torn knee. And while France may or may not offer lust-worthy physical therapy, it has occasionally produced notable cinematic depictions of injurious passion, of which this unblinking portrait of emotional abuse is an especially juicy example.
2016-08-11.headline_main: Review: In ‘My King,’ Blindly Falling Fast and Furious

2016-08-11.abstract: Written and directed by Jeff Baena, this comedy features Thomas Middleditch and Adam Pally, among others, enjoying a weekend of middle-class debauchery.
2016-08-11.snippet: Written and directed by Jeff Baena, this comedy features Thomas Middleditch and Adam Pally, among others, enjoying a weekend of middle-class debauchery.
2016-08-11.lead_paragraph: The opening notes of “Joshy,” a new picture written and directed by Jeff Baena, go from glum to harrowing in mere minutes. The title character, played by Thomas Middleditch (“Silicon Valley”), returns home from work on his birthday and has a desultory conversation with his live-in fiancée, Rachel, who went the entire day without getting out of bed. Joshy goes to work out in his building’s gym, and on his return discovers that his relationship with Rachel is definitively over.
2016-08-11.headline_main: Review: In ‘Joshy,’ Wedding’s Off, Bachelor Party’s a Go

2016-08-11.abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
2016-08-11.snippet: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
