2016-08-14.snippet: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Communist China announces that it is making “a new leap forward” in August 1966.
2016-08-14.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Communist China announced yesterday [Aug. 13] it was making ‘‘a new leap forward.’’ The Central Committee of the Chinese Communist party, in its first plenary session in nearly four years, strongly reaffirmed the nation’s ‘‘hard line’’ at home and abroad, said a Radio Peking broadcast monitored here. The committee, which ended its 12-day meeting in Peking Friday, announced its decisions on the domestic service of Radio Peking yesterday.
2016-08-14.headline_main: 1966: Chinese Communists to Make ‘New Leap Forward’

2016-08-14.abstract: Rio de Janeiro residents have criticized Brazilian officials for spending money on the Olympics rather than tending to the country’s problems.
2016-08-14.snippet: Rio de Janeiro residents have criticized Brazilian officials for spending money on the Olympics rather than tending to the country’s problems.
2016-08-14.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — A thousand metaphysical miles from the well-heeled Olympic zone, a couple of activists and I entered the Favela do Mandela, a ramshackle collection of brick-and-tar-paper buildings. We walked a narrow road ringed by wary-eyed young men, which led to a narrower one, which led to a five-foot-wide alleyway. We found the home of 64-year-old Marie Auxiliadora.
2016-08-14.headline_main: Officials Spent Big on Olympics, but Rio Natives Are Paying the Price

2016-08-14.abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: The economical situation of Bulgaria rapidly becomes critical in August 1916.
2016-08-14.snippet: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: The economical situation of Bulgaria rapidly becomes critical in August 1916.
2016-08-14.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The economical situation of Bulgaria is rapidly becoming as critical as that of Germany and Austria-Hungary. According to information from various reliable sources bread is everywhere extremely scarce. In Sofia, white bread is unobtainable and black bread is given out sparingly. In some parts of the country only two pounds a week is allowed to each householder. Sugar, butter, eggs and salt are among the necessaries sold at exorbitant prices, and even then only in very small quantities.
2016-08-14.headline_main: 1916: Food Grows Scarce in Bulgaria

It has some regional flavor — with much of the action centered on a corner cafe in Lyon, France, run by the family of the disappeared girl — but it’s mostly menu typique.

2016-08-14.abstract: Jianglin Li examines recent Tibetan protests against Chinese rule against the backdrop of the military campaigns and repression of the 1950s.
2016-08-14.snippet: Jianglin Li examines recent Tibetan protests against Chinese rule against the backdrop of the military campaigns and repression of the 1950s.
2016-08-14.lead_paragraph: Generations of Chinese have been taught that the Tibetan people are grateful to China for having liberated them from “feudalism and serfdom,” and yet Tibetan protests, including self-immolations, continue to erupt against Chinese rule. In “Tibet in Agony: Lhasa 1959,’’ to be published in October by Harvard University Press, the Chinese-born writer Jianglin Li explores the roots of Tibetan unrest in China’s occupation of Tibet in the 1950s, culminating in March 1959 with the People’s Liberation Army’s shelling of Lhasa and the Dalai Lama’s flight to India. In an interview, she shared her findings.
2016-08-14.headline_main: A Writer’s Quest to Unearth the Roots of Tibet’s Unrest

2016-08-14.abstract: A single in the eighth inning, on Matz’s 105th pitch, allowed Collins to pull Matz, whose elbow has been a source of concern.

2016-08-14.headline_main: Steven Matz’s No-Hit Bid Is Broken Up, to Terry Collins’s Relief

2016-08-14.abstract: Set in 2016 B.C., this Ashutosh Gowariker film is a standard epic adventure with music and romance.
2016-08-14.snippet: Set in 2016 B.C., this Ashutosh Gowariker film is a standard epic adventure with music and romance.
2016-08-14.lead_paragraph: Before the action starts, the Bollywood movie “Mohenjo Daro” assures us that no animals were harmed during its making. More unusual, a note tells us that the film doesn’t support or dispute any specific interpretation of ancient Indian civilization. This disclaimer probably isn’t necessary. From its first scenes, the movie, set in 2016 B.C., makes its intentions known: This is a hero’s tale, not history.
2016-08-14.headline_main: Review: ‘Mohenjo Daro’ Depicts a Go-To Hero’s Exertions in Antiquity

2016-08-14.abstract: Severino, who was charged with seven runs and was pulled in the fourth inning, was optioned to Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre after the Yankees lost in a rout.
2016-08-14.snippet: Severino, who was charged with seven runs and was pulled in the fourth inning, was optioned to Class AAA Scranton/Wilkes-Barre after the Yankees lost in a rout.
2016-08-14.lead_paragraph: Mariano Rivera’s plaque is the newest addition to Yankee Stadium’s Monument Park, where the inscription credits his “signature cut fastball” with leading to 652 saves, the major league record.
2016-08-14.headline_main: Yankees’ Luis Severino Returns to Minors After Savaging by Rays

2016-08-14.abstract: This Mostly Mozart premiere at Lincoln Center featured 1,000 singers and succeeded as a feel-good communal event.
2016-08-14.snippet: This Mostly Mozart premiere at Lincoln Center featured 1,000 singers and succeeded as a feel-good communal event.
2016-08-14.lead_paragraph: Though the actual temperature hovered in the mid-90s late Saturday afternoon in New York, the “feels like” indicator on weather sites put the figure at 105 degrees. Even so, the premiere of David Lang’s “the public domain,” his new work for 1,000 voices, went on as planned in the main plaza of Lincoln Center. Arriving for the performance, I was certain that the volunteer choristers who had rehearsed the piece so thoroughly would show up. But would anyone else?
2016-08-14.headline_main: Review: ‘The public domain’ Beats the Heat and Humidity

2016-08-14.abstract: This book by Ben Greenman, a collection of essays, encompasses a range of music genres as the author riffs on a number of topics.
2016-08-14.snippet: This book by Ben Greenman, a collection of essays, encompasses a range of music genres as the author riffs on a number of topics.
2016-08-14.lead_paragraph: They strode upon the land like gods. They had formidable egos and captivating prose styles and strong, often unpredictable opinions. They had influence, too, at least for a while, and maybe even a modicum of power. I speak here of the rock critics — writers like Lester Bangs, Robert Christgau, Ellen Willis and Dave Marsh — who rose to prominence in the 1960s and ’70s, and I mention them as a way of providing a contrast to Ben Greenman’s new book, “Emotional Rescue.”
2016-08-14.headline_main: Review: ‘Emotional Rescue’ Ruminates on Life and Music

2016-08-14.abstract: Advertisers are experimenting with minimovies using top stars and directors as more people skip or block ads when streaming shows or browsing the web.
2016-08-14.snippet: Advertisers are experimenting with minimovies using top stars and directors as more people skip or block ads when streaming shows or browsing the web.
2016-08-14.lead_paragraph: “Lifeline” is a half-hour thriller directed by an Academy Award winner about a man’s search for his missing girlfriend. In the film, set in Shanghai with a plot driven by corporate malfeasance, punches are thrown, shots are fired and people are killed. At one point, the actress Olivia Munn stands over a dead woman, blood on her hands.
2016-08-14.headline_main: It’s Thrilling. It’s Chilling. It’s a 30-Minute Commercial.

2016-08-14.abstract: Usain Bolt strode to glory again, and synchronized swimmers flipped through a preliminary round on a day when athletes at a variety of venues had reason to celebrate.
2016-08-14.snippet: Usain Bolt strode to glory again, and synchronized swimmers flipped through a preliminary round on a day when athletes at a variety of venues had reason to celebrate.
2016-08-14.lead_paragraph: Usain Bolt strode to glory again, and synchronized swimmers flipped through a preliminary round on a day when athletes at a variety of venues had reason to celebrate.
2016-08-14.headline_main: Arms, and Legs, Aloft

2016-08-14.abstract: Mr. Rylance’s portrayal in “Twelfth Night” is, hands down, our chief theater critic’s favorite Shakespeare performance. The actor tells us how he developed the role.
2016-08-14.snippet: Mr. Rylance’s portrayal in “Twelfth Night” is, hands down, our chief theater critic’s favorite Shakespeare performance. The actor tells us how he developed the role.
2016-08-14.lead_paragraph: LONDON — When you live with a woman for more than a decade — as Mark Rylance did, on and off, with a certain countess famed for her beauty and her severity — you come to know her well. “I liked her enormously,” Mr. Rylance said recently, in a rush of respectful warmth. “I guess I liked the struggle between the form she felt she had to maintain and the great force within her.” He also came to realize that she was both funnier and sadder than he had at first suspected.
2016-08-14.headline_main: How Mark Rylance Became Olivia Onstage

2016-08-14.abstract: Some fans are less than thrilled by an institutional tribute to the summer of 1976, when the Ramones and the Sex Pistols helped punk rock take flight.
2016-08-14.snippet: Some fans are less than thrilled by an institutional tribute to the summer of 1976, when the Ramones and the Sex Pistols helped punk rock take flight.
2016-08-14.lead_paragraph: BLACKPOOL, England — “Ramones forever!” C. J. Ramone yelled to a tightly packed crowd at the Rebellion Festival here earlier this month, and a little roar rippled through a sea of bright-pink mohawks, bleached-blond spikes — and more than a few balding heads.
2016-08-14.headline_main: Hey Ho, It’s Old: England Embraces Punk Rock 40 Years Later

2016-08-14.abstract: We asked punk rockers what it means to them, 40 years after it emerged as a genre of loud, fast rebellious music, with style and attitude to match.
2016-08-14.snippet: We asked punk rockers what it means to them, 40 years after it emerged as a genre of loud, fast rebellious music, with style and attitude to match.
2016-08-14.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The origins of punk rock are somewhat hazy, but by 1976 it had emerged as a genre of loud, fast, rebellious music, with style and attitude to match. Forty years later, we asked punk rockers and those who know their music what it means to them.
2016-08-14.headline_main: Forty Years On, What Does Punk Rock Mean?

2016-08-14.abstract: Sam Trabucco gets our solving week going.
2016-08-14.snippet: Sam Trabucco gets our solving week going.
2016-08-14.lead_paragraph: MONDAY PUZZLE — Today’s crossword by Sam Trabucco solved almost like a Tuesday to me because the theme was a bit less straightforward than I was expecting for a Monday. Committing a puzzle to a specific day of the week is a fine line to walk.
2016-08-14.headline_main: Someone’s Gonna Pay

2016-08-14.abstract: A federal lawsuit filed in New York claims that private investors who have taken ownership of federally insured mortgages are putting black homeowners at higher risk of foreclosure.
2016-08-14.snippet: A federal lawsuit filed in New York claims that private investors who have taken ownership of federally insured mortgages are putting black homeowners at higher risk of foreclosure.
2016-08-14.lead_paragraph: For years, the federal government avoided insuring mortgages in black neighborhoods, a practice known as redlining that exacerbated racial divides throughout America’s cities.
2016-08-14.headline_main: Sale of Federal Mortgages to Investors Puts Greater Burden on Blacks, Suit Says

2016-08-14.abstract: The world’s biggest semiconductor company is scrambling for a place in sensors, wireless networking and autonomous vehicles, as computing spreads to nearly every machine.
2016-08-14.snippet: The world’s biggest semiconductor company is scrambling for a place in sensors, wireless networking and autonomous vehicles, as computing spreads to nearly every machine.
2016-08-14.lead_paragraph: Andy Grove, the renowned chief executive of Intel, who died in March, coined a phrase beloved in Silicon Valley: “Only the paranoid survive.”
2016-08-14.headline_main: Intel’s New Mission: Find Fresh Uses for Its Famous Paranoia

2016-08-14.abstract: For the second year in a row, Mr. Obama released his summer vacation music and reading lists, and they’re emblematic of his personality and popularity.
2016-08-14.snippet: For the second year in a row, Mr. Obama released his summer vacation music and reading lists, and they’re emblematic of his personality and popularity.
2016-08-14.lead_paragraph: EDGARTOWN, Mass. — Some full-time music critics spend their lives curating playlists they hope become popular. President Obama outdid them all last week in between briefings by senior aides and rounds of golf with friends on vacation here.
2016-08-14.headline_main: President Obama’s Emotional Spotify Playlist Is a Hit

2016-08-15.abstract: A passenger was haunted by the memory of a rabbity little man furiously scribbling words and numbers on page after page.
2016-08-15.snippet: A passenger was haunted by the memory of a rabbity little man furiously scribbling words and numbers on page after page.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Dear Diary:
2016-08-15.headline_main: Mysterious Scribbling on the Subway

2016-08-15.abstract: Johnson Controls seeks to acquire Tyco in a $16 billion deal. Reports are also expected this week on consumer prices and housing starts.
2016-08-15.snippet: Johnson Controls seeks to acquire Tyco in a $16 billion deal. Reports are also expected this week on consumer prices and housing starts.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Here’s what to expect in the week ahead.
2016-08-15.headline_main: A Vote on the Tyco Merger and Earnings Reports From Target and Walmart

2016-08-15.abstract: With donated ingredients and some of the world’s top chefs, Refettorio Gastromotiva has become a feel-good counterpoint to the commercialization of the Games.
2016-08-15.snippet: With donated ingredients and some of the world’s top chefs, Refettorio Gastromotiva has become a feel-good counterpoint to the commercialization of the Games.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Consider what it takes to keep all those Olympian machines nourished and hydrated for one meal at the Rio Games: 250 tons of raw ingredients to fill the bellies of 18,000 athletes, coaches and officials in the Olympic Village.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Celebrity Chefs Turn Wasted Olympics Food Into Meals for Homeless

2016-08-15.abstract: An examination of the activities of Paul Manafort shows how he benefited from powerful interests that are now under scrutiny.
2016-08-15.snippet: An examination of the activities of Paul Manafort shows how he benefited from powerful interests that are now under scrutiny.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — On a leafy side street off Independence Square in Kiev is an office used for years by Donald J. Trump’s campaign chairman, Paul Manafort, when he consulted for Ukraine’s ruling political party. His furniture and personal items were still there as recently as May.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Secret Ledger in Ukraine Lists Cash for Donald Trump’s Campaign Chief

2016-08-15.abstract: Mr. Finkel won an Emmy for his portrayal of a cantankerous lawyer on the 1990s show “Picket Fences.”
2016-08-15.snippet: Mr. Finkel won an Emmy for his portrayal of a cantankerous lawyer on the 1990s show “Picket Fences.”
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Fyvush Finkel, whose homespun moniker and putty face — comic statements all their own — helped him become a mainstay of what remained of Yiddish entertainment, and who later crossed over into television as the cantankerous lawyer on the 1990s series “Picket Fences,” died on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Fyvush Finkel, Pillar of Yiddish Theater Who Crossed Into TV, Dies at 93

2016-08-15.abstract: Bolt became the first runner to win the 100 meters at three straight Olympics. The American Justin Gatlin was second.
2016-08-15.snippet: Bolt became the first runner to win the 100 meters at three straight Olympics. The American Justin Gatlin was second.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — As the king of sprinting and the biggest global star at the Rio Games, Usain Bolt of Jamaica held aloft his index finger, signaling that he was No. 1, during introductions Sunday night as a smitten crowd chanted his name.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Usain Bolt Is Still the World’s Fastest Man

2016-08-15.abstract: At least five people were killed and thousands rescued because of weekend flooding. More areas are expected to flood as swollen waters roll south.
2016-08-15.snippet: At least five people were killed and thousands rescued because of weekend flooding. More areas are expected to flood as swollen waters roll south.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: After days of ruinously heavy storms in southern Louisiana, rain-swollen rivers and creeks continued wreaking damage across the state, inundating neighborhoods and submerging roads and highways.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Thousands Displaced in Storm-Drenched Louisiana

2016-08-15.abstract: The Mets have won two straight thanks to strong pitching, while injuries continue to afflict wild-card contenders, including the Mets themselves.
2016-08-15.snippet: The Mets have won two straight thanks to strong pitching, while injuries continue to afflict wild-card contenders, including the Mets themselves.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Terry Collins was off by one day. When Collins, the Mets’ manager, delivered a blistering tirade about his sluggish team last Thursday, he did it with the struggling Logan Verrett scheduled to pitch the next game. Verrett promptly gave up five runs in the first inning on Friday.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Pitching, and Injuries to Rivals, Keep the Mets in the Wild-Card Race

2016-08-15.abstract: Transparency about our political candidates is critical to American democracy.
2016-08-15.snippet: Transparency about our political candidates is critical to American democracy.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Among Donald J. Trump’s traits is his penchant for internalizing and personalizing things — insults, rejections and even policy disagreements. Trading slights seems essential to his personality, or at least something he feels is necessary for his presidential campaign.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Mark Sanford: I Support You, Donald Trump. Now Release Your Tax Returns.

2016-08-15.abstract: He defeated Juan Martín del Potro, 7-5, 4-6, 6-2, 7-5, to win the men’s singles title at the Rio Games.
2016-08-15.snippet: He defeated Juan Martín del Potro, 7-5, 4-6, 6-2, 7-5, to win the men’s singles title at the Rio Games.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Andy Murray of Britain put a brighter shine on his finest tennis season by winning his second straight Olympic gold medal in singles on Sunday night, but surely Juan Martín del Potro of Argentina deserves something more precious than silver.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Andy Murray’s Big Year Now Has Olympic Gold

2016-08-15.abstract: The United States has a policy allowing the first use of nuclear weapons. Abolishing it will save money and make the world safer.
2016-08-15.snippet: The United States has a policy allowing the first use of nuclear weapons. Abolishing it will save money and make the world safer.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Throughout the nuclear age, presidents have allowed their senior commanders to plan for the first use of nuclear weapons. Contingency plans were drawn to initiate first strikes to repel an invasion of Europe by the Soviet Union, defeat China and North Korea, take out chemical and biological weapons and conduct other missions.
2016-08-15.headline_main: End the First-Use Policy for Nuclear Weapons

2016-08-15.abstract: Hours after a police officer shot and killed a fleeing armed man, angry crowds confronted the police and then went on a violent rampage.
2016-08-15.snippet: Hours after a police officer shot and killed a fleeing armed man, angry crowds confronted the police and then went on a violent rampage.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — Like many of his neighbors, Dominic A. Lebourgeois was in disbelief on Sunday at the level of violence that descended on his Sherman Park neighborhood the previous evening.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Milwaukee Shaken by Eruption of Violence After Shooting by Police

2016-08-15.abstract: Imam Alauddin Akonjee, who was fatally shot on Saturday, is remembered for brokering unity between Muslim groups and urging peace amid discrimination.
2016-08-15.snippet: Imam Alauddin Akonjee, who was fatally shot on Saturday, is remembered for brokering unity between Muslim groups and urging peace amid discrimination.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Imam Alauddin Akonjee delivered his weekly sermon on Friday in his quietly powerful manner, drawing, as usual, nearly 200 people to a two-story house-turned-mosque in Ozone Park, Queens. He spoke in Bengali, his native language.
2016-08-15.headline_main: ‘Our Community Lost Its Heart’: Queens Imam Is Recalled as Peacemaker

2016-08-15.abstract: Michael W. Ferro Jr., who made himself chairman of Tribune Publishing and changed its name to Tronc, clashed with other investors over Gannett’s takeover bids.
2016-08-15.snippet: Michael W. Ferro Jr., who made himself chairman of Tribune Publishing and changed its name to Tronc, clashed with other investors over Gannett’s takeover bids.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: In early summer, after the company formerly called Tribune Publishing had rejected two takeover offers from Gannett, two of its biggest investors found themselves in an escalating dispute. The investment firm Oaktree Capital Management was publicly questioning the motives of Michael W. Ferro Jr., an investor and the new chairman of the publishing company, in his decision to rebuff Gannett.
2016-08-15.headline_main: A Tech Mogul’s Fight to Keep Control of a Newspaper Empire

2016-08-15.abstract: Two digital acquaintances, one in Israel and another in Afghanistan, collaborated to save a baby in Pakistan with life-threatening congenital heart problems.
2016-08-15.snippet: Two digital acquaintances, one in Israel and another in Afghanistan, collaborated to save a baby in Pakistan with life-threatening congenital heart problems.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: HOLON, Israel — They had never met, but they were Facebook friends connected across thousands of miles. Together the two digital acquaintances — a young English teacher in Jalalabad, Afghanistan, and a retired State Department official living in Haifa, Israel — collaborated to save a baby in Pakistan with life-threatening congenital heart problems.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Unlikely Facebook Friendship Saves Afghan Baby With Heart Defect

2016-08-15.abstract: As the deadline for bids on the embattled company nears, three to five companies have emerged as the most likely suitors.
2016-08-15.snippet: As the deadline for bids on the embattled company nears, three to five companies have emerged as the most likely suitors.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: The end of Gawker Media as an independent company is near.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Who Might Buy Gawker Media? Here Are Some Possibilities

2016-08-15.abstract: After the social network streams its first N.F.L. game on Sept. 15, it will assess whether live streaming can be a linchpin of its future.
2016-08-15.snippet: After the social network streams its first N.F.L. game on Sept. 15, it will assess whether live streaming can be a linchpin of its future.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last March, Twitter and Facebook, along with other tech companies, faced off over which of them would get the rights to live-stream National Football League games on Thursday nights.
2016-08-15.headline_main: With N.F.L. Deal, Twitter Live-Streams Its Ambitions

2016-08-15.abstract: There were warning signs before a sexual harassment case at Fox News, just as there were before the phone hacking that shook the Murdoch media empire.
2016-08-15.snippet: There were warning signs before a sexual harassment case at Fox News, just as there were before the phone hacking that shook the Murdoch media empire.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Settlements for alleged inappropriate behavior that continued unabated.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Fox News Turmoil Recalls News Corp. Phone Hacking Scandal

2016-08-15.abstract: Bitter conflicts have erupted between insurers and consumers at hearings around the country as companies request double-digit premium increases.
2016-08-15.snippet: Bitter conflicts have erupted between insurers and consumers at hearings around the country as companies request double-digit premium increases.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After the Affordable Care Act took effect in 2010, it created a review mechanism intended to prevent exorbitant increases in health insurance rates by shaming companies that sought them.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Health Insurers Use Process Intended to Curb Rate Increases to Justify Them

2016-08-15.abstract: Emperor Akihito indicated in a rare public address that he wants to abdicate the throne, which would make him the first Japanese monarch in 200 years to step down.
2016-08-15.snippet: Emperor Akihito indicated in a rare public address that he wants to abdicate the throne, which would make him the first Japanese monarch in 200 years to step down.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Emperor Akihito indicated in a rare public address that he wants to abdicate the throne, which would make him the first Japanese monarch in 200 years to step down.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Heng on Japan’s Emperor and the Constitution

2016-08-15.abstract: The fatal shooting of an imam and his assistant has been deeply unsettling for residents of Ozone Park, Queens.
2016-08-15.snippet: The fatal shooting of an imam and his assistant has been deeply unsettling for residents of Ozone Park, Queens.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: On Sunday afternoon, Nurul Khan changed clothes after working around his house on a sweltering day and set off on a short walk, just around the corner, to his mosque to pray. It is a stroll he takes five times a day, he said, starting each morning before the sun has risen.
2016-08-15.headline_main: 2 Killings Near Mosque Plunge a Queens Neighborhood Into Fear

2016-08-15.abstract: Building a credit history holds less appeal for young Americans who had trouble paying off student loans and saw their families’ struggles during the financial crisis.
2016-08-15.snippet: Building a credit history holds less appeal for young Americans who had trouble paying off student loans and saw their families’ struggles during the financial crisis.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Kids these days: They just aren’t pulling out the plastic like they did in the past.
2016-08-15.headline_main: How Millennials Became Spooked by Credit Cards

2016-08-15.abstract: Quotation of the day for Monday, August 15, 2016.
2016-08-15.snippet: Quotation of the day for Monday, August 15, 2016.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: “It is a situation of national shame. I was seeing this kind of thing when I was a medical student a half-century ago. It hurts me. The disease had disappeared.”
2016-08-15.headline_main: Quotation of the Day

2016-08-15.abstract: Naz is again caught in a lie, but the suspect list in Andrea’s death grows when she is painted as someone who attracts violence, if not instigates it.
2016-08-15.snippet: Naz is again caught in a lie, but the suspect list in Andrea’s death grows when she is painted as someone who attracts violence, if not instigates it.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: In the recap for last week’s episode, I wrote about how Naz’s acclimation to prison life mirrored that of the lead character in the French drama “A Prophet,” which tracks a young convict’s rise from helpless naïf to jailhouse kingpin. Yet, I also noted a crucial difference between the two: “A Prophet” is about how a system predicated on reform turns a petty criminal into violent monster, but we don’t know if the same is true of Naz. There are suggestions, based on his behavior and based on the real possibility that he murdered Andrea Cornish, that prison hasn’t changed Naz so much as revealed the coarsened soul that his good-guy demeanor has hidden so effectively.
2016-08-15.headline_main: ‘The Night Of’ Season 1, Episode 6: The Cat or the Yarn?

2016-08-15.abstract: In Sunday’s episode, tension between Tommy, Holly and Ghost escalates to a violent impasse.
2016-08-15.snippet: In Sunday’s episode, tension between Tommy, Holly and Ghost escalates to a violent impasse.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: This interview contains spoilers for last Sunday’s episode of “Power.”
2016-08-15.headline_main: On ‘Power,’ an ‘Unholy Trinity’ Reaches a Breaking Point

2016-08-15.abstract: Despite aggressive monetary policies under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, the second-quarter G.D.P. figure showed fitful growth.
2016-08-15.snippet: Despite aggressive monetary policies under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, the second-quarter G.D.P. figure showed fitful growth.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: NAGOYA, Japan — Japan on Monday reported that its economy had expanded by the smallest of margins in the second quarter. The country has been struggling to ignite growth after years of slumping wages and prices. The currency has shot up this year, hurting crucial export industries. It’s the world’s third-largest economy. So what does it mean when it grows only a fraction of a percent in one quarter?
2016-08-15.headline_main: The Numbers Behind Japan’s Sputtering Economy

2016-08-15.abstract: Oksana Chusovitina of Uzbekistan competed in her seventh Games and was seventh in the vault final. The average age of her opponents was 20.
2016-08-15.snippet: Oksana Chusovitina of Uzbekistan competed in her seventh Games and was seventh in the vault final. The average age of her opponents was 20.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Now that the marquee gymnastics events are over at the Rio Games — with the Japanese men and the American women proving to be the best in the team and all-around competitions — the sport’s apparatus finals have begun.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Gymnast’s Specialty: Returning to the Olympics. (She’s 41. It’s Her 7th Trip.)

2016-08-15.abstract: The city now joins other places where police killings highlighted simmering anger over the systemic problems that have so many black people feeling hopeless.
2016-08-15.snippet: The city now joins other places where police killings highlighted simmering anger over the systemic problems that have so many black people feeling hopeless.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: The burning buildings, smashed police cars and scuffles between police officers and angry protesters on Milwaukee’s north side over the weekend might have seemed like a spontaneous eruption.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Racial Violence in Milwaukee Was Decades in the Making, Residents Say

2016-08-15.abstract: In Brooklyn Heights, a team of architects will give a second life to a dilapidated 19th-century mansion.

2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: In Brooklyn Heights, a team of architects will give a second life to a dilapidated 19th-century mansion.

2016-08-15.snippet: A team of architects will restore a ruined 19th-century building in Brooklyn Heights, building a replica around the underlying structure.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, a mansion stood at the corner of Clark Street and Monroe Place in Brooklyn Heights. Built in 1872, it was stately and corniced, bedecked in stone scrollwork and intricate ironwork, a credit to its architect.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Tattered Brooklyn Mansion Has a Blueprint for Rebirth

2016-08-15.abstract: Teyonah Parris, part of show’s cast, discusses a charged topic surrounding black women and beauty.

2016-08-15.snippet: Travelers were told to leave two terminals while the police investigated, but no injuries were reported and there was no confirmation that shots had been fired.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Panicked travelers stampeded through Kennedy International Airport on Sunday night after unconfirmed reports of gunfire there, leading the police to evacuate two terminals and close part of a major highway that runs near the airport, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Reports of Gunfire at J.F.K. Airport Prompt Evacuation

2016-08-15.abstract: The activists Joshua Wong and Nathan Law were spared jail in a 2014 protest that led to pro-democracy sit-ins, and a third defendant’s jail term was suspended.

2016-08-15.abstract: A teenager goes missing after a night of revelry in “The Disappearance,” a sudsy French thriller. And survivors of the Orlando massacre talk about life after the attack.
2016-08-15.snippet: A teenager goes missing after a night of revelry in “The Disappearance,” a sudsy French thriller. And survivors of the Orlando massacre talk about life after the attack.

And survivors of the Orlando, Fla., massacre talk about life after the attack.

2016-08-15.snippet: The case for not promising too much.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: It’s fantasy football time in political punditry, as commentators try to dismiss Hillary Clinton’s dominance in the polls — yes, Clinton Derangement Syndrome is alive and well — by insisting that she would be losing badly if only the G.O.P. had nominated someone else. We will, of course, never know. But one thing we do know is that none of Donald Trump’s actual rivals for the nomination bore any resemblance to their imaginary candidate, a sensible, moderate conservative with good ideas.

2016-08-15.abstract: Pushing down the cost of borrowing doesn’t address weak consumer demand or weak business investment.
2016-08-15.snippet: Pushing down the cost of borrowing doesn’t address weak consumer demand or weak business investment.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Hoping to kick-start European economies, the European Central Bank took the extraordinary step two years ago of lowering one of its key interest rates to below zero. The idea was to discourage banks from stashing their money in the central bank by charging them a modest rate for doing so. Since the banks would lose money rather than earn interest on their deposits, it was hoped they would be prompted instead to make more loans at lower rates to businesses and consumers.
2016-08-15.headline_main: What Two Years of Negative Interest Rates in Europe Tell Us

2016-08-15.abstract: Times have changed. So why do so many queer narratives still end in death?
2016-08-15.snippet: Times have changed. So why do so many queer narratives still end in death?
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: The first time I fell in love, I did nothing about it. She seemed out of reach, unattainable, impossible. There was fear and doubt, naturally, but beneath all that, I had been conditioned to believe that if anything was certain, my happiness wasn’t. It was a time-honored tradition: My queerness was inherently tragic. That’s how I had been told our stories end. Women who loved women couldn’t live happily ever after.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Women Who Love Women Aren’t Tragic

2016-08-15.snippet: From the dollar store or the design studio, solutions to make daily tasks easier for the elderly.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: When Barbara Beskind, 92, had trouble reaching foods in the back of her refrigerator, she installed a lazy susan on an inside shelf. The revolving tray makes items much easier to reach. Ms. Beskind, a former occupational therapist in the Army who has age-related macular degeneration, a disease that reduces her central vision, also attached small tactile bumps to the “Answer” button and the “2” and “8” keys on her phone, making it easier for her to respond to and make calls.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Hacks Can Ease the Trials of Aging

2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Credit card debt among Americans under 35 has fallen to its lowest level since 1989. Having racked up a pile of student loans, young people want to avoid the kind of pressure that they saw their family and friends under during the financial crisis. And laws passed after that crisis make it harder for them to secure credit cards anyway.

2016-08-15.abstract: Why is it the developed world has to find fault in a developing country that organizes a major sporting event?
2016-08-15.snippet: Why is it the developed world has to find fault in a developing country that organizes a major sporting event?
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: When I was a correspondent in Brazil 30 years ago, inflation was rampant. It ran at an average of 707.4 percent a year from 1985 to 1989. The salaries of the poor were wiped out within hours of being paid. The country went through three currencies — cruzeiro, cruzado and cruzado novo — while I lived in Rio. The only way out for Brazilians, people joked, was Galeão, the international airport.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Brazil’s Uplifting Olympics

2016-08-15.abstract: Professional women’s boxing has never been easy to sell. But if the sport’s officials were smart, they’d recognize that they need fighters like the Olympian Claressa Shields.
2016-08-15.snippet: Professional women’s boxing has never been easy to sell. But if the sport’s officials were smart, they’d recognize that they need fighters like the Olympian Claressa Shields.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: There’s a scene in “T-Rex” — a documentary that follows the middleweight phenom Claressa Shields from her hometown of Flint, Mich., to the 2012 Olympic Games in London and back again — that perfectly illustrates the biggest problem faced by women’s boxing. Shields is sitting with two Team U.S.A. representatives and her coach, Jason Crutchfield, in a nondescript lobby after glory and fanfare have receded into a post-Olympic haze. She has returned home after four decisive victories, having won the first American gold medal in women’s boxing. She’s 17. The reps from Team U.S.A. are discussing her sponsorship opportunities. Names like Ryan Lochte and Gabby Douglas are tossed out as the sort of Olympians to whom sponsors flock. Team U.S.A.’s public-relations consultant, a woman named Julie Goldsticker, goes into an incomprehensible description of why sponsors are attracted to certain people. Then she looks at Shields and says: “I would love for you to stop saying that you like beating people up and making them cry.”
2016-08-15.headline_main: Women Have Been Boxing in the Shadows for Too Long

2016-08-15.abstract: It grabs headlines to say medical errors in hospitals kill more people than guns or cars. But there are problems with this assertion.
2016-08-15.snippet: It grabs headlines to say medical errors in hospitals kill more people than guns or cars. But there are problems with this assertion.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: When I started out as a doctor in 1999, the Institute of Medicine published a blockbuster report that declared that up to 98,000 people were dying in United States hospitals each year as a result of preventable medical errors. Just a few months ago, a study in the BMJ declared that number has now risen to more than 250,000, making preventable medical errors in hospitals the third-largest cause of death in the country in 2013.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Death by Medical Error: Adding Context to Scary Headlines

2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK — The New York Herald Tribune, one of America’s oldest and most influential newspapers, went out of existence today [Aug. 15]. The newspaper, which sent Stanley to find Livingstone in Africa, fell victim to rising costs, strong competition and a series of prolonged strikes. The owners of the World Journal Tribune, a corporation formed by the merger of the morning Herald Tribune and the afternoon ‘‘Journal American’’ and the ‘‘World Telegram and the Sun,’’ announced the Herald Tribune’s death. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 16, 1966

2016-08-15.abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: “St Mary’s Day” in 1916 loses its traditional splendor.
2016-08-15.snippet: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: “St Mary’s Day” in 1916 loses its traditional splendor.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: ‘‘St. Mary’s Day’’ was shorn of much of its customary splendor yesterday [Aug. 15]. In normal times on August 15, the Feast of the Assumption, every Marie in France — there are hundreds of thousands of them, mostly pretty, or have been pretty — is fairly certain to receive a bouquet, or a flowering plant in blossom, or a humble little nosegay, from some relative, or suppliant, or friend. But the war’s baleful effect has touched even ‘‘la Sainte-Marie.’’ Husbands, suppliants, brothers and friends are in the trenches, and for countless Maries yesterday, instead of being a day of rejoicing, was one of sad memories. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Aug. 16, 1916
2016-08-15.headline_main: 1916: ‘St. Mary’s Day’ Loses Splendor

2016-08-15.abstract: Why is Emperor Akihito of Japan announcing his wish to abdicate now?
2016-08-15.snippet: Why is Emperor Akihito of Japan announcing his wish to abdicate now?
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — August is always a solemn time in Japan. It is the month when we remember the double destruction of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, and Japan’s defeat in World War II. This year, however, we find ourselves not only remembering history, but witnessing it: The nation has been shaken by a recent video message from Emperor Akihito in which he hinted that he wished to abdicate.
2016-08-15.headline_main: The Emperor and the Prime Minister

2016-08-15.abstract: Miller, from the Bahamas, beat American Allyson Felix by 0.07 seconds. Americans Laurie Hernandez and Simone Biles took silver and bronze, respectively, on the balance beam.
2016-08-15.snippet: Miller, from the Bahamas, beat American Allyson Felix by 0.07 seconds. Americans Laurie Hernandez and Simone Biles took silver and bronze, respectively, on the balance beam.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: In a desperate lunge at the finish line, Shaunae Miller of the Bahamas won the women’s 400 meters at the Rio Olympics on Monday night, defeating Allyson Felix of the United States.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Rio Olympics: Shaunae Miller Dives to Gold in 400 Meters

2016-08-15.abstract: After 80 years of dormancy, the Czechoslovakian brand Nehera, helmed by Samuel Drira, has become surprisingly modern.
2016-08-15.snippet: After 80 years of dormancy, the Czechoslovakian brand Nehera, helmed by Samuel Drira, has become surprisingly modern.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Today, it is possible to purchase a pair of pants online and have those pants hand-delivered to you — neatly folded in a gift box — within the hour. But in the 1920s, when the Czechoslovakian businessman Jan Nehera founded his eponymous brand, if you wanted pants you had to make them yourself, or have a tailor make them for you. Nehera thought shopping should be easy, so he started producing ready-to-wear clothing made from sturdy, practical material that you could buy straight off the rack. The result was a new model that revolutionized the industry and shot Nehera to success. His brand flourished throughout the 1930s — at its height, there were 130 stores across Europe — until World War II brought things to a halt.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Brand to Know: A Voluminous Line, Brought Back From the Past

2016-08-15.abstract: The experimental performance space in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, will feature new guest programmers, 30 newly commissioned works and the start of an online arts journal.
2016-08-15.snippet: The experimental performance space in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, will feature new guest programmers, 30 newly commissioned works and the start of an online arts journal.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: National Sawdust, the experimental performance space that opened in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, last fall and quickly became a vital part of New York’s new music scene, said Monday that its second season would feature a roster of guest programmers, 30 newly commissioned works and the start of an online arts journal.

2016-08-15.snippet: Mr. Trump, in a foreign policy address, called for “extreme vetting” of prospective new arrivals that would include an “ideological test.”
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump on Monday invoked comparisons to the Cold War era in arguing that the United States must wage an unrelenting ideological fight if it is to defeat the Islamic State. He said he would temporarily suspend immigration from “the most dangerous and volatile regions of the world” and judge allies solely on their participation in America’s mission to root out Islamic terrorism.

2016-08-15.abstract: Officials and many residents say a plan to create 10 anchorage sites on the river would be a step backward for communities that have worked hard to shed their industrial pasts.
2016-08-15.snippet: Officials and many residents say a plan to create 10 anchorage sites on the river would be a step backward for communities that have worked hard to shed their industrial pasts.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: YONKERS — This city’s mayor, Mike Spano, likes to stroll along the Hudson River waterfront and marvel at the changes since the 1980s. Hundreds of millions of dollars in public and private investment have transformed a once forlorn riverfront marred by abandoned industry into a vibrant place where people live and play.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Plan to Let Barges Park on the Hudson Meets Resistance in ‘River Towns’

2016-08-15.abstract: Doughnuts are a hot commodity at Grindstone Coffee in Sag Harbor, N.Y.
2016-08-15.snippet: Doughnuts are a hot commodity at Grindstone Coffee in Sag Harbor, N.Y.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Kyle Shanahan lives in Sag Harbor, N.Y., where he thought there was a shortage of coffee shops like the ones he recalled in his native Cleveland. “And nothing goes better with coffee than doughnuts,” he said. So he has opened his own coffee and doughnut shop, with help from his stepfather, the chef Michael Symon. Mr. Shanahan’s doughnuts are yeasted, but made from brioche dough, so they have a denser, more caky consistency than most. Each day he produces four classics and four special doughnuts, like one gleaming with chocolate glaze and a popcorn topping and another with lemon-poppy seed icing. The honey-glazed variety, one of his classics, is my favorite. He makes 1,300 on weekdays, 2,200 on weekends, and when they’re gone, they’re gone: Grindstone Coffee and Donuts, 7A Main Street (Bay Street), Sag Harbor, N.Y., 631-808-3370, grindstonecoffeeanddonuts.com.
2016-08-15.headline_main: When They’re Gone, They’re Gone

2016-08-15.abstract: Some 90 years after they were developed, Bronx seedless table grapes have arrived in New York.
2016-08-15.snippet: Some 90 years after they were developed, Bronx seedless table grapes have arrived in New York.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Bronx grapes have arrived. Some 90 years after the Cornell Agricultural Experiment Station in Geneva, N.Y., and the New York Botanical Garden developed the Bronx Seedless table grape, Lagier Ranches in Escalon, Calif., has enough of a crop of these lovely translucent pale green-to-pink grapes (with thin skins and a lush, almost candied flavor) to ship them to New York. The organic grapes have been sold on a limited basis in Northern California, but the grape never grew well in the Northeast. They will be available for about three weeks: Bronx Seedless Table Grapes from Lagier Ranches, $6.99 for a one-pound box at Agata & Valentina and Eataly stores.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Give Them the Old Bronx Grape

2016-08-15.abstract: “Preserving Italy” is a new cookbook that shows how to savor summer’s bounty the Italian way.
2016-08-15.snippet: “Preserving Italy” is a new cookbook that shows how to savor summer’s bounty the Italian way.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: In summer, books about canning and preserving are as common as apple cookbooks in the fall. But Domenica Marchetti’s book caught my eye for its uncommon point of view: preserving food the Italian way. Pack artichokes, peppers and mushrooms in oil. Make deliciously spicy pickles from melon. Even limoncello, mostarda and confections like torrone can come straight from your kitchen. There are simple cheeses and cured meats, along with a useful section covering tomatoes, but the option of freezing for preservation is not included. At the end of each chapter are some easy recipes for using your homemade creations. It’s a cautious book that stresses safety over shortcuts. The techniques may have been passed down by generations of nonnas, but they knew what they were doing: “Preserving Italy” by Domenica Marchetti (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $23).
2016-08-15.headline_main: Canned Tomatoes and So Much More

2016-08-15.abstract: Many jails in the South lack air-conditioning. To plenty of prisoners, and some federal judges, that effectively amounts to cruel and unusual punishment.
2016-08-15.snippet: Many jails in the South lack air-conditioning. To plenty of prisoners, and some federal judges, that effectively amounts to cruel and unusual punishment.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: JENNINGS, La. — The air inside the Jefferson Davis Parish jail was hot and musty. Prisoners, often awakened by the morning heat, hoped for cooling rain after nightfall. And ice, one inmate recalled, brought fleeting relief in the cell she called a “sweatbox.”
2016-08-15.headline_main: In U.S. Jails, a Constitutional Clash Over Air-Conditioning

2016-08-15.abstract: When you hear complaints about too much regulation, don’t forget to ask what harm that regulation may prevent.
2016-08-15.snippet: When you hear complaints about too much regulation, don’t forget to ask what harm that regulation may prevent.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Capitalism may be the best economic system ever devised, but one of its drawbacks is that it provides financial incentives to harm and even kill people. Just ask those people who say they have been victimized by cigarettes, predatory lenders, Volkswagen diesel emissions, Takata airbags, General Motors ignition switches, Trump University, Vioxx, asbestos or other products.
2016-08-15.headline_main: The Risks of Unfettered Capitalism

2016-08-15.abstract: A new pink gin adds a blush to summer martinis.
2016-08-15.snippet: A new pink gin adds a blush to summer martinis.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: This season of rosé now includes a gin. Pink gin, a Victorian-era throwback said to have been first concocted by the Royal Navy, achieves its pale salmon color from the botanicals and bitters used to mellow the spirit’s strong juniper profile. This English gin, made in pot stills in small batches, gets its name from the Gin Act of 1751, legislation designed to restrict the sale of “demon” gin to the poor. Consider it for a blushing martini or gimlet, or simply serve it on the rocks with a spritz of lime and just a splash of good tonic: Gin Lane 1751 “Victoria” Pink Gin, $27.99 from ginlane1751.com.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Rosé All Day, but at Night, Grab the Gin

2016-08-15.abstract: Reflections on world-class performance by two Olympic gold medalists, along with a numeric challenge by the math educator Sunil Singh.
2016-08-15.snippet: Reflections on world-class performance by two Olympic gold medalists, along with a numeric challenge by the math educator Sunil Singh.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: “Great spirits have always encountered violent opposition from mediocre minds,” wrote Albert Einstein in 1940. The expression is a terrible cliché at this point, but it’s always intrigued me. What does “violent opposition” look like? Are only mediocre minds susceptible? And how do these great spirits respond?
2016-08-15.headline_main: Numberplay: Olympic Strategies, Part 2

2016-08-15.abstract: Fresh chocolate mousse in white or dark chocolate now available in the dairy case.
2016-08-15.snippet: Fresh chocolate mousse in white or dark chocolate now available in the dairy case.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: “There has to be a chocolate mousse that’s fresh, not frozen,” said Johan Halsberghe, who was the chef for the Belgian ambassador in New York. So he decided to do something about it. He uses organic Belgian chocolate for his white- and dark-chocolate mousses, made in Brooklyn and sold fresh in food shops. The dark variety is light-textured and creamy with an excellent balance of bitter and sweet. The white chocolate version, made with gelatin, is a trifle spongier in texture, but also not too sweet. Both are sold in small plastic containers. The mousses can be unmolded for more elegant service by running a knife around the inside of the cup and inverting it with a bit of force onto a plate: Johan Fresh Chocolate Mousse, dark, 2.47 ounces; white, 2.82 ounces, each $3.99 at Brooklyn Fare, 431 West 37th Street, 212-216-9700, brooklynfare.com.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Belgian Chocolate in a Pudding Cup

2016-08-15.abstract: Airbnb has teamed up with corporate travel management companies and introduced new rules and services to appeal to business travelers and their bosses.
2016-08-15.snippet: Airbnb has teamed up with corporate travel management companies and introduced new rules and services to appeal to business travelers and their bosses.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Whether traveling for business or pleasure, Tad Milbourn, chief executive of the San Francisco technology start-up Payable, stays at an Airbnb property whenever possible.

2016-08-15.abstract: Eric Ripert recounts his early career at a talk at the Museum of Food and Drink.

2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: The chef Eric Ripert will discuss his childhood in the south of France and his early years working in Paris as recounted in his new memoir, “32 Yolks: From My Mother’s Table to Working the Line,” at the Museum of Food and Drink. Signed copies of the book will be sold afterward: “32 Yolks, a Conversation With Eric Ripert,” Aug. 30, 6:30 to 8 p.m., $35, Museum of Food and Drink, 62 Bayard Street (Lorimer Street), Williamsburg, Brooklyn, mofad.org.

2016-08-15.abstract: There are no guidelines to distinguish between the cases that deserve criminal prosecution and the ones that receive only a civil proceeding.
2016-08-15.snippet: There are no guidelines to distinguish between the cases that deserve criminal prosecution and the ones that receive only a civil proceeding.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Insider trading can be prosecuted by the Justice Department, and it can be pursued in a civil enforcement action by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The S.E.C. used to handle the bulk of these cases, but lately it seems that more cases result in criminal charges along with a parallel lawsuit.

2016-08-15.abstract: Brazil has deployed a security force of 85,000 for the Olympics, but with an economy in turmoil, residents fear that violence will soon surge again.
2016-08-15.snippet: Brazil has deployed a security force of 85,000 for the Olympics, but with an economy in turmoil, residents fear that violence will soon surge again.

A police officer was killed when his vehicle was sprayed with gunfire, and an Olympics bus carrying journalists was attacked by people throwing rocks.

2016-08-15.abstract: A capsule collection of beautifully lightweight cashmere from Calvin Klein.
2016-08-15.snippet: A capsule collection of beautifully lightweight cashmere from Calvin Klein.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: No matter where you look, the ’90s, suddenly, are back — with slip dresses, crop tops and dark lipstick. Now comes Calvin Klein’s new all-cashmere offering, a 23-style range of sumptous fabric in black, white and stone gray. There are ribbed turtlenecks and blanket scarves, simple pullovers, leggings and lightweight T-shirts. Best of all, the pieces come in a variety of cashmere weights — so they will take you from early fall straight through to the depths of winter.
2016-08-15.headline_main: The ’90s-Minimalist Revival to End Them All

2016-08-15.abstract: Giants of the industry are facing off against smaller players over a proposal to give the F.D.A. more authority to ensure the safety of beauty products.
2016-08-15.snippet: Giants of the industry are facing off against smaller players over a proposal to give the F.D.A. more authority to ensure the safety of beauty products.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Los Angeles hairstylist Chaz Dean pitched his almond mint and lavender-scented hair care products — endorsed by celebrities like Brooke Shields and Alyssa Milano — he sold millions. But his formula got an unexpected result: itching, rashes, even hair loss in large clumps, in both adults and children.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Their Hair Fell Out. Should the F.D.A. Have the Power to Act?

2016-08-15.abstract: The nation’s embrace of Western foods like red meat and soda has exacerbated the problem, researchers from Harvard University found.
2016-08-15.snippet: The nation’s embrace of Western foods like red meat and soda has exacerbated the problem, researchers from Harvard University found.

2016-08-15.headline_main: Upset by Brexit, Some British Jews Look to Germany

2016-08-15.abstract: Surgeons can learn in a virtual surgical theater, wielding a virtual scalpel, among the many ways medical situations are simulated. But the moments of truth can’t be.
2016-08-15.snippet: Surgeons can learn in a virtual surgical theater, wielding a virtual scalpel, among the many ways medical situations are simulated. But the moments of truth can’t be.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: You’d think medicine would be the last holdout against virtual reality. After all, the body is the body — solid flesh, no faking it, no escaping it. We may turn books into bytes, create driverless cars and soldierless wars; but even patched with plastic and titanium and attached to external electric circuits, the body is still where medicine does business.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Yes, Medicine Can Use Virtual Reality, Emphasis on Reality

2016-08-15.abstract: European owners of tainted Volkswagen diesels are being offered far less in restitution than American owners, but online legal start-ups are working to close the gap.
2016-08-15.snippet: European owners of tainted Volkswagen diesels are being offered far less in restitution than American owners, but online legal start-ups are working to close the gap.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Volkswagen owners in the United States will receive about $20,000 per car as compensation for the company’s diesel deception. Volkswagen owners in Europe at most get a software update and a short length of plastic tubing.
2016-08-15.headline_main: In the U.S., VW Owners Get Cash. In Europe, They Get Plastic Tubes.

2016-08-15.abstract: Meet Chloé’s freewheeling inspiration, Anne-France Dautheville.
2016-08-15.snippet: Meet Chloé’s freewheeling inspiration, Anne-France Dautheville.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Anne-France Dautheville is 28 in 1972, astride a Moto Guzzi 750 motorcycle on the way to Tehran, traveling alone cross-continent. She’s flagged down by a car, and three children get out to ask Dautheville about herself, her life and her eye makeup. (“I always made up my eyes,” she recalls.) “Then they start driving faster than me. Ten kilometers later, they stop on the side of the road, and they stop me again. I ask, ‘Is there something you forgot?’ And they say, ‘Well, we were wondering, are you a girl or are you a boy?’ ” Dautheville throws back her head and roars with laughter.
2016-08-15.headline_main: In the ’70s, She Motorcycled Around the World. Today, She’s Fashion’s Unlikely New Muse.

2016-08-15.snippet: Journalists have nothing to fear from my campaign against the website.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Last month, I spoke at the Republican National Convention in Cleveland because I believe our country is on the wrong track, and we need to solve real problems instead of fighting fake culture wars. I’m glad that an arena full of Republicans stood up to applaud when I said I was proud to be gay, because gay pride shouldn’t be a partisan issue. All people deserve respect, and nobody’s sexuality should be made a public fixation.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Peter Thiel: The Online Privacy Debate Won’t End With Gawker

2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Bill Shine, the newly appointed co-president of Fox News, commutes two hours every morning from Long Island to Midtown Manhattan, leaving his house so early that, as he tells colleagues, “the other guys on the train all have Sheetrock on their boots.”

2016-08-15.abstract: There are reasons for Lyft, the No. 2 American ride-hailing service, to steer clear of Detroit, but with pressure from cash-flush rivals like Uber, it may eventually run out of road.
2016-08-15.snippet: There are reasons for Lyft, the No. 2 American ride-hailing service, to steer clear of Detroit, but with pressure from cash-flush rivals like Uber, it may eventually run out of road.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Lyft, the No. 2 American ride-hailing service, recently rebuffed takeover interest from General Motors, its 9 percent owner, according to the news service The Information. There are reasons for Lyft to steer clear of Detroit, despite a shared vision for autonomous cars. But cash-flush rivals could still force the Silicon Valley start-up into G.M.’s lane.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Lyft Declined G.M. Takeover Effort, but Rivals Could Force Its Hand

2016-08-15.abstract: The revelation that $12.7 million in cash payments from a pro-Russian political party were earmarked for Mr. Manafort provided yet another distraction to the campaign.
2016-08-15.snippet: The revelation that $12.7 million in cash payments from a pro-Russian political party were earmarked for Mr. Manafort provided yet another distraction to the campaign.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: The Trump campaign was on the defensive on Monday after a New York Times report revealed that its chairman, Paul Manafort, was designated to receive $12.7 million in undisclosed and potentially illegal cash payments from a pro-Russian political party in Ukraine.

2016-08-15.abstract: Should we not call out lies, lest a bigger liar come along?
2016-08-15.snippet: Should we not call out lies, lest a bigger liar come along?
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: So, there’s a new conservative take on who’s to blame for Donald Trump — and the answer, it turns out, is liberal commentators, and me in particular. Yep, by denouncing the dishonesty of people like Mitt Romney, I was crying wolf, so that voters paid no attention to warnings about Trump.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Lies, Lying Liars, and Donald Trump

2016-08-15.abstract: Larry Tye’s biography goes beyond the “bad Bobby” and “good Bobby” approach in exploring how a hard-nosed politician came to tilt against social injustice.
2016-08-15.snippet: Larry Tye’s biography goes beyond the “bad Bobby” and “good Bobby” approach in exploring how a hard-nosed politician came to tilt against social injustice.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Reading about the life and death of Robert F. Kennedy, the reader can’t help but be reminded of the striking parallels between the late 1960s and today — polarized politics, racial tensions and growing social anxiety and tumult. It’s also impossible not to think about the vast gulf between the idealistic hopes Kennedy inspired among his young followers, and the fear and cynicism that have marked this year’s presidential campaign.
2016-08-15.headline_main: From Bare Knuckles to Idealism in ‘Bobby Kennedy: The Making of a Liberal Icon’

2016-08-15.abstract: Officials said there was no evidence that a report of gunfire at J.F.K. on Sunday night was a deliberate hoax. What followed, they said, was a sign of the times.

2016-08-15.snippet: Russia’s foreign minister acknowledged that daily three-hour pauses in fighting in Aleppo were insufficient to halt a humanitarian disaster.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Acknowledging an unfolding disaster in Syria’s besieged city of Aleppo, where roughly two million people are trapped, Russia conceded on Monday that daily three-hour halts in fighting that it had proposed last week were insufficient, possibly opening the door to longer pauses.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Under Pressure Over Aleppo Siege, Russia Hints at Seeking Deal With U.S.

2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: At first glance, it seemed to have the all the makings of a Jane Austen novel: wholesome second daughter of a country family that has come up in the world gets swept away by wealthy, dashing suitor after whirlwind romance and years of enduring idle gossip around her broken courtships and social aspirations, not to mention poisonous comparisons with a dazzling older sister.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Pippa Middleton Goes Out on Her Own. But She’s Not Alone.

2016-08-15.abstract: This AXS TV movie presents a version of history in which Presley didn’t really die on Aug. 16, 1977, but faked his demise to protect himself and his family.
2016-08-15.snippet: This AXS TV movie presents a version of history in which Presley didn’t really die on Aug. 16, 1977, but faked his demise to protect himself and his family.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Thinking people everywhere know that Elvis Presley is alive. We just disagree on the details, like where and how, and what his hair looks like these days. All of us, though, are probably going to be disappointed in the rather bland possibility presented in “Elvis Lives!,” a Tuesday night movie on AXS TV.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Review: ‘Elvis Lives!’ (And Not Just in Your Head)

2016-08-15.abstract: A theater critic with an infant son is going to shows less this summer, but she is managing to stay engaged in her field — sometimes outdoors.
2016-08-15.snippet: A theater critic with an infant son is going to shows less this summer, but she is managing to stay engaged in her field — sometimes outdoors.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: Recently, I went a whole month without seeing a play. Five weeks, actually. For most people, this is a profound nonevent. For me, it was a marvel. And also sort of a problem. I was a drama-besotted adolescent who became a college actress who became a theater critic. I don’t really know what to do with myself if I’m not spending a lot of my week sitting in a creaking plush seat, staring up at a stage.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Devotion to the Stage, and to a Newborn

2016-08-15.abstract: In Toshiki Okada’s latest play, commissioned by Hoi Polloi and staged at Jack, theatergoers sit on a mattress as a mystery traveler roams through the space.
2016-08-15.snippet: In Toshiki Okada’s latest play, commissioned by Hoi Polloi and staged at Jack, theatergoers sit on a mattress as a mystery traveler roams through the space.
2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: New York may be a world capital, but it can feel provincial when it comes to non-English-speaking theater. Oh, we see Chekhov and Ibsen and indulge in the occasional French comedy, but those works tend to be decades or centuries old. The situation is dire for playwrights who happen to be alive.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Review: In ‘Quiet, Comfort,’ a Mattress Becomes the Audience’s Magic Carpet

There, for the past week of searing heat, he had slept in a pup tent pitched on the pavement to be among the first in a line of several hundred people seeking to join the carpenters’ union.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Waiting 8 Days in the Heat for a Career in Carpentry

2016-08-15.lead_paragraph: VANCOUVER, British Columbia — The Cannabis Culture Lounge has everything a pothead might need to feel right at home: $3 marijuana buds, bongs for rent, bags of Skittles and Doritos for sale, and black leather couches where customers can recline in zoned-out contemplation in a pungent haze. Never mind that it is all technically prohibited by Canadian law.
2016-08-15.headline_main: As Canada Moves to Legalize Marijuana, Shop Owners Ask: Why Wait?

2016-08-15.snippet: Mr. Richard, a pastry chef by training, brought a playful, French twist to his food, and headed some of the United States’ most beloved restaurants.

He was 68.
2016-08-15.headline_main: Michel Richard, Acclaimed Chef at Citronelle, Dies at 68

2016-08-15.abstract: Anna Sofia Botha, 74, has coached the South African runner Wayde van Niekerk for four years, helping him break the elusive men’s 400-meter world record.
2016-08-15.snippet: Anna Sofia Botha, 74, has coached the South African runner Wayde van Niekerk for four years, helping him break the elusive men’s 400-meter world record.

And, without exception, her puzzles are solid and fun to solve.

2016-08-16.abstract: Fu Yuanhui, already a media star for her exuberant style, broke a taboo among female athletes by telling an interviewer she had her period at the Olympics.
2016-08-16.snippet: Fu Yuanhui, already a media star for her exuberant style, broke a taboo among female athletes by telling an interviewer she had her period at the Olympics.
2016-08-16.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The uninhibited Fu Yuanhui, the Chinese swimmer beloved for her over-the-top expressions, has made waves once again. On Saturday night in Rio, she freely discussed having her period while competing in the Olympics, breaking what has long been a taboo among female athletes. The video of her poolside interview quickly went viral.
2016-08-16.headline_main: Uninhibited Chinese Swimmer, Discussing Her Period, Shatters Another Barrier

2016-08-16.snippet: Mr. Hutcherson was one of the first jazz musicians to adapt his instrument to a freer postbop language, often playing chords with a pair of mallets in each hand.

2016-08-16.abstract: Symbols are free speech, too. We can’t let Big Tech make all our choices.
2016-08-16.snippet: Symbols are free speech, too. We can’t let Big Tech make all our choices.
2016-08-16.lead_paragraph: Cambridge, Mass. — This month, Apple previewed some changes to its next generation of iPhones and iPads with the promise that “all the things you love to do are more expressive, more dynamic and more fun than ever.” That especially includes emojis, those little icons that, according to one study, 92 percent of the online population now make part of their everyday communication.
2016-08-16.headline_main: Apple’s Emoji Gun Control

2016-08-16.abstract: Passage of state legislation would provide a national model for promoting retirement savings.
2016-08-16.snippet: Passage of state legislation would provide a national model for promoting retirement savings.
2016-08-16.lead_paragraph: At any given moment, about half of the private-sector employees in the United States — some 60 million people — do not have any type of employer-sponsored retirement plan. The result is a growing American underclass, in which a third of current retirees live almost entirely on Social Security and fully half of future retirees will face reduced standards of living. Worse, the coverage gap has long proved intractable, with Congress and the financial industry unable or unwilling to design or support truly simple and low-cost retirement savings plans.
2016-08-16.headline_main: From California, a Better Way to Retire

2016-08-16.abstract: Far from delivering a plausible blueprint for action, Donald Trump further exposed his ignorance and lack of understanding of world affairs.
2016-08-16.snippet: Far from delivering a plausible blueprint for action, Donald Trump further exposed his ignorance and lack of understanding of world affairs.
2016-08-16.lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s speech on Monday was advertised as an attempt to redirect his campaign from a series of blunders to a more serious discussion of foreign policy, starting with combating global terrorism. As such, it marked another test of his readiness to lead. It did not go well.
2016-08-16.headline_main: Mr. Trump’s Foreign Policy Confusions

2016-08-16.abstract: How the secret Known or Suspected Terrorist File threatens civil liberties.
2016-08-16.snippet: How the secret Known or Suspected Terrorist File threatens civil liberties.
2016-08-16.lead_paragraph: New Haven — When a police officer pulled over Peter Santilli last December in Newtown, Ohio, it seemed like a routine traffic stop. But when the officer ran his data in the law enforcement database, Mr. Santilli’s name came up as a match on a terrorist watch list. The cop “pulled out his weapon immediately,” Mr. Santilli said, and told him to put his hands up.
2016-08-16.headline_main: Who Will Watch the Watch List?

2016-08-16.abstract: Despite recent reports, crime has fallen steeply and continues to fall in New York City.
2016-08-16.snippet: Despite recent reports, crime has fallen steeply and continues to fall in New York City.
2016-08-16.lead_paragraph: A blogger who writes about New York City parks looked at some crime statistics recently and found an uptick. For the nine months ending in March, there were 417 major crimes (like murder, rape, robbery and assault) in about 1,000 of the city’s biggest parks. That is up 23 percent from the 340 crimes reported in the same period last year.
2016-08-16.headline_main: The Shadow of Crime in City Parks

2016-08-16.snippet: Terrorism fatalities in the most dangerous countries in the world are falling. But deaths in North America and Western Europe, still rare, are up.
2016-08-16.lead_paragraph: If it feels as if terrorism deaths are rising in the West, it’s because they are. Yet the numbers remain relatively small, and globally, deaths from terrorism appear to be declining, not rising.
2016-08-16.headline_main: Is Terrorism Getting Worse? In the West, Yes. In the World, No.
