2016-08-18.headline_main: Who Are the Swimmers Who Were With Ryan Lochte?

2016-08-18.abstract: The network’s pro-American predisposition has been visible in who is interviewed after an event or whose families are shown in stadiums and arenas.
2016-08-18.snippet: The network’s pro-American predisposition has been visible in who is interviewed after an event or whose families are shown in stadiums and arenas.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: NBC’s Summer Games broadcasts should be thought of as an Olympic edition of “America’s Got Talent,” a 17-day series about a rousingly successful American team tailored to an American audience that is probably happy to watch Americans do fantastically well in Rio de Janeiro.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Little Is Medal-Worthy About NBC’s Coverage of Foreign Athletes

2016-08-18.abstract: Quotation of the day for Thursday, August 18, 2016.
2016-08-18.snippet: Quotation of the day for Thursday, August 18, 2016.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: “Fear is a good thing. Fear is going to lead you to take action.”
2016-08-18.headline_main: Quotation of the Day

2016-08-18.abstract: Wednesday’s episode revealed what many had suspected: that Elliot’s mundane post-hack life was an elaborate mental deception.
2016-08-18.snippet: Wednesday’s episode revealed what many had suspected: that Elliot’s mundane post-hack life was an elaborate mental deception.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: No canned laughter, no “Full House” theme song, no retro commercials, no ALF cameo — and yet somehow I don’t think anyone will complain about a relative lack of narrative boldness in this week’s episode of “Mr. Robot.” Turns out it’s not just a 20-minute sojourn in sitcom land for which Elliot Alderson departed from reality this time around. He’s actually been living in a fantasy world all season.
2016-08-18.headline_main: ‘Mr. Robot’ Season 2, Episode 7: Escaping Reality

2016-08-18.abstract: There are still about 24 million American adults without coverage, according to a survey by a health research group.
2016-08-18.snippet: There are still about 24 million American adults without coverage, according to a survey by a health research group.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: Roughly 20 million more Americans have health insurance now than when President Obama’s health care law was passed in 2010. But as Mr. Obama prepares to leave office, there are still about 24 million adults with no coverage, according to a survey by the Commonwealth Fund, a health research group. That translates to an uninsured rate of about 13 percent, down from 20 percent in 2013. Who are the remaining uninsured?
2016-08-18.headline_main: Six Years Into Obama’s Health Care Law, Who Are the Uninsured?

2016-08-18.abstract: Brown was suspended for an unspecified violation of the N.F.L.’s personal conduct policy. He may participate fully throughout the preseason.
2016-08-18.snippet: Brown was suspended for an unspecified violation of the N.F.L.’s personal conduct policy. He may participate fully throughout the preseason.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: The Giants’ Pro Bowl place-kicker Josh Brown was suspended Wednesday under the N.F.L.’s personal conduct policy and will miss the opening game of the season against the Dallas Cowboys on Sept. 11. The cause of the one-game suspension, which is without pay, was not specified. Brown, in a statement issued by the team, said he disagreed with the decision by the league.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Giants Kicker Josh Brown Suspended for Season Opener

2016-08-18.abstract: Corrections appearing in print on Thursday, August 18, 2016.

2016-08-18.abstract: Neymar scored the fastest goal in Olympic history and then added a penalty kick in stoppage time as Brazil beat Honduras, 6-0, for a spot in the gold medal match.
2016-08-18.snippet: Neymar scored the fastest goal in Olympic history and then added a penalty kick in stoppage time as Brazil beat Honduras, 6-0, for a spot in the gold medal match.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: Neymar scored the fastest goal in Olympic history and then added a penalty kick in stoppage time on Wednesday as Brazil beat Honduras, 6-0, for a spot in the gold medal match. Brazil has never won Olympic gold in the sport.
2016-08-18.headline_main: After an Injury Scare, Neymar Strikes Back Against Honduras

2016-08-18.abstract: Steam up your screen — while basking in air-conditioned comfort — with “Unfaithful,” “Body Heat” and “Match Point.” Usain Bolt, meanwhile, races for another gold.
2016-08-18.snippet: Steam up your screen — while basking in air-conditioned comfort — with “Unfaithful,” “Body Heat” and “Match Point.” Usain Bolt, meanwhile, races for another gold.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: Baby, it’s hot outside. Steam up your screen — while basking in air-conditioned comfort — with “Unfaithful,” “Body Heat” and “Match Point.” Usain Bolt, meanwhile, races for another gold in the 200-meter sprint. And “Deliverance” provides a late-night chill.
2016-08-18.headline_main: What’s on TV Thursday: ‘Unfaithful’ and Usain Bolt in Rio

2016-08-18.abstract: Usain Bolt advanced to the 200-meter final in an effort to win his third straight gold medal in the event, and Brazilian teams had a busy day on the beach and the indoor volleyball courts.
2016-08-18.snippet: Usain Bolt advanced to the 200-meter final in an effort to win his third straight gold medal in the event, and Brazilian teams had a busy day on the beach and the indoor volleyball courts.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: Usain Bolt advanced to the 200-meter final in an effort to win his third straight gold medal in the event, and Brazilian teams had a busy day on the beach and the indoor volleyball courts.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Bolt Is Back

2016-08-18.abstract: Niese, making his first start since rejoining the Mets, was not alone in his struggles as Rickie Weeks Jr. and Yasmany Tomas combined for four homers to lead an Arizona rout.
2016-08-18.snippet: Niese, making his first start since rejoining the Mets, was not alone in his struggles as Rickie Weeks Jr. and Yasmany Tomas combined for four homers to lead an Arizona rout.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — There are many reasons the Mets have plodded through the past three weeks. They have endured more injuries. Their offense has remained inadequate. Their pitching has not been sharp, especially at the back end of the rotation.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Jon Niese Returns to Starting Role, and Mets Return to Losing

2016-08-18.abstract: “Freedom Jazz Dance — The Bootleg Series Vol. 5,” which includes studio recordings from the late 1960s, will be released on Oct. 21.
2016-08-18.snippet: “Freedom Jazz Dance — The Bootleg Series Vol. 5,” which includes studio recordings from the late 1960s, will be released on Oct. 21.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: The Miles Davis Quintet of the 1960s has long been praised as one of the most advanced small groups in jazz history, and anyone seeking to test the claim can choose from an abundance of evidence: studio albums, concert and club recordings, multi-disc collections. This fall will bring a new addition: “Freedom Jazz Dance — The Bootleg Series Vol. 5,” a three-CD boxed set.
2016-08-18.headline_main: New Miles Davis Boxed Set Features His Quintet at Its Peak

2016-08-18.abstract: This word has appeared in four New York Times articles in the past year.
2016-08-18.snippet: This word has appeared in four New York Times articles in the past year.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: superannuated • \ˌsü-pər-ˈan-yə-ˌwat-ed\ • adjective
2016-08-18.headline_main: Word of the Day + Quiz | superannuated

2016-08-18.abstract: The portraiture of William Eggleston, whose color photography helped shepherd the medium into the art world, is the exclusive feature of a new exhibit and book.
2016-08-18.snippet: The portraiture of William Eggleston, whose color photography helped shepherd the medium into the art world, is the exclusive feature of a new exhibit and book.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: The portraiture of William Eggleston, whose color photography helped shepherd the medium into the art world, is the exclusive feature of a new exhibit and book.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Highly Personal Portraiture by William Eggleston

2016-08-18.abstract: Discrimination is resurgent at the town, city and county levels.
2016-08-18.snippet: Discrimination is resurgent at the town, city and county levels.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: In Texas, Michigan, North Carolina and elsewhere, federal courts in recent months have struck down one discriminatory voting law after another in a series of major victories for voting-rights advocates. Millions of voters, especially minorities who might have otherwise been obstructed by voter-identification requirements or shortened early voting times, will now be able to cast their ballots in the presidential election.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Voting Rights Success? Not So Fast

2016-08-18.abstract: Both Mr. Trump and Mr. Pence opposed the bailout that helped save the auto industry. Our columnist disagrees, and he was there.
2016-08-18.snippet: Both Mr. Trump and Mr. Pence opposed the bailout that helped save the auto industry. Our columnist disagrees, and he was there.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: No shortage of critics unleashed their weaponry eight years ago as the federal government intervened to save General Motors and Chrysler when they teetered near bankruptcy. Among the more notable: Mitt Romney, who’s well remembered for his 2008 New York Times Op-Ed article, “Let Detroit Go Bankrupt.”
2016-08-18.headline_main: What Trump Doesn’t Know About Detroit

2016-08-18.abstract: In recent abortion and voter ID cases, courts have looked at what lawmakers are really doing, not what they say they are doing.
2016-08-18.snippet: In recent abortion and voter ID cases, courts have looked at what lawmakers are really doing, not what they say they are doing.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: In 1962, in the midst of the civil rights movement, African-American residents of Jackson, Miss., went to court to challenge the racial segregation of the city’s five municipal swimming pools, four of which were set aside for whites and one for blacks. When the plaintiffs won, the Jackson City Council responded by closing all the pools. It first claimed a “minor water difficulty” and later explained that integrated pools would present a safety problem and would be too expensive to operate. No pools, evidently, were preferable to integrated pools.
2016-08-18.headline_main: The Courts Begin to Call Out Lawmakers

2016-08-18.abstract: Ending a visa program that granted a safe haven for interpreters would be reckless and morally reprehensible.
2016-08-18.snippet: Ending a visa program that granted a safe haven for interpreters would be reckless and morally reprehensible.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: The nation’s rancorous debate over immigration policy has greatly diminished the chances of citizenship for a small group of people who have done a great service to the United States and are as deserving as anyone to make it their new home. They are the Afghan interpreters who, at considerable risk to their lives and families, worked for the American government during the war and who remain in mortal danger.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Breaking a Promise to Afghan Translators

2016-08-18.abstract: How a passionate and instructive love affair with the sport became a refuge from nerves.
2016-08-18.snippet: How a passionate and instructive love affair with the sport became a refuge from nerves.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: “Just relax,” my freshman high school basketball coach said when I forgot to remove my warm-up jacket. It was the middle of the third quarter, score tied. I nodded and bolted toward the court. He yanked my jersey and reminded me to report to the scorer’s table first.
2016-08-18.headline_main: A Life of Anxiety and Basketball

2016-08-18.abstract: An inmate faces execution under a law that blames accomplices as much as actual killers.
2016-08-18.snippet: An inmate faces execution under a law that blames accomplices as much as actual killers.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: When it comes to capital punishment, there is not much official mercy to be found in the state of Texas.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Rare Chance for Mercy on Texas’ Death Row

2016-08-18.abstract: Readers had different reactions to two reasons I am grieving.
2016-08-18.snippet: Readers had different reactions to two reasons I am grieving.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: Last Thursday, our beloved family dog, Katie, died at the age of 12. She was a gentle giant who respectfully deferred even to any mite-size puppy with a prior claim to a bone. Katie might have won the Nobel Peace Prize if not for her weakness for squirrels.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Do You Care More About a Dog Than a Refugee?

2016-08-18.abstract: To the extent that they succeed in finding work at all, older people are likely to find themselves in certain types of jobs.
2016-08-18.snippet: To the extent that they succeed in finding work at all, older people are likely to find themselves in certain types of jobs.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: The rules of the job market aren’t the same for older workers.
2016-08-18.headline_main: More Older People Are Finding Work, but What Kind?

2016-08-18.abstract: The portraiture of William Eggleston, whose color photography helped shepherd the medium into the art world, is the exclusive feature of a new exhibit and book.
2016-08-18.snippet: The portraiture of William Eggleston, whose color photography helped shepherd the medium into the art world, is the exclusive feature of a new exhibit and book.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: Most portrait artists attempt to differentiate the emotional essence of each individual subject. But William Eggleston, a father of color photography whose 1976 Museum of Modern Art exhibit arranged by John Szarkowski helped shepherd the medium into the art world — much to the chagrin of critics — insists that he photographs a person the same way he photographs a parking lot. A new exhibition of his portraiture at the National Portrait Gallery in London, however, belies that assertion by displaying more than 100 highly personal images.
2016-08-18.headline_main: For William Eggleston, People Are Like Parking Lots

2016-08-18.abstract: Stung by dozens of different insects for his research, the entomologist Justin Schmidt has become an expert in physical agony.
2016-08-18.snippet: Stung by dozens of different insects for his research, the entomologist Justin Schmidt has become an expert in physical agony.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: Within minutes of our first meeting, and more or less in response to my saying good morning, Justin Schmidt began lamenting our culture’s lack of insect-based rites of passage. He told me about the Sateré-Mawé people in northwestern Brazil, who hold a ceremony in which young men slip their hands into large mitts filled with bullet ants, whose stings are so agonizing they can cause temporary paralysis; when initiates pass the test, they’re one step closer to becoming full members of society.
2016-08-18.headline_main: The Connoisseur of Pain

2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Part of Jillian Boshart’s life plays out in tidy, ordered lines of JavaScript computer code, and part in a flamboyant whirl of corsets and crinoline. She’s a tech student by day, an enthusiastic burlesque artist and producer by night. “Code-mode” and “show-mode,” she calls those different guises.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Debt. Terror. Politics. To Seattle Millennials, the Future Looks Scary.

The rewards were high — for those willing to make a wager — and bets on the decision to leave, or “Brexit,” were dirt cheap.

2016-08-18.abstract: Garlicky grits, slices of avocado and a velvety gravy combine to make a dish that is as deeply satisfying as it is simple.
2016-08-18.snippet: Garlicky grits, slices of avocado and a velvety gravy combine to make a dish that is as deeply satisfying as it is simple.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: In the hierarchy of enjoyable social interactions, “chitchat in the dentist’s chair” ranks barely higher than “unbidden office talk in the men’s room.” But last month, the hygienist buzzing my teeth fascinated me with her vacation stories. She had taken her first trip to Haiti, where her family is from. We talked a bit about the hits of Haitian cuisine — the crisped chile-­citrus pork called griot, the beautifully named black-­mushroom rice called diri djon djon. But what struck me was her story about the man next to her on the plane. He was returning to his birthplace and was miserable about it. She tried to cheer him up, but when they landed, he turned his head from the window and said, “Looks like I haven’t missed much.”
2016-08-18.headline_main: A Haitian Grandmother’s Home-Cooked Porridge

2016-08-18.abstract: “A Tale of Love and Darkness,” based on Amos Oz’s memoir, depicts a family caught up in the conflict and confusion leading to Israel’s war of independence.
2016-08-18.snippet: “A Tale of Love and Darkness,” based on Amos Oz’s memoir, depicts a family caught up in the conflict and confusion leading to Israel’s war of independence.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: “A Tale of Love and Darkness,” Natalie Portman’s directing debut, addresses a hugely complicated and consequential moment in 20th-century history: the founding of the state of Israel. There is no simple way to tell the story, and Ms. Portman’s film, closely based on a memoir by the Israeli novelist Amos Oz, is full of mixed emotions and chronological tangles. But despite the geopolitical momentousness — and present-day potency — of its concerns, it’s an elegant and intimate movie, a thing of nostalgic whispers and sighs rather than polemical slogans and shouts.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Review: From Natalie Portman, Israel’s Birth Distilled in Mood and Memory

2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — Organizers have defended the choice of Hong Kong as the site for a global conference on transplants, saying it did not signify international acceptance of China’s transplant system, which long relied on organs from executed prisoners. Chinese officials say that they are overhauling the system, and that the use of prisoners’ organs has ended.

2016-08-18.abstract: To all of you struggling to find your fitness groove, I have a message for you: Do less, and do it regularly.
2016-08-18.snippet: To all of you struggling to find your fitness groove, I have a message for you: Do less, and do it regularly.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: Watching the Olympics, especially the track and field events, has long been somewhat fraught for me. Sixteen years ago this summer, I retired from my career as a professional runner and abandoned my dreams of becoming an Olympian. I had been a top-ranked American runner, represented the United States in international competition and was a World University Games gold medalist. So while viewing the Olympics brought joy, it was matched with an undercurrent of sadness and self-criticism. I missed my former life and lamented the lack of intensity in my physical fitness regime.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Advice From a Former Olympic Hopeful: Set the Bar Low

2016-08-18.abstract: Want to save on airfare? Pick your travel days wisely, don’t shop too far in advance and know when tickets will be offered at a sale price.
2016-08-18.snippet: Want to save on airfare? Pick your travel days wisely, don’t shop too far in advance and know when tickets will be offered at a sale price.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: The airfare for your family vacation to Orlando, Fla., cost you $500 a person. Your friend snagged tickets there during the same week for nearly half the price. What gives? It may not be pure luck, according to Rick Seaney, the founder of farecompare.com, an airline ticket comparison site. “There are ways to save on airfare, but you have to know the tricks,” he said. Here, he shares his top ones.
2016-08-18.headline_main: You Can Save on Airfare (If You Know the Tricks)

The kidnapping sparked an international outcry, and a #BringBackOurGirls Twitter campaign.

2016-08-18.abstract: The Smithsonian Channel’s day of nautical programming includes a look at the Queen Mary’s war years and the story of the U.S.S. Tang.
2016-08-18.snippet: The Smithsonian Channel’s day of nautical programming includes a look at the Queen Mary’s war years and the story of the U.S.S. Tang.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: The Queen Mary, put into service 80 years ago, was built as a passenger liner, but World War II altered its mission, a transformation explored in “Mighty Ship at War: The Queen Mary,” which airs Sunday, Aug. 21, as part of a daylong nautical theme on the Smithsonian Channel. As the situation in Europe darkened, the ship was increasingly used to ferry emigrants out of troubled areas, and once Britain declared war, it was turned into a troop transport. The program recounts a catastrophic incident in 1942 when the liner collided with one of its own escort ships, the Curacao, splitting it in half and killing more than 300. Sunday’s lineup also includes the final installment of “Hell Below,” a six-part series on submarine warfare in World War II. Part 6, “Fatal Voyage,” is about the U.S.S. Tang, which compiled a formidable record against Japanese ships until a fateful engagement in October 1944, when it was sunk by one of its own malfunctioning torpedoes.
2016-08-18.headline_main: A Luxury Liner at War, a Submarine in Peril

2016-08-18.abstract: The Beach Sessions, at Rockaway Beach, bring contemporary dance to the water’s edge and work with organizations that help the environment.
2016-08-18.snippet: The Beach Sessions, at Rockaway Beach, bring contemporary dance to the water’s edge and work with organizations that help the environment.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: Typically, dancers are barefoot, not their audiences. But at the Beach Sessions, at Rockaway Beach, spectators can wriggle their toes in the sand. Last year, the Rockaway resident Sasha Okshteyn started this free outdoor series to bring contemporary dance from city stages to the long shoreline of Queens. The effort is ecological as well as artistic: In pairing performance with beach cleanups and partnering with organizations like the Surfrider Foundation, Ms. Okshteyn is forging a dialogue between dance and its environs.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Beach Cleanup and Dance, Together in Queens

2016-08-18.headline_main: Rio Olympics: Ashton Eaton and Usain Bolt Defend Titles

2016-08-18.abstract: “The Secret Life of Textiles: Animal Fibers” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art also gets into the often inscrutable facts of textiles.
2016-08-18.snippet: “The Secret Life of Textiles: Animal Fibers” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art also gets into the often inscrutable facts of textiles.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: “The Secret Life of Textiles: Animal Fibers” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art delves deep into the history and beauty but also the often inscrutable facts of textiles. Its two dozen items range across several cultures and centuries, including Chinese textile fragments from the fourth century B.C., Indian and Russian shawls, men’s hats from Tibet and Korea, and a 19th-century French Jacquard-weave portrait of George Washington. Building on nature’s genius, these often labor-intensive artifacts use fibers from yaks, sheep, goats, horses, cows and silkworms. One of the few intact garments in this show is a lavish ceremonial robe from 19th-century China discreetly trimmed in cat fur. Especially enlightening are the works’ labels, which parse the different fibers’ morphologies and the techniques that transformed them, aided by greatly magnified photographs. (Through Feb. 20; 212-535-7710, metmuseum.org.)
2016-08-18.headline_main: Delving Into the History and Beauty of Textiles at the Met

2016-08-18.abstract: Among the performers are the pianist Randy Weston, the singer Jazzmeia Horn and the alto saxophonist Grace Kelly.
2016-08-18.snippet: Among the performers are the pianist Randy Weston, the singer Jazzmeia Horn and the alto saxophonist Grace Kelly.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: The Charlie Parker Jazz Festival is one of the more generous rites of summer in the city: a weekend’s worth of free performances, uptown and downtown, with a lineup that cuts across age and style. Named after a peerless alto saxophonist and bebop lodestar, the festival usually spotlights one of his former contemporaries. This year, it’s the magisterial pianist Randy Weston, who recently turned 90; he is to perform on Saturday, Aug. 27, with his African Rhythms Sextet at Marcus Garvey Park.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Charlie Parker Jazz Festival Has Free Shows for Many Tastes

2016-08-18.abstract: Programs at Merkin Concert Hall and the Kaplan Penthouse provide divergent listening opportunities.
2016-08-18.snippet: Programs at Merkin Concert Hall and the Kaplan Penthouse provide divergent listening opportunities.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: In 1680, the Baroque composer and organist Dietrich Buxtehude wrote “Membra Jesu Nostri,” a cycle of seven cantatas reflecting on the body of Christ. Over two programs on Sunday, Aug. 21, at Merkin Concert Hall, the International Contemporary Ensemble (ICE), in residence this summer at the Mostly Mozart Festival, will perform the cantatas along with seven works written in response to them by a diverse group of composers. The new pieces will be introduced in two groups: The first, at 3 p.m., will feature works by David T. Little, Anna Thorvaldsdottir, Caroline Shaw and Hans Thomalla; for the second, at 7 p.m., Buxtehude’s sacred cantatas will be heard along with pieces by Lewis Spratlan, Pelle Gudmundsen-Holmgreen and Santa Ratniece. The Crossing, an acclaimed chamber choir, joins ICE for these bold programs.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Exploring Jesus and Josephine Baker Through Music

2016-08-18.abstract: The app, a curated list of stories intended to broaden The Times’s reader base, will no longer be available to download starting the week of Aug. 29.
2016-08-18.snippet: The app, a curated list of stories intended to broaden The Times’s reader base, will no longer be available to download starting the week of Aug. 29.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: In early 2014, The New York Times introduced an app called NYT Now that would provide a curated list of stories — for a lower price than a full digital subscription — to what it hoped would be a younger, mobile-savvy audience. Jill Abramson, then the executive editor of The Times, unveiled the app at the South by Southwest conference in Austin, Tex.
2016-08-18.headline_main: New York Times to Shelve NYT Now App

2016-08-18.abstract: Ellen McLaughlin, who played the celestial messenger in “Angels in America” on Broadway, brings her “Trojan Women” to the Flea Theater’s resident actors.
2016-08-18.snippet: Ellen McLaughlin, who played the celestial messenger in “Angels in America” on Broadway, brings her “Trojan Women” to the Flea Theater’s resident actors.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: The Greek tragedians, the dramatist Ellen McLaughlin writes, “ask the hardest questions.” Perhaps best known for portraying the celestial messenger in the Broadway production of Tony Kushner’s “Angels in America,” Ms. McLaughlin continues to ask those questions from her own perspective, in her own language. Having refracted the Hellenic take on the nature of humanity and mortality, on war and its aftermath, in contemporary adaptations of works by Sophocles (“Oedipus”) and Aeschylus (“The Persians”), Ms. McLaughlin revisits the battle-ravaged plains and psyches of Euripides’ all too timely “The Trojan Women,” at the Flea Theater. Directed by Anne Cecelia Haney, with choreography by Joya Powell, the show begins performances on Wednesday, Aug. 24, featuring the Flea’s resident acting company, the Bats. (Through Sept. 26; 866-811-4111, theflea.org.)
2016-08-18.headline_main: An Angel Introduces Bats to Trojans

2016-08-18.abstract: The Qatari-American artist Sophia Al-Maria presents a dystopian view of the Gulf states.
2016-08-18.snippet: The Qatari-American artist Sophia Al-Maria presents a dystopian view of the Gulf states.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: At art school in London a decade or so ago, the Qatari-American artist, writer and filmmaker Sophia Al-Maria came up with a pithy term, Gulf Futurism, to describe the warp-speed transformations of Dubai and other oil-rich cities: the rise of hotels, malls and museums and the incorporation of the area’s Bedouin tribes into an international consumer class. She has been elaborating on this catchphrase ever since, in videos and writings that combine sci-fi fantasies with dystopian musings on the human and environmental costs of hyperdevelopment.
2016-08-18.headline_main: The Luxury Mall as Consumer Prison

2016-08-18.abstract: “History of the World, Part I” is one of seven Brooks movies being served with food and drinks at the theater-restaurant Syndicated.
2016-08-18.snippet: “History of the World, Part I” is one of seven Brooks movies being served with food and drinks at the theater-restaurant Syndicated.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: What’s moronic, tasteless and celebrating its 35th anniversary this year? “History of the World, Part I,” Mel Brooks’s 1981 cameo-filled collection of ersatz historical episodes. Janet Maslin, reviewing the film when it came out, complained that “many of the jokes are either meanspirited or scatological, or both,” and these days the best way to watch it may be with an accompaniment of grub and alcoholic beverages. That’s possible Monday, Aug. 22, at Syndicated, the theater and restaurant in Bushwick, Brooklyn, which begins a Brooks week with the movie that evening. Sample gag: Moses comes down from the mountain carrying three tablets and announces to his people, “The Lord Jehovah has given unto you these 15 [drops one tablet, which shatters] — 10! Ten Commandments.” The rest of the week’s lineup: “Blazing Saddles,” “Robin Hood: Men in Tights,” “Spaceballs,” “Young Frankenstein,” “The Producers” and “High Anxiety.” (syndicatedbk.com.)
2016-08-18.headline_main: A Week of Mel Brooks in Brooklyn

2016-08-18.abstract: Istalif’s resurgence after the fall of the Taliban in 2001 hardened the reputation for resilience it earned over centuries, but now it is threatened again.
2016-08-18.snippet: Istalif’s resurgence after the fall of the Taliban in 2001 hardened the reputation for resilience it earned over centuries, but now it is threatened again.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: ISTALIF, Afghanistan — To survive the last catastrophe, when their town was sacked and burned by the Taliban, the potters of the northern Afghan town of Istalif buried the tools of their trade and fled, some enduring years of exile until the threat finally passed.
2016-08-18.headline_main: War and Pillaging Couldn’t Break an Afghan Village, but a Tumbling Economy May

2016-08-18.abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Britain stops exports to Sweden in August 1916.
2016-08-18.snippet: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: Britain stops exports to Sweden in August 1916.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: LONDON, England — The King to-day [Aug. 18] signed the proclamation forbidding all exports from Great Britain to Sweden, except under special license. General satisfaction is expressed in the press at the energetic measures taken to prevent the re-exportation of merchandise from Sweden to enemy countries. It is fully realized here that the Government has been forced to action by sheer force of circumstances, of which the Swedish Trade Law of April 16, 1916, making it illegal for an importer in Sweden to furnish an exporter in the United Kingdom with information regarding the disposal of the goods, was the climax.
2016-08-18.headline_main: 1916: Britain Stops Exports to Sweden

2016-08-18.snippet: The newest wave of white rappers, acts like G-Eazy, Mike Stud and Lil Dicky, has avoided the established hip-hop industry.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: Last month, the white rapper G-Eazy — a handsome ectomorph sporting a motorcycle jacket and 1950s-slick hair — headlined a show at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, part of a weekslong tour. Over the last couple of years, this Oakland, Calif., musician has evolved from regional curio to legitimate pop contender: He appears on the lead single from the forthcoming Britney Spears album, and in March, his song “Me, Myself & I” with the guest singer Bebe Rexha — from his platinum album, “When It’s Dark Out” — went to No. 7 on the Billboard Hot 100.
2016-08-18.headline_main: White Rappers, Clear of a Black Planet

2016-08-18.abstract: In “Southside With You,” a 25-year-old Mrs. Obama, then Michelle Robinson, gets ice cream and a first kiss from the future president.
2016-08-18.snippet: In “Southside With You,” a 25-year-old Mrs. Obama, then Michelle Robinson, gets ice cream and a first kiss from the future president.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: WEST HOLLYWOOD, Calif. — Tika Sumpter knew the screenplay was something special. It was, at its core, a romance, with two charming leads slowly falling for each other over the course of a single Chicago day. They speak passionately — at some points, angrily — about moral courage and racial politics and the struggles of staying true to oneself. They take sides on “Good Times” versus “The Brady Bunch,” ice cream versus pie. They quote the poet Gwendolyn Brooks (“We Real Cool”) from memory, while sizing up Ernie Barnes’s painting “Sugar Shack.” They watch “Do the Right Thing.”
2016-08-18.headline_main: Tika Sumpter on Playing the Future First Lady, Michelle Obama

2016-08-18.abstract: Ralph Lauren’s first collection of round timepieces for women features Breguet-style hands and a bold combination of numerals.
2016-08-18.snippet: Ralph Lauren’s first collection of round timepieces for women features Breguet-style hands and a bold combination of numerals.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: It was women who pioneered wearing watches on the wrist. Queen Elizabeth was given an intricately bejeweled one by the Earl of Leicester in 1572; the Queen of Naples had a band made of hair and gold thread. While men continued to keep their watches in their pockets, sporty 19th-century ladies wore timepieces with leather straps while on horseback and bicycles. Ralph Lauren channels that intrepid spirit with his first collection of round watches for women, RL888, named for the address of his flagship Madison Avenue mansion. The selection features Breguet-style hands and a bold combination of Arabic and Roman numerals. Many have interchangeable straps, including this one made of slick black alligator.
2016-08-18.headline_main: An Instantly Classic Women’s Watch

2016-08-18.abstract: Ivy Mix, a decorated master of cocktails, worked with her father on a new line of in-demand vessels, handmade in Vermont.
2016-08-18.snippet: Ivy Mix, a decorated master of cocktails, worked with her father on a new line of in-demand vessels, handmade in Vermont.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: If you’ve been to Leyenda, the Brooklyn cocktail joint known for jalapeño-infused tequila tipples and tiki-inspired pisco potions, you’ve likely met Ivy Mix — or at least enjoyed her drinks. She runs the bar with her partner Julie Reiner (both are highly decorated in the world of mixology; last year, Mix won Best American Bartender at the Oscars of the spirits industry, Tales of the Cocktail); and despite Leyenda’s success, it’s just one aspect of Mix’s resume. Much of her time is spent on the road managing Speed Rack, the femme-focused national cocktail competition she co-founded in 2011. And this month, she launches a new venture: a new line of barware created in partnership with her father, Robin Mix, a glassblowing artist based in rural Vermont.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Barware, by a Beloved Brooklyn Bartender’s Dad

2016-08-18.abstract: Feminists have typically opposed war, but taking up arms is one way for women to defend their communities and to define their place in them.
2016-08-18.snippet: Feminists have typically opposed war, but taking up arms is one way for women to defend their communities and to define their place in them.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: Two years ago this month, the Islamic State attacked the Yazidis, a Kurdish religious minority who live around Sinjar Mountain in Iraq. The militants came down on unprotected villages like Byron’s wolf on the fold, slaughtering the men and taking away thousands of women and children to be sold as sex slaves.
2016-08-18.headline_main: When Women Fight ISIS

2016-08-18.abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: The U.S. Senate passes a defense bill on the Vietnam War in August 1966.
2016-08-18.snippet: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: The U.S. Senate passes a defense bill on the Vietnam War in August 1966.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Senate unanimously passed today a near-record $58.2 billion defense money bill providing about $10 billion and possibly thousands of men for the Vietnam war. The Senate bill, exceeded only by a 1944 World War II Army appropriation, included a controversial provision that would give President Johnson authority to call up individual reservists for duty in Vietnam. Reserve groups have expressed opposition to the amendment, which could, if Mr. Johnson exercised this authority, strip some Reserve units of personnel. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 19, 1966
2016-08-18.headline_main: 1966: Senate Passes Defense Bill

2016-08-18.abstract: An American teenager seeks his place in the world in Heidelberg, Germany.
2016-08-18.snippet: An American teenager seeks his place in the world in Heidelberg, Germany.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: “Morris From America,” Chad Hartigan’s charming new film, begins with a father-son discussion of hip-hop, an argument about beats, flows and hooks. It’s partly an affectionate intergenerational dispute; 13-year-old Morris (Markees Christmas) is skeptical of his father’s old-school dogma, while his dad, Curtis (Craig Robinson), dismisses his son’s taste as too pop. The conversation also provides a clue about the movie’s own strategies. It’s a pop confection with a rough, honest texture, real but not raw and suffused with an infectious sweetness that lingers after the final shot.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Review: ‘Morris From America’: A 13-Year-Old Stranger in a Strange Land

2016-08-18.abstract: Charlie, Emerson and other unisex names are not just a Hollywood fad but a rising trend among American parents.
2016-08-18.snippet: Charlie, Emerson and other unisex names are not just a Hollywood fad but a rising trend among American parents.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: When it came to naming their third son a few weeks ago, Megan Fox and Brian Austin Green sidestepped traditional boys names like Ethan and Jacob for the gender-agnostic name Journey, which may have been a subtle nod to the couple’s much-chronicled attempts to work their way back from the brink of divorce.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Is Hayden a Boy or Girl? Both. ‘Post-Gender’ Baby Names Are on the Rise.

2016-08-18.abstract: American brewers have taken up the dark art of sour beers. Results are mixed, but the best indicate a promising future.
2016-08-18.snippet: American brewers have taken up the dark art of sour beers. Results are mixed, but the best indicate a promising future.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: Five years can be an eternity in the craft-beer business. What may begin as an experiment can accelerate into a fad, if not a furor. So it has seemed with American brewers and the range of styles collectively known as sour beers.
2016-08-18.headline_main: When Tart, Pungent and Funky Mean It’s a Good Brew

2016-08-18.abstract: This City Parks Foundation production at the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theater in Central Park features a clever update of the fairy tale.
2016-08-18.snippet: This City Parks Foundation production at the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theater in Central Park features a clever update of the fairy tale.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: Most audience members at the Swedish Cottage Marionette Theater politely turn off their cellphones before the curtain rises. But these days, at every performance, one all-too-typical Manhattan kid persists in texting, tweeting, posting, sharing, emailing and updating, completely oblivious to those around her.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Review: In ‘Little Red’s Hood,’ Tweets, Sweets and a Wolf on the Way to Grandma’s

2016-08-18.abstract: Word of the website’s closing comes after the sale of its parent, Gawker Media, to Univision this week.
2016-08-18.snippet: Word of the website’s closing comes after the sale of its parent, Gawker Media, to Univision this week.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: For nearly 14 years, Nick Denton and Gawker.com have defined Gawker Media.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Gawker.com to Shut Down Next Week

2016-08-18.abstract: What it takes to be a shuttle used at the Rio Games: the right temperature and humidity, demanding craftsmanship, and 16 feathers from the left wing of a goose.
2016-08-18.snippet: What it takes to be a shuttle used at the Rio Games: the right temperature and humidity, demanding craftsmanship, and 16 feathers from the left wing of a goose.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: It has 16 goose feathers, sits on a stump of Portuguese cork and flies at up to 300 miles per hour, which makes the badminton shuttlecock one of the more curious pieces of sports equipment to be found anywhere.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Badminton’s Shuttlecock: Sports Gear’s Rare Bird

2016-08-18.abstract: Roughly one out of every 100 competitors at this year’s Games has served a suspension. So far, 25 have won medals in Rio.
2016-08-18.snippet: Roughly one out of every 100 competitors at this year’s Games has served a suspension. So far, 25 have won medals in Rio.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: Roughly one out of every 100 competitors at this year’s Games has served a suspension. So far, 25 have won medals in Rio.
2016-08-18.headline_main: At Least 120 Athletes at the Rio Olympics Were Previously Suspended for Doping

2016-08-18.abstract: In engrossing detail, Heather Ann Thompson charts the 1971 rebellion at the prison and decades of government efforts to prevent the full tale from being told.
2016-08-18.snippet: In engrossing detail, Heather Ann Thompson charts the 1971 rebellion at the prison and decades of government efforts to prevent the full tale from being told.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: Not all works of history have something to say so directly to the present, but Heather Ann Thompson’s “Blood in the Water: The Attica Prison Uprising of 1971 and Its Legacy,” which deals with racial conflict, mass incarceration, police brutality and dissembling politicians, reads like it was special-ordered for the sweltering summer of 2016.
2016-08-18.headline_main: ‘Blood in the Water,’ a Gripping Account of the Attica Prison Uprising

2016-08-18.abstract: The film’s director, writer and star, Nate Parker, has come under fire in recent days as details of a 1999 rape case in which he was charged and later acquitted have resurfaced.
2016-08-18.snippet: The film’s director, writer and star, Nate Parker, has come under fire in recent days as details of a 1999 rape case in which he was charged and later acquitted have resurfaced.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: Despite the controversy clouding the new film “The Birth of a Nation,” the Toronto International Film Festival will screen it as planned in September, according to a festival spokeswoman.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Toronto International Film Festival to Screen ‘The Birth of a Nation’ as Planned

2016-08-18.abstract: The glazed terra-cotta technique that became a specialty is showcased in “Della Robbia: Sculpting With Color in Renaissance Florence” at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.
2016-08-18.snippet: The glazed terra-cotta technique that became a specialty is showcased in “Della Robbia: Sculpting With Color in Renaissance Florence” at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — In Renaissance Italy, art was a form of advertising, pushing hopes and emotions as much as things. Allegorical images — Temperance, Justice, Charity — on urban facades promoted civic pride and obedience. In churches, sculptural angels offered getaway deals to heaven. Home icons of the Virgin and Child taught that salvation lay not in riches but in fruitfulness, patience and a good-night kiss.
2016-08-18.headline_main: The Art of Della Robbia: From Earth and Water, Pure Beauty

2016-08-18.abstract: News coverage of the Rio Games draws complaints about sexism in the media.
2016-08-18.snippet: News coverage of the Rio Games draws complaints about sexism in the media.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: When Corey Cogdell-Unrein of the U.S. Olympic team won a bronze medal in women’s trap shooting, The Chicago Tribune left out a key detail when it shared the  news: her name. It described her only as the wife of a Bears lineman.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Sure, These Women Are Winning Olympic Medals, but Are They Single?

2016-08-18.abstract: The automaker could not have modified engine software to deceive emissions regulators without help from Robert Bosch GmbH, lawyers said in a court filing.
2016-08-18.snippet: The automaker could not have modified engine software to deceive emissions regulators without help from Robert Bosch GmbH, lawyers said in a court filing.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — The German auto supplier Robert Bosch GmbH played a key role in developing the software that let Volkswagen cheat on clean air rules, according to new allegations filed in a San Francisco court on behalf of car owners.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Volkswagen Supplier Played Key Role in Cheating, Court Papers Say

2016-08-18.abstract: A federal judge made public still images from surveillance video in a class-action lawsuit alleging that migrants caught illegally entering the country are held in dirty, crowded cells.
2016-08-18.snippet: A federal judge made public still images from surveillance video in a class-action lawsuit alleging that migrants caught illegally entering the country are held in dirty, crowded cells.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — In June 2015, legal and civil rights groups filed a class-action lawsuit in Federal District Court in Tucson accusing the Border Patrol of holding migrants in dirty and crowded cells at stations in southeastern Arizona, after they were caught illegally entering the United States.
2016-08-18.headline_main: Photos Offer Glimpse Inside Arizona Border Detention Centers

2016-08-18.abstract: The racial divide in swimming not only raises safety and fitness issues but also can be a barrier to employment, a lifeguard writes.
2016-08-18.snippet: The racial divide in swimming not only raises safety and fitness issues but also can be a barrier to employment, a lifeguard writes.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
2016-08-18.headline_main: Swimming’s Racial Divide

2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
2016-08-18.headline_main: Champions of Our National Parks

2016-08-18.abstract: Tbilisi, the capital of Georgia, has an ancient wine culture, thermal baths, excellent food — and an unlikely electronic music scene. Party on.
2016-08-18.snippet: Tbilisi, the capital of Georgia, has an ancient wine culture, thermal baths, excellent food — and an unlikely electronic music scene. Party on.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: Back when Georgia — a country bordered by the Black Sea and the Caucasus Mountains — was behind the Iron Curtain, it was fancied the California of the U.S.S.R. Slightly smaller in size than South Carolina, but with impressively diverse terrain, this fertile country had a reputation for producing exceptional fruits and vegetables, superb wines and talented filmmakers. “When I was studying in Leningrad in the ’70s,” says Ambassador Ian C. Kelly, currently stationed in Georgia, “a group of us were taken to Tbilisi. Arriving there was like arriving in Oz — suddenly everything went from black and white to color.”
2016-08-18.headline_main: The California of the Caucasus

2016-08-18.abstract: Two rabbis react to an Op-Ed essay arguing that gender identity, even for God, was fluid in biblical times.
2016-08-18.snippet: Two rabbis react to an Op-Ed essay arguing that gender identity, even for God, was fluid in biblical times.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
2016-08-18.headline_main: Gender Identity in Olden Times: Interpreting the Torah

2016-08-18.abstract: The Swedish photographer Per-Anders Pettersson has spent the last five years documenting the vibrant fashion scene across sub-Saharan African.
2016-08-18.snippet: The Swedish photographer Per-Anders Pettersson has spent the last five years documenting the vibrant fashion scene across sub-Saharan African.

2016-08-18.abstract: Pietro, on Elizabeth Street, focuses on light interpretations of mainstay dishes — served in a bright pink space inspired by the Memphis Group.
2016-08-18.snippet: Pietro, on Elizabeth Street, focuses on light interpretations of mainstay dishes — served in a bright pink space inspired by the Memphis Group.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: In the middle of a quiet Elizabeth Street block, above an unmistakably pink subterranean stone entryway with flower boxes of mottled caladium leaves, a neon starburst with a smiley face announces a new arrival: the full-service “healthy Italian” restaurant Pietro Nolita. Its owners, Pietro Quaglia and Mina Soliman, met in 2003, when Soliman was working at Indochine as a maître d’. At the time, Quaglia was interning at Dolce and Gabbana, whose team held ritual Friday night dinners there. The pair didn’t talk restaurants until September of last year, when Quaglia was alerted the space was available by the restaurateur and designer Serge Becker — whose wife happens to be Soliman’s sister. The longtime friends becomes business partners soon thereafter.
2016-08-18.headline_main: The New (Very Pink) NoLIta Restaurant Making Italian Healthy

2016-08-18.abstract: While many readers praised Mr. Thiel, some questioned whether he was really a defender of Americans’ privacy.
2016-08-18.snippet: While many readers praised Mr. Thiel, some questioned whether he was really a defender of Americans’ privacy.
2016-08-18.lead_paragraph: While many readers praised Peter Thiel for his support of a lawsuit against Gawker, some questioned whether he was really a defender of Americans’ privacy, in response to a recent Op-Ed.
2016-08-18.headline_main: ‘A World Mr. Thiel Helped Create’: Readers on Peter Thiel and Gawker

2016-08-18.abstract: With its own fashion weeks, along with homegrown talent making a splash abroad, the continent is establishing itself as an important design hub.
2016-08-18.snippet: With its own fashion weeks, along with homegrown talent making a splash abroad, the continent is establishing itself as an important design hub.
