2016-08-23.abstract: Campaign-trail blunders allow reporters to criticize politicians without criticizing what they stand for. But what happens when a candidate says exactly what he thinks?
2016-08-23.snippet: Campaign-trail blunders allow reporters to criticize politicians without criticizing what they stand for. But what happens when a candidate says exactly what he thinks?
2016-08-23.lead_paragraph: When a politician says something stupid, reporters are traditionally expected to mask their glee with a veneer of shock and disappointment. It was in this mode, more or less, that the NBC News political director, Chuck Todd, and his colleague Carrie Dann began the Aug. 3 edition of First Read, the network’s daily political tip sheet, warning that Donald Trump’s campaign had gone “from ‘unraveling’ to ‘break glass’ mode.” They began with a heroic attempt to catalog all the previously inconceivable-for-a-presidential-nominee things Trump said and did in the preceding 24 hours, a long list that included the candidate’s displaying to a rally audience the Purple Heart medal he had been given by a retired U.S. Army lieutenant colonel who was wounded in Iraq. “I always wanted to get the Purple Heart,” said Trump, who received draft deferments during the Vietnam War for, among other things, bone spurs that had miraculously little impact on his youthful athletic career. “This was much easier.”
2016-08-23.headline_main: How Donald Trump Blew Up the ‘Gaffe’

2016-08-23.abstract: As capital punishment declines nationwide, a tiny fraction of the country generates an alarming number of death sentences. What this new geography tells us about justice in America.
2016-08-23.snippet: As capital punishment declines nationwide, a tiny fraction of the country generates an alarming number of death sentences. What this new geography tells us about justice in America.
2016-08-23.lead_paragraph: On a Saturday evening in July 2013, just before 6:30, James Rhodes was recorded on a surveillance camera walking into a Metro PCS cellphone store in Jacksonville, Fla. He was wearing a black do-rag and a blue bandanna, which he pulled over his nose and mouth. Shelby Farah, the store manager, stood behind the counter. Rhodes pointed a gun at her and demanded the money in the cash register. Shelby gave it to him. Then Rhodes shot her in the head. She was 20 years old. He was 21.
2016-08-23.headline_main: Where the Death Penalty Still Lives

2016-08-23.abstract: Mr. Obama met with residents on a trip that required a delicate mix of compassion and politics.
2016-08-23.snippet: Mr. Obama met with residents on a trip that required a delicate mix of compassion and politics.
2016-08-23.lead_paragraph: ZACHARY, La. — For Linda Fernandez, this summer has been one long disaster tour. In July, her daughter died in Baton Rouge, while her infant great-granddaughter mysteriously ailed in Houston. It was at a hospital there, a week and a half ago, where Ms. Fernandez learned she had lost her home, too, to flooding.
2016-08-23.headline_main: Obama Visits Louisiana Flood Victims, but Some Are Busy Just Hanging On

2016-08-23.abstract: Washing livestock in the Atlantic is a weekly tradition, even on the crowded beaches near the capital, Dakar, that the human swimmers favor.
2016-08-23.snippet: Washing livestock in the Atlantic is a weekly tradition, even on the crowded beaches near the capital, Dakar, that the human swimmers favor.
2016-08-23.lead_paragraph: The rest of the week, the beaches of Senegal are a haven for swimmers, sunbathers or anyone in the mood to relax under a grass-thatched umbrella with some grilled shrimp and an orange Fanta. A number of beaches around Dakar, the capital, have also become wildly popular with surfers, chasing the bliss of the perfect wave captured in the 1966 documentary “The Endless Summer,” which was shot partly in Senegal.
2016-08-23.headline_main: On Sundays in Senegal, Surf’s Up for the Sheep

2016-08-23.abstract: The problems that cities face in hosting the Olympics, like being left with immediately obsolete venues, call for organizers to develop a more sustainable approach.

2016-08-23.abstract: Many Turks have put aside political differences after a failed military uprising — although some may be motivated by fear in the wake of the president’s purge of suspected political enemies.

2016-08-23.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey is normally a divisive figure, loved by his base of religious conservatives and loathed by the rest of society. But there he was recently, sipping tea and making easy chitchat with his political rivals, just before joining them in a rally this month on Istanbul’s waterfront to celebrate the failure of an attempted military coup.

2016-08-23.lead_paragraph: When I was a kid, “Quantum Leap” was one of my favorite TV shows. Its conceit was ludicrous, but in a way that allowed for maximum entertainment: A time-travel experiment gone awry forces the handsome Dr. Sam Beckett to “leap” among different bodies at various points in history. Each episode began with Beckett waking up in a new situation and piecing together the mystery of his surroundings. The show didn’t shy away from serious themes: In one, he wakes up in the body of a woman who has just been raped; in another, he wakes up in the body of a black man in Alabama in the 1950s. “Quantum Leap” has stayed with me all these years, I think, because it offered my young, impressionable mind a framework for normal travel. Arriving in a new place — even if it’s in the same dimension — can be disjointing and chaotic, because each new destination is governed by an invisible set of rules.
2016-08-23.headline_main: Turning Instagram Into a Radically Unfiltered Travel Guide

2016-08-23.lead_paragraph: The syringe started off as a conspiracy theory about Hillary Clinton’s health posted on a fringe right-wing website. It traveled to the legitimizing megaphone of prime-time cable news. And it ended, after an agonizing journey through the new realities of the campaign media, with a single phone call that debunked its entire existence. There was no syringe.

2016-08-23.abstract: How social media helped a movement against sexual harassment and domestic violence break the taboo of silence.
2016-08-23.snippet: How social media helped a movement against sexual harassment and domestic violence break the taboo of silence.
2016-08-23.lead_paragraph: As in other days, the day I rebelled I was walking home from school by myself. I was 13, and I liked to wear the skirt of that godawful Peruvian school uniform above my knees. I loved my legs, and I had recently waxed them for the first time. It was Lima in the 1990s, I was crossing a street avoiding illegally parked cars shining under weak rays of sunshine and I did not even see it coming. All I felt was a burst of discomfort, a whiplash of shame. A hand slightly raising the skirt, brushing my thigh, trying to reach me. It lasted a few seconds. Like every time I experienced a “metida de mano” — a local institution of sexual harassment — I froze and muted an agonized scream.
2016-08-23.headline_main: The Day Peruvian Women Rebelled

2016-08-23.abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: 120-year-old parrot, Cocky Bennett, dies in Australia in August 1916.
2016-08-23.snippet: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: 120-year-old parrot, Cocky Bennett, dies in Australia in August 1916.
2016-08-23.lead_paragraph: LONDON — News has been received here that ‘‘Cocky Bennett,’’ probably the Mathusalah of the parrot world, has just died in Australia at the ripe age of 120 years. ‘‘Cocky’’ was born in 1796 in the neighbourhood of Sydney. Old age greatly deformed the bird’s once ‘‘cocky’’ head. The skin fell in folds, and his upper beak grew to an abnormal length. The centenarian, nevertheless, retained his activity and gaiety to almost the last, for he received visitors with a cheery cry of ‘‘Welcome, gentlemen.’’ — The New York Herald, European Edition, Aug. 24, 1916
2016-08-23.headline_main: 1916: Parrot, Age 120, Passes Away

When it comes to his own health, however, Mr. Trump has released only a bizarre letter from his doctor Harold Bornstein, which contains little medical detail. Mrs. Clinton has released a more detailed letter. In an interview, Dr. Robert Lahita, a professor of medicine at Rutgers University who has studied the history of presidential ailments, spoke about past presidents’ efforts to keep their illnesses under wraps and the need for more transparency.

2016-08-23.abstract: The novelist describes how she reacts to unsparing reviews and has come to take criticism less personally: “Sometimes fate smiles on you and sometimes it doesn’t.”
2016-08-23.snippet: The novelist describes how she reacts to unsparing reviews and has come to take criticism less personally: “Sometimes fate smiles on you and sometimes it doesn’t.”
2016-08-23.lead_paragraph: I only recently became a book critic. In 2014, when my own book came out, I remember living in deathly fear of the person I now am. How many jobs involve submitting your work to the scrutiny of a paid corps of strangers? It seemed, at the time, like someone’s idea of a cruel joke. And I instantly understood why Nathan Zuckerman fantasized about quitting the novel-writing business and becoming an obstetrician in Philip Roth’s “The Anatomy Lesson”: “He catches what comes out and everyone loves him. When the baby appears they don’t start shouting, ‘You call that a baby?’”
2016-08-23.headline_main: Criticism’s Sting: The Author Curtis Sittenfeld on Book Reviews

2016-08-23.abstract: A restaurant for Russian and Jewish specialties, a temple to Japanese udon noodles, and more food news.
2016-08-23.snippet: A restaurant for Russian and Jewish specialties, a temple to Japanese udon noodles, and more food news.
2016-08-23.lead_paragraph: LOX This spacious restaurant on the second floor of the Museum of Jewish Heritage takes its name seriously, offering five varieties of house-cured salmon, some smoked. Legendary Affairs, the company that has provided kosher food for catered events at the museum, was given the restaurant concession, and now David Teyf, the chef and owner, serves an array of Jewish and Russian dishes. Many, like the Russian coffee cake thickly barnacled with walnuts, and the salmon, are also sold to take away. Some other specialties are assorted herring dishes, smoked mackerel, cheese blintzes and mini black-and-white cookies. The restaurant serves dairy only. Some of the food, including a savory, buttery, garlic-laced matzoh babka from Minsk, which bears a slight resemblance to kugel, are recipes from Mr. Teyf’s grandfather. “My family is from Minsk, some of them are Holocaust survivors, and I am happy to honor them,” he said. The restaurant also has a lovely terrace:  36 Battery Place (First Place), 646-437-4231, loxnyc.com.
2016-08-23.headline_main: Lox, in a Jewish Museum, Offers a Gallery of Salmon

2016-08-23.abstract: The Dutch design collective We Make Carpets creates vibrant, intricately patterned installations out of everyday objects: deflated balloons, dry pasta and more.
2016-08-23.snippet: The Dutch design collective We Make Carpets creates vibrant, intricately patterned installations out of everyday objects: deflated balloons, dry pasta and more.
2016-08-23.lead_paragraph: At “Dream Out Loud,” a contemporary design exhibition opening Aug. 26 at the Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam, the Dutch collective We Make Carpets is bringing the party supplies. The trio, all in their early 30s, are known for installations of intricate patterns assembled from everyday objects, including colored sponges, dry pasta and deflated balloons. And in the Stedelijk show, three pulsating wall pieces, measuring about 6.5 by 9 feet, share a celebratory theme. “Stirrer Carpet” gets its glow from 8,000 neon-colored plastic cocktail stirrers; “Umbrella Carpet 2” employs 6,000 fancy-drink umbrellas; and “Cocktail Carpet 2” uses 16,000 shimmering cocktail sticks for its miniature fireworks. All of the pieces entice the viewer to zoom in and out to experience multiple perspectives on the work.
2016-08-23.headline_main: When 6,000 Cocktail Umbrellas Become Art

2016-08-23.abstract: All the Priebus that’s fit to print.
2016-08-23.snippet: All the Priebus that’s fit to print.
2016-08-23.lead_paragraph: Regular readers of this magazine might detect a curious institutional man-crush on Reince Priebus, the embattled but indefatigably upbeat chairman of the Republican National Committee. O.K., guilty. You, and I, first encountered Priebus earlier this spring, when I was reporting an article on how Donald Trump’s political ascendancy had put the Republican Party’s responsible adults in a, well, interesting spot. Over the course of our regular interviews, Priebus was a surprisingly good sport about the whole thing — enough so that we’ve decided to initiate a new feature, Tuesdays With Reince, a semiregular encounter-session with the head of the fracturing party of Lincoln, to provide our readers with the full-spectrum Priebus coverage they have been clamoring for.
2016-08-23.headline_main: Tuesdays with Reince, Episode 1: ‘I Take My Health One Day at a Time’

2016-08-23.abstract: Bill Janu is white and a police detective. Shanna Janu is black and a lawyer. Their infant son is coming of age in a new time of racial turmoil.
2016-08-23.snippet: Bill Janu is white and a police detective. Shanna Janu is black and a lawyer. Their infant son is coming of age in a new time of racial turmoil.
2016-08-23.lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — He assembled the crib and mounted the bookshelves. She unpacked the bedding and filled the closet with onesies and rompers. Then husband and wife stood in the nursery and worried. Bill Janu, a police officer, is white. Shanna Janu, a lawyer, is black. As they eagerly awaited their baby’s birth this spring, they felt increasingly anxious.
2016-08-23.headline_main: ‘I Have a Black Son in Baltimore’: Anxious New Parents and an Era of Unease

2016-08-23.abstract: The popular Italian TV series about the inner workings of organized crime makes its American debut on SundanceTV on Wednesday.
2016-08-23.snippet: The popular Italian TV series about the inner workings of organized crime makes its American debut on SundanceTV on Wednesday.
2016-08-23.lead_paragraph: A pair of Mafia lieutenants, filling a jerry can at a Naples gas station, pass the time discussing the foibles of modern youth. “She put a picture of me and her mom on ‘book,’” the older one says. “Facebook,” his younger colleague tells him. “All the kids have it.” Gangsters — they’re just like us!

2016-08-23.lead_paragraph: More than the staggeringly self-absorbed British pop star, the wistful giant, the Greeks bickering inside the Trojan horse or the baby floating in utero, the glowworms got me.

2016-08-23.abstract: State wildlife officials suspended recreation along almost 200 miles of the Yellowstone River last week to prevent a parasite from spreading.
2016-08-23.snippet: State wildlife officials suspended recreation along almost 200 miles of the Yellowstone River last week to prevent a parasite from spreading.
2016-08-23.lead_paragraph: LIVINGSTON, Mont. — The Yellowstone River, flowing in ribbons beneath the towering Absaroka mountains and through this small town, is usually flecked with drifting boats and rafts, sport fishermen and children jumping off bridges. But now the river, one of Montana’s premier fly-fishing destinations, is empty as wildlife officials and scientists race to contain the spread of a microscopic invader, a parasite that is deadly to fish.
2016-08-23.headline_main: Tiny Invader, Deadly to Fish, Shuts Down a River in Montana

2016-08-23.headline_main: Trying to Turn Back the Clock on Deals Gone Sour

2016-08-23.lead_paragraph: Natural disasters that were once anomalous are becoming almost commonplace, and the country is clearly not prepared for them. Historic floods in Louisiana displaced thousands and led to the deaths of 17 people this month. Record-setting rain devastated parts of West Virginia in June and South Carolina in October.
2016-08-23.headline_main: After Louisiana, Preparing for the Next Storm

She was 87.

2016-08-24.abstract: A playful debut by Matthew Sewell.
2016-08-24.snippet: A playful debut by Matthew Sewell.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — In 1979, Daniel Okrent, a former public editor for The New York Times and fellow crossword enthusiast, invented Rotisserie League Baseball, one of the best known of the fantasy sports leagues. He’s also been the managing editor of Life magazine and one of his books, “Great Fortune: The Epic of Rockefeller Center” was a finalist for a Pulitzer Prize. But what he is primarily known for is a game where baseball fans can draft the lineup of their fantasies and then play “baseball.” On paper.
2016-08-24.headline_main: Field of DraftKings and FanDuel

2016-08-24.abstract: A show at the Pompidou Center in Paris, “Beat Generation: New York, San Francisco, Paris,” is the first major retrospective on the Beats since the 1990s.
2016-08-24.snippet: A show at the Pompidou Center in Paris, “Beat Generation: New York, San Francisco, Paris,” is the first major retrospective on the Beats since the 1990s.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Visitors to the Pompidou Center this summer are greeted with a vitrine that stretches uninterrupted before them for 120 linear feet. Unspooled inside it is the 1951 typescript of Jack Kerouac’s “On the Road,” page after page of tracing paper taped together to form a single continuous sheet, the defining road novel of its time laid out before them like so much two-lane blacktop. “That river of words,” mused Jean-Jacques Lebel, an artist and onetime associate of the Beats who helped organize the museum show this manuscript introduces. “That Mississippi of words.”
2016-08-24.headline_main: The Beats’ Countercultural Ferment Still Bubbles, in Paris

2016-08-24.headline_main: North Korea Test-Fires Missile From Submarine

2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: If law enforcement officials wanted to stage a mock terrorist attack to test security at New York City’s Kennedy International Airport, they couldn’t have planned it better than what actually happened on Aug. 14. That Sunday evening passengers at the huge network of terminals suddenly began hearing noises, followed shortly by reports — false, it turned out — of gunfire.

2016-08-24.abstract: As regulation and safety oversight remain lax, prosecutors bring charges in crimes that couldn’t have occurred if the government had done its job.

2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: The latest criminal charges of public officials in the contamination of the Flint, Mich., water supply seem righteous. After so much government ineptitude with such hideous consequences — tens of thousands of Flint residents poisoned; elevated blood lead levels in nearly 5 percent of the city’s children, many with possibly irreversible brain damage — surely these criminal charges will bring, at long last, justice for Flint.

2016-08-24.snippet: Syrian rebels, aided by Turkish tanks, planes and special forces, said they had taken control of Jarabulus, the last major Islamic State redoubt near Turkey’s border.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: ISTANBUL — Turkey sent tanks, warplanes and special operations forces into northern Syria on Wednesday in its biggest plunge yet into the Syrian conflict, enabling Syrian rebels to take control of an important Islamic State stronghold within hours.

2016-08-24.abstract: The social entrepreneur on the benefits of bipartisan collaboration, the anxieties of each voter base and why policy wonks are often sci-fi nerds.
2016-08-24.snippet: The social entrepreneur on the benefits of bipartisan collaboration, the anxieties of each voter base and why policy wonks are often sci-fi nerds.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: It seems as if what you’re best known for, at least in pop culture, is being the guy Glenn Beck hounded out of the White House, and also for owning Jeffrey Lord on CNN. What would you like to be known for? I’m a serial, successful social entrepreneur. I don’t spend a lot of time worrying about being known for something. I spend a lot of time trying to solve problems.
2016-08-24.headline_main: Van Jones Can Empathize With Trump Voters

2016-08-24.abstract: How a strange new class of media outlet has arisen to take over our news feeds.
2016-08-24.snippet: How a strange new class of media outlet has arisen to take over our news feeds.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: Open your Facebook feed. What do you see? A photo of a close friend’s child. An automatically generated slide show commemorating six years of friendship between two acquaintances. An eerily on-target ad for something you’ve been meaning to buy. A funny video. A sad video. A recently live video. Lots of video; more video than you remember from before. A somewhat less-on-target ad. Someone you saw yesterday feeling blessed. Someone you haven’t seen in 10 years feeling worried.
2016-08-24.headline_main: Inside Facebook’s (Totally Insane, Unintentionally Gigantic, Hyperpartisan) Political-Media Machine

They tried to scale the fence, scattering only when he raised and cocked his gun.
2016-08-24.headline_main: ‘No One Is Safe’: Zimbabwe Threatens to Seize Farms of Party Defectors

He apparently vowed revenge, eventually carrying out a plan to fund lawsuits against Gawker Media, the publisher that upset him, culminating this week with the shuttering of the flagship Gawker.com.

2016-08-24.abstract: Sea, sand, history and climate forecasts are all part of a trip to the Dry Tortugas, an aquatic paradise at the edge of the Gulf of Mexico.
2016-08-24.snippet: Sea, sand, history and climate forecasts are all part of a trip to the Dry Tortugas, an aquatic paradise at the edge of the Gulf of Mexico.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: As the seaplane soared more than 1,000 feet in the air, I scoured the crystalline waters below, hoping for a glimpse of dolphin squadrons, manatees, perhaps sharks. They might be visible even at this altitude, I’d been told. I saw none. Yet among several seemingly motionless sailboats, a shadowy yet distinct shape stood out. It was the shipwreck of the Arbutus, a treasure-hunting vessel that sank in 1983. The haunting, rather morose, image was set against an otherwise celestial landscape.
2016-08-24.headline_main: West of Key West, an Under-the-Radar National Park

2016-08-24.abstract: On a volcano’s flanks, a serene world apart that’s green and, occasionally, a fiery red.
2016-08-24.snippet: On a volcano’s flanks, a serene world apart that’s green and, occasionally, a fiery red.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: In the summer, Sicily is the color of flax. The valleys, the hillsides, the horizon all bear the same overexposed quality, the burned-out yellow of haystacks. But if you fly into Palermo and head east by car, the hues slowly start to change, getting deeper and greener with altitude. Roll down the windows and, as you approach the mountain, the oppressive heat of the island’s parched interior gives way to the shady, dank feeling of a forest. And once you see foreboding black rocks dotting the landscape of ominous volcanic soil, you will know you have arrived.
2016-08-24.headline_main: Sicily’s Mount Etna, an Island Within an Island

2016-08-24.abstract: One of the growing pains of Malaysia’s economic prosperity is that its capital’s traffic problem is reaching critical mass.
2016-08-24.snippet: One of the growing pains of Malaysia’s economic prosperity is that its capital’s traffic problem is reaching critical mass.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: The ostrich is as tall as the cars around it, and running at a fair pace in the fast lane of the Federal Highway, which links Kuala Lumpur’s city center to Petaling Jaya, its largest satellite town. As the video of the surreal incident — the result of a tame ostrich’s escaping from captivity — circulated on social media in June, what struck many observers was that the giant bird was able to run so freely along the busiest of the capital’s many traffic-clogged highways. An hour or two later and the adventurous ostrich would have been hemmed in by gridlocked traffic, just like the rest of us.
2016-08-24.headline_main: Gridlock Comes to Kuala Lumpur

2016-08-24.abstract: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
2016-08-24.snippet: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: Early this year, a Facebook user in Baghdad using the name Hussein Mahyawi posted a photograph of a slightly worn M4 assault rifle he was offering for sale. Veterans of the latest war in Iraq immediately recognized it. It was a standard American carbine equipped with a holographic sight, a foregrip that was military-issue during the occupation and a sticker bearing a digital QR code used by American forces for inventory control. Except for one detail — an aftermarket pistol grip, the sort of accessory with which combatants of the current generation often pimp their guns — it was a dead ringer for any of the tens of thousands of M4s the Pentagon handed out to Iraqi security forces and various armed militias after toppling Saddam Hussein in 2003. And here it was on the open market, ready for bids.
2016-08-24.headline_main: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.

2016-08-24.abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on when going along with your spouse is a gross deception, whether a child should know the real cause of his father’s death and when paying back a debt creates a greater burden than it lifts.
2016-08-24.snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on when going along with your spouse is a gross deception, whether a child should know the real cause of his father’s death and when paying back a debt creates a greater burden than it lifts.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: My wife and are I childless. We can’t have children of our own, and in any case, I have never wanted children. Now we are in our 40s, and my wife is starting the process of adoption. She is very well aware that I do not want to adopt a child, but to keep the peace in our relationship, I go along, under protest. I drag out every task required of me (writing application essays, for instance) for as long as I can, hoping either to change my mind (not happening yet) or to change hers (not happening either). This is putting a big strain on our friendship, as I feel she is pushing something on me that I don’t want. I also understand that I take away something from her that she really longs for — to be a mother.
2016-08-24.headline_main: My Wife Wants to Adopt. When Do I Tell Her I Won’t?

2016-08-24.abstract: As foreign minister and deputy chancellor under Willy Brandt, Mr. Scheel fostered closer ties with Communist East Germany.
2016-08-24.snippet: As foreign minister and deputy chancellor under Willy Brandt, Mr. Scheel fostered closer ties with Communist East Germany.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: Walter Scheel, who as foreign minister and deputy chancellor of West Germany under Chancellor Willy Brandt from 1969 to 1974 helped foster détente with the Soviet bloc and rapprochement with Communist East Germany, died on Wednesday in Bad Krozingen, in southwest Germany. He was 97.
2016-08-24.headline_main: Walter Scheel, Leading Figure in West German Thaw With the East, Dies at 97

2016-08-24.snippet: A shallow fault and the presence of centuries-old, unreinforced masonry buildings combined to produce widespread, deadly destruction.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: The combination of a shallow fault and old, unreinforced masonry buildings led to widespread devastation in the earthquake that struck central Italy early Wednesday.

2016-08-24.abstract: Aheda Zanetti, who created the full-body swimsuit, said her invention was about “freedom and happiness.”
2016-08-24.snippet: Aheda Zanetti, who created the full-body swimsuit, said her invention was about “freedom and happiness.”
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The woman credited with creating  the so-called burkini said the controversy over efforts to ban the full-body bathing suit worn by some Muslim women has helped bolster demand for her invention, which she said was not meant to be a political statement.

2016-08-24.abstract: The project is a collaboration among the choreographer Jonathan Burrows, the composer Matteo Fargion and the video artist Hugo Glendinning.
2016-08-24.snippet: The project is a collaboration among the choreographer Jonathan Burrows, the composer Matteo Fargion and the video artist Hugo Glendinning.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: It can be hard to articulate all that goes into becoming and being a dancer, but the project known as 52 Portraits does so on a refreshingly human scale, without oversimplifying. A collaboration among the choreographer Jonathan Burrows, the composer Matteo Fargion and the video artist Hugo Glendinning, the digital series, produced by Sadler’s Wells in London, captures the thoughts and histories of its subjects through short autobiographical solos, one released every Monday of 2016.
2016-08-24.headline_main: At 52 Portraits, the Stories Behind the Dancers

2016-08-24.abstract: In 1903 Teddy Roosevelt dropped politics and took a hike. One result was the National Park system.
2016-08-24.snippet: In 1903 Teddy Roosevelt dropped politics and took a hike. One result was the National Park system.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: Somewhere not far from any American, it’s possible to visit one of this country’s most remarkable assets – its national parks. And from August 25 to 28, as part of this year’s celebration of the 100th year of the National Park System, you can do so free of charge. Of the 400-plus parks in the system, 124 normally charge an entrance fee. You can find the nearest park here.
2016-08-24.headline_main: Time to Follow Teddy Roosevelt’s Advice: ‘Drop Politics’ and Enjoy a Park

2016-08-24.abstract: “Eat the World With Emeril Lagasse,” a six-episode Amazon series, debuts on Friday.
2016-08-24.snippet: “Eat the World With Emeril Lagasse,” a six-episode Amazon series, debuts on Friday.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: How does a chef divine the connection between food and place? He asks another chef, naturally. In “Eat the World With Emeril Lagasse,” a six-episode Amazon series that begins Friday, Sept. 2, Mr. Lagasse (of Food Network fame) nibbles his way around the globe with guidance from some well-traveled colleagues. In China, Mario Batali joins him on a quest for the best dumpling soup. In Sweden, the teacher is Marcus Samuelsson, and the lesson is New Nordic cuisine. Danny Bowien provides an introduction to Jeong Kwan, a Zen Buddhist nun in South Korea known as the Philosopher Chef. And José Andrés takes Mr. Lagasse to Barcelona, where the modernist genius Ferran Adrià and his army of thinkers dissect food down to the molecule. It might be Amazon’s answer to Netflix’s “Chef’s Table,” with enough food porn and zesty banter to keep viewers aroused. But fears of a loud American prowling the globe should be laid to rest: Not a single “bam!” resounded in the two episodes I watched.
2016-08-24.headline_main: Emeril Lagasse Takes Bite-Size Steps Across the World

2016-08-24.abstract: “Women of Abstract Expressionism” at the Denver Art Museum brings together the work of 12 artists from the 1940s and ’50s.
2016-08-24.snippet: “Women of Abstract Expressionism” at the Denver Art Museum brings together the work of 12 artists from the 1940s and ’50s.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: Abstract Expressionism is usually treated as a boys-club affair. But it wasn’t, as an exhibition called “Women of Abstract Expressionism” at the Denver Art Museum proves. Not that entry for women was easy. Of the 12 artists in the show, only a few, like Helen Frankenthaler and, to some degree, Grace Hartigan, got to take an early turn in the mainstream spotlight before being shouldered out by men. Others, like Jay DeFeo and Lee Krasner, had to wait years for attention, which came after they died. Many other artists — Mary Abbott, Sonia Gechtoff and Judith Godwin among them — are waiting still.
2016-08-24.headline_main: The Women Who Helped Create Abstract Expressionism

2016-08-24.abstract: This singer-songwriter from Birmingham, England, is part of the Afropunk Fest.
2016-08-24.snippet: This singer-songwriter from Birmingham, England, is part of the Afropunk Fest.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: “I can only be who I am,” Laura Mvula sings on the opening track of her stunning second album, “The Dreaming Room” (Columbia). The track, “Who I Am,” lyrically consists of just four short lines, leading irresistibly to this assertion. Ms. Mvula means for the message to stick.
2016-08-24.headline_main: Laura Mvula Sings the Complicated Truth

2016-08-24.abstract: Chiara will present the composer’s complete string quartets at National Sawdust, from memory.
2016-08-24.snippet: Chiara will present the composer’s complete string quartets at National Sawdust, from memory.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: “By heart” is a funny term when you think about it. After all, the act of memorization is done by the head. But the members of the Chiara String Quartet, who have made it their mission to perform without sheet music in front of them, say something special happens in the act of internalizing an entire quartet; connections deepen — with the music, with fellow players and with the audience.
2016-08-24.headline_main: Bartok, by Heart, From the Chiara String Quartet

2016-08-24.abstract: This 1992 movie was adapted from E. M. Forster’s 1910 novel about upper-middle-class British life at the turn of the century.
2016-08-24.snippet: This 1992 movie was adapted from E. M. Forster’s 1910 novel about upper-middle-class British life at the turn of the century.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: “Howards End,” the 1992 movie adapted from E. M. Forster’s 1910 novel about upper-middle-class British life at the turn of the century, was the artistic pinnacle of what became known as the Merchant-Ivory brand. With a cast featuring Emma Thompson, Helena Bonham Carter, Vanessa Redgrave and Anthony Hopkins, this third adaptation of a Forster novel made by Ismail Merchant (producer), James Ivory (director) and Ruth Prawer Jhabvala (screenwriter) received nine Academy Award nods. (Ms. Thompson won for best actress.)
2016-08-24.headline_main: Before ‘Downton,’ There Was ‘Howards End.’ See It at Film Forum.

2016-08-24.abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: An explosion in a colliery near Merfhyr, Wales, kills 2 in August 1891.
2016-08-24.snippet: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: An explosion in a colliery near Merfhyr, Wales, kills 2 in August 1891.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: LONDON — About 2.30 yesterday afternoon, a terrific explosion occurred in the Abercanaid pit, belonging to Hill’s Plymouth Company, near Merfhyr. The detonation was so great as to alarm the whole neighborhood, and people rushed to the pit’s mouth. There were between fifty and sixty men in the pit at the time, and fears were entertained lest the whole had perished. Events, however, proved that excepting two men all were safe. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 25, 1891
2016-08-24.headline_main: 1891: Terrible Colliery Explosion

2016-08-24.abstract: Angel Olsen leaves her comfort zone in her new album, “My Woman.”
2016-08-24.snippet: Angel Olsen leaves her comfort zone in her new album, “My Woman.”
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: Angel Olsen’s third full-length album, “My Woman,” out next week, may raise the eyebrows of fans expecting the singer-songwriter’s trademark earthy, folky sound. In the video for “Intern,” the opening track, which Olsen directed herself, she wears a silver tinsel wig, her voice floating and trembling over a blazing synth line. “I like pushing myself,” says the 29-year-old. When she leaves her comfort zone in songwriting, she explains, “my voice does things other than it normally would. I hold back on something because it goes better with the song.” On the album, she explores the contradictions of a relationship and the process of breaking down ideals: “I dare you to understand / What makes me a woman.”
2016-08-24.headline_main: A Singer-Songwriter’s New Sound — and Tinsel Wig to Match

2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: The archive of Charles M. Conlon, a photographer who captured some of the giants of baseball’s golden years, will be auctioned Saturday. 2016-08-24.abstract: Under pressure to connect with new audiences, orchestras are employing new tactics, such as forgoing Tchaikovsky for hits by Beyoncé. But at what price?
2016-08-24.snippet: Under pressure to connect with new audiences, orchestras are employing new tactics, such as forgoing Tchaikovsky for hits by Beyoncé. But at what price?
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: Tchaikovsky’s bombastic “1812 Overture” has been a staple of the Boston Pops’ Fourth of July concert since 1974, when the famed Pops conductor Arthur Fiedler added it — complete with cannon blasts and church bells — to lift attendance. It became the traditional lead-in to the fireworks display over the Charles River.
2016-08-24.headline_main: What’s Lost When Pops Orchestras Tap Pop Culture

2016-08-24.abstract: Random House said that it has acquired a book of personal essays from Mr. Odenkirk; he says it will be a sort of “comic ‘bildungsroman.’”
2016-08-24.snippet: Random House said that it has acquired a book of personal essays from Mr. Odenkirk; he says it will be a sort of “comic ‘bildungsroman.’”
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: In his ever-evolving show-business career, Bob Odenkirk has been a sketch-comedy star and a leading man of drama; a very bad lawyer and also that same lawyer making all the choices that would send him down that corrupt path. Now he can add memoirist to his résumé: Random House said on Wednesday that it had acquired a book of personal essays from Mr. Odenkirk that the publisher described as “a comic exploration” of his life and work. The book will trace Mr. Odenkirk’s trajectory from Second City in Chicago to “Saturday Night Live,” “The Ben Stiller Show” and “Mr. Show With Bob and David,” as well as his role as Jimmy McGill (a.k.a. Saul Goodman) on the AMC crime drama “Breaking Bad” and the prequel series “Better Call Saul.”
2016-08-24.headline_main: Bob Odenkirk to Write Comic Memoir

2016-08-24.abstract: The gallerist and flower and scent designer Eric Buterbaugh has created a site-specific installation with the designer Chuck Moffit.
2016-08-24.snippet: The gallerist and flower and scent designer Eric Buterbaugh has created a site-specific installation with the designer Chuck Moffit.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: In the midst of Los Angeles’s enduring drought, a meadow — albeit one forged from bronze and blackened steel — grows in West Hollywood. At his eponymous gallery on Thursday, Eric Buterbaugh opens “Chuck Moffit: With the Promise of Nectar,” a collaborative installation that, in true L.A. fashion, is a crossover of genres. In an unlikely pairing, the gallerist-cum-flower-and-scent designer is creating a site-specific installation of purple dahlias and custom scents in response to a new collection of Moffit’s sculptural furniture, which he made by hand in his lone studio on the high-altitude slopes of Mount Baldy.
2016-08-24.headline_main: In One L.A. Gallery, Flowers and Furniture Combine

2016-08-24.abstract: Asafumi Yamashita is the designated grower for four Michelin-starred kitchens in Paris, but he never imagined he would cultivate produce for a living.
2016-08-24.snippet: Asafumi Yamashita is the designated grower for four Michelin-starred kitchens in Paris, but he never imagined he would cultivate produce for a living.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: Asafumi Yamashita never imagined he would cultivate produce for a living. He was an expert in the Japanese tradition of bonsai when he moved from Tokyo to Paris almost 30 years ago. Asked by a chef to grow vegetables unavailable in local markets, he went back to Japan to look for seeds: “The quality there makes them more potent and reliable,” he says. But it’s his careful tending that has made him the designated grower for four Michelin-starred restaurants in Paris, including L’Astrance and Le Cinq. “I know each of my crops because I listen to them,” he explains. “Some years, my turnips decide to taste like pears, some years they taste like parsnips.” Yamashita is a key player in a revolution in French cuisine, what he describes as “taking the vegetable away from its role as a side and making it the key element on the plate.” But not just anyone is worthy of his produce; he handpicks the chefs he supplies to be sure they respect his offerings. “Giving my vegetables away is like marrying off my daughter.”
2016-08-24.headline_main: The Japanese Vegetable Whisperer Behind Great French Restaurants

2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: When N. K. Jemisin was halfway through writing her fantasy novel “The Fifth Season,” she called her editor in a panic and said she couldn’t finish. Ms. Jemisin felt the story — which unfolds in a world where mutants who can control seismic energy are feared and oppressed — was too painful to write, given the uncomfortable parallels to persistent racial injustice in the real world.

2016-08-24.snippet: “Glory,” Ms. Spears’s ninth studio album, is her latest attempt to reclaim her place on the pop charts.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: Britney Spears strives mightily to be one-dimensional on “Glory,” her ninth studio album. But Ms. Spears has plenty of back story; she’s a 34-year-old working mother, the headliner in her own Las Vegas spectacle and a performer who has weathered teenage fame, backlash, public meltdowns and wave after wave of tabloid headlines. “Glory,” her first album since 2013, is her latest attempt to reclaim her place on the pop charts, which are now crowded with younger performers who have studied her the way Ms. Spears studied Madonna. Her latest strategy is relentless and unambiguous: Stick to sexy.
2016-08-24.headline_main: In ‘Glory,’ Britney Spears Promises Pleasure, but Offers Nothing Personal

2016-08-24.abstract: Luke Dittrich’s book examines the case of Henry Molaison, who, after a brain operation, was almost unable to form memories. His surgeon was Mr. Dittrich’s grandfather.
2016-08-24.snippet: Luke Dittrich’s book examines the case of Henry Molaison, who, after a brain operation, was almost unable to form memories. His surgeon was Mr. Dittrich’s grandfather.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: For nearly six decades, Henry Molaison was known only by his initials, H.M., a brutally fitting detail for a man whose identity had more or less been erased. On Aug. 25, 1953, a surgeon drilled two holes in his forehead, pried up his frontal lobes with a flat brain spatula and suctioned out several elegantly shaped structures — they looked like hooks, almonds, seahorses — in an effort to subdue an ungovernable case of epilepsy.
2016-08-24.headline_main: ‘Patient H.M.’ Recalls the Story of a Surgery That Took a Man’s Memories

At 185 Greenwich Street.

2016-08-24.abstract: It’s too easy to forget that this is a stunning but shaky land.
2016-08-24.snippet: It’s too easy to forget that this is a stunning but shaky land.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: Milan — If you put a pin right in the middle of a map of Italy, you’re likely to hit Amatrice. A small, historic city known as “the town of the hundred churches,” it lies two hours from Rome and 3,280 feet above sea level, in the scenic Gran Sasso National Park, on the watershed between the Adriatic and the Tyrrhenian Seas. The area straddles four of our most famous regions: Lazio, Abruzzo, Marche and Umbria. Amatrice is the centerpiece of picture-postcard Italy, for those who find Tuscany too obvious, Rome too noisy and Venice too crowded.
2016-08-24.headline_main: Italy’s Fragile Beauty

2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: Colombia’s government and the largest rebel group in the country have reached a deal to end more than 50 years of conflict, the two sides announced Wednesday, paving the way for an end to the longest-running war in the Americas.

2016-08-24.abstract: Heather Bresch, the chief executive of Mylan, which raised the price of EpiPens, is the daughter of Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia.
2016-08-24.snippet: Heather Bresch, the chief executive of Mylan, which raised the price of EpiPens, is the daughter of Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A bipartisan group of senators pressing on Wednesday for an explanation of the skyrocketing cost of the EpiPen, a lifesaving injection device for those with severe allergies, found themselves directing their outrage toward an inconvenient target: the daughter of Senator Joe Manchin III.
2016-08-24.headline_main: Awkward Target for Outrage Over EpiPen: A Senator’s Daughter

2016-08-24.abstract: Inspired by a trip to the children’s room of the New York Public Library, the filmmaker sought to preserve the books’ lush illustrations when animating them.
2016-08-24.snippet: Inspired by a trip to the children’s room of the New York Public Library, the filmmaker sought to preserve the books’ lush illustrations when animating them.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: Morton Schindel, who turned beloved children’s books into animated films narrated by actors like Meryl Streep and James Earl Jones while preserving the spirit of the original illustrations, died on Saturday at his home in Weston, Conn. He was 98.
2016-08-24.headline_main: Morton Schindel, Who Turned Children’s Books Into Animated Films, Dies at 98

2016-08-24.abstract: The Fed is trying to find its footing in an era whose challenge is not the strength of inflation, but the weakness of economic growth.
2016-08-24.snippet: The Fed is trying to find its footing in an era whose challenge is not the strength of inflation, but the weakness of economic growth.
2016-08-24.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When a dozen protesters in green T-shirts showed up two years ago at the Federal Reserve’s annual conference in Jackson Hole, Wyo., they were regarded by many participants as an amusing addition.
2016-08-24.headline_main: Fed, Eager to Show It’s Listening, Welcomes Protesters

2016-08-25.snippet: Graduate students who work as teaching and research assistants finally have the right to unionize at private universities.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: In a corrective action more than a decade in the making, the National Labor Relations Board ruled on Tuesday that graduate students who work as teaching and research assistants at private universities have the right to unionize.

2016-08-25.snippet: A hospital worker said that the man, Peter A. Kaisen, of Islip, was denied emergency-room service, a claim the hospital disputes.

2016-08-25.abstract: Mylan’s price increases for the allergy treatment device highlight a common tactic in the industry: raising prices just before a generic competitor reaches the market.
2016-08-25.snippet: Mylan’s price increases for the allergy treatment device highlight a common tactic in the industry: raising prices just before a generic competitor reaches the market.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: In 2012, the company behind the EpiPen settled a lawsuit by agreeing to allow a generic competitor into the market in 2015, potentially cutting into a big part of its business.
2016-08-25.headline_main: Mylan Raised EpiPen’s Price Before the Expected Arrival of a Generic

2016-08-25.abstract: At a rally against a state law allowing concealed handguns on campuses, protesters wave sex toys and say they consider the move obscene.
2016-08-25.snippet: At a rally against a state law allowing concealed handguns on campuses, protesters wave sex toys and say they consider the move obscene.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — On the first day of classes at the University of Texas in this city that revels in its own oddball creativity, students protested a law allowing concealed handguns on state college campuses by carrying something they thought was just as ridiculous and out of place: Thousands of sex toys.
2016-08-25.headline_main: University of Texas Students Find the Absurd in a New Gun Law

2016-08-25.abstract: My Sioux tribe opposes a pipeline that risks the clean water of millions.
2016-08-25.snippet: My Sioux tribe opposes a pipeline that risks the clean water of millions.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: Near Cannon Ball, N.D. — It is a spectacular sight: thousands of Indians camped on the banks of the Cannonball River, on the edge of the Standing Rock Sioux Reservation in North Dakota. Our elders of the Seven Council Fires, as the Oceti Sakowin, or Great Sioux Nation, is known, sit in deliberation and prayer, awaiting a federal court decision on whether construction of a $3.7 billion oil pipeline from the Bakken region to Southern Illinois will be halted.
2016-08-25.headline_main: Taking a Stand at Standing Rock

2016-08-25.abstract: The six-month ban for Solo, 35, was her second from the national team in the last two years, and but the termination of her contract could signal the end of her international career.
2016-08-25.snippet: The six-month ban for Solo, 35, was her second from the national team in the last two years, and but the termination of her contract could signal the end of her international career.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: U.S. Soccer terminated the contract of goalkeeper Hope Solo on Wednesday for what it called “conduct that is counter to the organization’s principles.” The federation also said it had suspended Solo from the women’s national team for six months, but in ending her contract, it sent a strong signal that Solo — who has balanced on-field excellence with off-field controversy for more than a decade — might have played her last game for the United States.
2016-08-25.headline_main: U.S. Soccer Suspends Hope Solo and Terminates Her Contract

2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was a frenetic Monday afternoon at Abs Hospital in northern Yemen, with doctors and nurses busily shuttling among the patients and a maternity ward filled with 25 women expecting to give birth.

Calls from onlookers to “go back to where you came from.” Public humiliation and ostracism with echoes of the morals police of theocratic countries like Iran or Saudi Arabia, not a country that sees its values as a paragon of Western freedoms.

Trump has begun to recast his political message in more structured terms and wrestle with his temptation to go off script, as his campaign seeks to revive his fading candidacy and turn the focus this fall to Hillary Clinton’s honesty and integrity.

Mara on Wednesday defended the team’s decision to re-sign kicker Josh Brown despite Brown’s 2015 arrest on a domestic violence charge and a statement by Brown’s former wife to the police that he had been physically violent with her on numerous occasions.

A ragged place surrounded by natural beauty, it’s not much more than a row of houses on a single street, so self-contained that you don’t have to be from far off to be “not from ’round here.” Outsiders are dubiously regarded.

2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: The most striking thing in this week’s episode of “Mr. Robot” wasn’t in this week’s episode of “Mr. Robot.” It’s Elliot Alderson, the mentally ill mastermind behind the hacker collective fsociety’s rapidly disintegrating plan to level the world’s economic playing field. For the first time in the history of the series, Elliot — and Rami Malek, the wide-eyed actor whom the role has made a star — did not appear.

2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: Andy Bragen raced to the net, hoping to capture a key point in the tight third-set tiebreaker. The results, initially at least, were calamitous. Losing the point was awful, but even worse for Bragen was the knowledge that Alhadeff was about to let loose with a self-congratulatory yell.

2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: It is haunting, maddening even, to revisit the facts of Abu Zubaydah’s time in American custody more than 14 years after he was detained in Pakistan in the frenzied period following the Sept. 11 attacks. Abu Zubaydah, the first prisoner known to have been waterboarded by the Central Intelligence Agency, loomed large in America’s imagination for years as the personification of evil.

2016-08-25.abstract: Steroid injections for tennis elbow may turn out to do more harm than good.
2016-08-25.snippet: Steroid injections for tennis elbow may turn out to do more harm than good.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: Tennis elbow is not exclusive to tennis players; anyone who frequently twists an arm or carries a heavy briefcase can develop it. But whoever they may be, sufferers of the condition in the past 10 years have generally been offered a cortisone shot as treatment. Recent surveys in the United States and Britain show that injections of the steroid, which rapidly dulls pain and fights inflammation, are the preferred first line of treatment among many orthopedic specialists. But growing evidence suggests that the injections, while effective in the short term, can frequently worsen the condition in the months that follow, raising interesting questions about the risks of quick fixes for pain.
2016-08-25.headline_main: For Tennis Elbow, No Such Thing as a Quick Fix

2016-08-25.snippet: Want a memorable meal while traveling? Dine like a resident by asking locals for suggestions, and try appetizers instead of entrees.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: Enjoying good food is an essential part of any vacation — at least according to David McInerney, the co-founder of the New York City-based grocery delivery service FreshDirect, who spends most of his time traveling the world sourcing food for the company. The way to savor memorable cuisine, he said, is to skip fancy restaurants and eat as the locals do. “You’ll get the best meals by eating the way the people do who live in the destination you’re visiting,” he said. Here, he shares advice on how to do just that:

2016-08-25.abstract: The same tangy, creamy, turbocharged flavor of the bottled stuff, sans animal fat.
2016-08-25.snippet: The same tangy, creamy, turbocharged flavor of the bottled stuff, sans animal fat.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: Flashback to the mid-1950s: A dude-ranch owner in Southern California whisks buttermilk and mayonnaise with herbs and spices. Later known as ranch dressing, it appears to make perfectly reasonable people lose their minds. The man tries to keep up with his dressing’s popularity, to harness its power, but in the end, he sells it to a corporation. Subjected to a series of experiments, ranch is transformed into a glorious shelf-stable beast, designed to be better, stronger and able to survive longer outside the fridge.
2016-08-25.headline_main: A Vegan Ranch Dressing That Rivals the Original

2016-08-25.abstract: He might be the most entertaining tennis player since John McEnroe. Too bad he’d rather be playing basketball.
2016-08-25.snippet: He might be the most entertaining tennis player since John McEnroe. Too bad he’d rather be playing basketball.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: It was just before noon on a swampy July morning when Nick Kyrgios came walking through the parking lot of the Evert Tennis Academy in Boca Raton, Fla., on his way to practice. He wore black shorts and a black basketball jersey, and his haircut straddled the line between a faux-hawk and a fade; a racket bag was slung over his shoulders, and his eyes were fixed on two smartphones, one in each hand. Kyrgios, a 21-year-old Australian of Greek and Malaysian descent — and quite possibly the most gifted tennis player to come along since Roger Federer — was accompanied by an improbable crew: a 13-year-old from Philadelphia named Tauheed Browning and a 14-year-old from Maryland named Langston Williams, two promising juniors who were training at the academy. They had bonded with Kyrgios over a shared infatuation with Pokémon GO, the blockbuster mobile game, and the three were apparently now inseparable. They had gone to the movies and the mall together.
2016-08-25.headline_main: The Electric, Infuriating Nick Kyrgios

2016-08-25.abstract: Too many? Not enough? Not newsy enough? Finding the right volume, mix and audience is a juggling act.
2016-08-25.snippet: Too many? Not enough? Not newsy enough? Finding the right volume, mix and audience is a juggling act.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: News alerts and push notifications regularly draw questions from readers. So I sat down with Eric Bishop and Michael Owen from the news desk at The Times to answer some of my questions — and hopefully yours — about how the newsroom approaches this area. Last month, The Times announced it was dividing its email alerts into two channels: Breaking News gives readers developing stories as they happen; and Top Stories gives subscribers breaking news plus special reports, investigative stories or live events in sports or politics if The Times deems them important. Soon, subscribers to mobile push notifications will get the same choice.
2016-08-25.headline_main: Why’d You Do That? How The Times Decides to Send News Alerts

2016-08-25.abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: In August 1966, Apollo soars from Cape Kennedy.
2016-08-25.snippet: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: In August 1966, Apollo soars from Cape Kennedy.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: CAPE KENNEDY — The United States today [Aug. 25] rocketed an unmanned Apollo moon ship three-quarters of the way around the world to a Pacific Ocean splash down. The 44,700-pound Apollo rode atop a powerful Saturn-1 rocket that landed 93 minutes after leaving here. The Apollo zoomed to a peak altitude of 700 miles over South Africa. Then its own rocket engine fired to drive it back, heat shield first, into the earth’s atmosphere at 19,000 miles per hour. Apollo control reported the 11,000-pound capsule impacted south-west of the aircraft carrier Hornet, the prime recovery ship, some 300 miles southeast of Wake Island.— New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 26, 1966
2016-08-25.headline_main: 1966: Apollo Soars From Cape

2016-08-25.abstract: Mr. McCombs’s new album, “Mangy Love,” by turns lofty, cryptic and mystical, reaffirms him as one of the great songwriters of his time.
2016-08-25.snippet: Mr. McCombs’s new album, “Mangy Love,” by turns lofty, cryptic and mystical, reaffirms him as one of the great songwriters of his time.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: Cass McCombs’s words are a black hole. “It is not wealth to have more than others,” this 38-year-old singer-songwriter intones on “It,” a serene and unsettling ballad from his new album, “Mangy Love.” And then, a bit later: “It is not health to take vitamins and exercise.” His lyrics, whether lofty or cranky, often imply that very little is what it seems and that we are all probably doing wrong, or paying into a rotten system. A song is a gift, but what kind of gift is this? What kind of dude is this?
2016-08-25.headline_main: Cass McCombs: Imagine Beckett as a Cranky Singer-Songwriter

2016-08-25.snippet: Every day we lose more frames from beloved old films. Preservationists are rushing to save them before a crucial part of cultural history is lost.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: If you have ever seen the 1931 film of “The Front Page,” based on the jauntily cynical play, you might have been startled by the moment when a wisecracking newspaperman silences his machine-gun-fast patter to raise his middle finger at the mayor and sheriff. Is this what the New York Times reviewer Mordaunt Hall was thinking of when he wrote that the film’s humor is “frequently harsh”?

His grade-school principal built the house across the street; his family doctor lived two doors down. Ruby Dee and Ossie Davis were his house guests. Those were the people who came to Sag Harbor Hills.

2016-08-25.abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: A fire lights up in the northern district of Paris in August 1916.
2016-08-25.snippet: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: A fire lights up in the northern district of Paris in August 1916.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: A sensation was caused in the northern districts of Paris last evening [Aug. 24], about half-past nine, when a red glow suddenly appeared in the sky, growing brighter rapidly and passing from its primitive hue to a blinding white glare and then through the whole gamut of colors. A stop was put to the alarming rumors which spread among the public when it was learned that a fire had occurred at the Ruggieri fireworks manufactory at Saint-Denis, destroying about 20,000fr. worth of chemical products, but causing no loss of life. — The New York Herald, European Edition, Aug. 26, 1916
2016-08-25.headline_main: 1916: Fire Lights Up Paris

2016-08-25.abstract: We’re excited about the latest exoplanet because of what it says about our own celestial home.
2016-08-25.snippet: We’re excited about the latest exoplanet because of what it says about our own celestial home.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: Charlottesville, Va. — Yesterday, the European Southern Observatory announced that astronomers have detected a planet the size of Earth orbiting our nearest star, Proxima Centauri. We discover hundreds of “exoplanets” every year, but this one is different: It orbits its star at just the right distance so that, in theory, it’s possible it could sustain life. This detection of a “goldilocks” planet so close to our own marks a significant achievement for exoplanet astronomy, the young field devoted to the search for and study of planets orbiting stars other than our sun.
2016-08-25.headline_main: What’s So Special About Another Earth?

2016-08-25.abstract: The building, in Chanhassen, Minn., also includes a music production complex and will open on Oct. 6.

2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: Paisley Park, Prince’s storied private estate and music complex in Chanhassen, Minn., plans to open as a museum this fall, according to an announcement from the singer’s estate on Wednesday. Public tours are scheduled to begin on Oct. 6, with tickets going on sale starting this Friday, at OfficialPaisleyPark.com. The family is also planning an official tribute concert for Prince on Oct. 13 at U.S. Bank Stadium in Minneapolis.
2016-08-25.headline_main: Paisley Park, Prince’s Estate, Will Open as a Museum

2016-08-25.snippet: A new government study finds that middle-class people paid less for health insurance in states that offered Medicaid to the poor.

2016-08-25.abstract: The daughter of Sumner Redstone achieved almost total victory in her fight to control the vast media empire, and Mr. Dauman was the biggest casualty.
2016-08-25.snippet: The daughter of Sumner Redstone achieved almost total victory in her fight to control the vast media empire, and Mr. Dauman was the biggest casualty.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: Just a few weeks ago, things seemed to be breaking Philippe A. Dauman’s way in his legal bid to maintain his grip on Viacom — which owns, among other things MTV, Comedy Central and Paramount Pictures — by having its majority owner and chairman, the 93-year-old media mogul Sumner Redstone, declared mentally incompetent.
2016-08-25.headline_main: How Philippe Dauman Lost the Battle for Viacom

2016-08-25.abstract: Working for Planned Parenthood elicits unwelcome talks with strangers. Also, worming your way into a tight-knit circle of friends — or not.
2016-08-25.snippet: Working for Planned Parenthood elicits unwelcome talks with strangers. Also, worming your way into a tight-knit circle of friends — or not.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: I work for Planned Parenthood. I love my job and I’m proud of what I do. In social settings, when asked what I do for a living, I answer truthfully and in full. But this nearly always leads to a big rehash of the politics surrounding my employer, together with the same old talking points and statistics. I don’t like taking my work home (or out) with me. Is there a way to head off these lengthy discussions without withholding the name Planned Parenthood? Saying “I work in health care” feels like hiding to me.
2016-08-25.headline_main: In a Social Setting, Is It OK to Avoid Saying Where You Work?

2016-08-25.abstract: Snake Day will be the highlight of an entire garden weekend starring these animals at Wave Hill in the Bronx.
2016-08-25.snippet: Snake Day will be the highlight of an entire garden weekend starring these animals at Wave Hill in the Bronx.

2016-08-25.headline_main: Snakes in the Garden (but These Are Welcome)

2016-08-25.abstract: Cancer can wear you down. So can life and moving and treatment and age. Sometimes I think the time has come to face the end, but then I remember there is more life to be lived.
2016-08-25.snippet: Cancer can wear you down. So can life and moving and treatment and age. Sometimes I think the time has come to face the end, but then I remember there is more life to be lived.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: Occasionally I feel so worn down by the exigencies of cancer and of aging that I believe the time has arrived to face the end, though I dearly wish to be proven wrong.

2016-08-25.abstract: The murders of three runners evoke a painful racial history.
2016-08-25.snippet: The murders of three runners evoke a painful racial history.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: When I ran cross-country in high school in California, I was well trained, well coached and professionally sized for my Asics racing flats. Running was a source of pleasurable vulnerability: I courted the limits of how much self-inflicted pain my body could handle, tracing the long curve of Santa Monica Bay, on the hard sand by the water, and the wealthy streets of Brentwood, past hedge-hidden homes. My runs were backlit by privilege.
2016-08-25.headline_main: Rape, Race and the Jogger

2016-08-25.abstract: The projects competing for best video this year — including those from Beyoncé, Drake, Justin Bieber and Kanye West — suggest a new maturity for the form.
2016-08-25.snippet: The projects competing for best video this year — including those from Beyoncé, Drake, Justin Bieber and Kanye West — suggest a new maturity for the form.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: As music awards shows go, MTV’s annual Video Music Awards ceremony — the V.M.A.s — is by far the loosest, the most vibrant and the most prone to disruption. It has long been the platform where pop stars know a medium amount of misbehavior will be tolerated — encouraged, actually. The show isn’t about trophies, but moments. That MTV itself isn’t much in the music business anymore only makes the playing field clearer for provocation: Acting out here is like trashing a hotel room, not your house.
2016-08-25.headline_main: Good News for MTV’s V.M.A.s: Music Videos Matter Again

2016-08-25.abstract: Taste the Tropics USA, a West Indian-themed ice cream parlor in Brooklyn that opened in the 1970s, serves ice cream flavors like pineapple, coconut, soursop and even a beer-based option: Guinness.
2016-08-25.snippet: Taste the Tropics USA, a West Indian-themed ice cream parlor in Brooklyn that opened in the 1970s, serves ice cream flavors like pineapple, coconut, soursop and even a beer-based option: Guinness.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: If you are anywhere near the corner of Nostrand and Avenue D in Brooklyn, it would take an almost herculean effort to ignore Taste the Tropics USA, Jerry Zirino’s West Indian-themed ice cream parlor. For the past four decades, he’s lured customers with the help of neon, a hand-painted mural, a cheerful clutter of old-fashioned signs — “Ask for a taste, please come in” — and a glorious rainbow logo whose swoosh connects a sugar cone to a trio of palm trees.
2016-08-25.headline_main: When Only a Scoop of Soursop Will Do

2016-08-25.abstract: Martin Blackwell had objected to the couple sleeping together in the apartment of his girlfriend.
2016-08-25.snippet: Martin Blackwell had objected to the couple sleeping together in the apartment of his girlfriend.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: As he waited for a pot of water to boil, Martin Blackwell had plenty of time to change his mind. But instead, he went ahead with what a judge in Georgia said was a “soulless” decision to throw the scalding water over two gay men sleeping on a mattress, burning them so severely that one was put into an induced coma at the hospital and both required skin grafts.
2016-08-25.headline_main: Georgia Man Gets 40 Years in Prison for Hot-Water Attack on Gay Men

2016-08-25.abstract: Matthew McConaughey stars as a professor who enters a Japanese forest to end his life. There he meets a businessman, played by Ken Watanabe, with the same goal.
2016-08-25.snippet: Matthew McConaughey stars as a professor who enters a Japanese forest to end his life. There he meets a businessman, played by Ken Watanabe, with the same goal.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: “The Sea of Trees” is another name for the Aokigahara forest in Japan, such a popular spot for suicides that some believe that the spirits of the dead linger there to trap unwary wanderers. Or perhaps to snare incautious filmmakers, as it’s also the setting for Gus Van Sant’s movie of the same name, a numinous meditation on grief that’s more likely to inspire laughter than tears.
2016-08-25.headline_main: Review: Love, Loss and Spiritual Torment in ‘The Sea of Trees’

2016-08-25.abstract: This British indie offers a cynical vision of technology-fostered callousness, a running-man cocktail of brutality spiked with low-level humor.
2016-08-25.snippet: This British indie offers a cynical vision of technology-fostered callousness, a running-man cocktail of brutality spiked with low-level humor.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: Matt (Josh Bowman) is having a very bad day. For one thing, his hardworking girlfriend, Anna (Leila Mimmack), has reached the limit of her tolerance for his couch-sitting, video-game-playing ways. And for another, three dudes wearing knitted balaclavas have just shown up at his front door, strapped a package to his chest and informed him that failure to deliver it will result in Anna’s being killed.
2016-08-25.headline_main: Review: In ‘Level Up,’ Yanked From a Video Game Stupor to a Real Mission

2016-08-25.abstract: After Mr. Trump indicated he might retreat from his vow to deport all immigrants in the United States illegally, disgust poured in from all sides, if for different reasons.
2016-08-25.snippet: After Mr. Trump indicated he might retreat from his vow to deport all immigrants in the United States illegally, disgust poured in from all sides, if for different reasons.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: For 15 months, even as Donald J. Trump vacillated on many other issues, he stuck to a simple, hard-line position on immigration: If elected president, he would form a “deportation force,” round up people who are in the United States illegally and send them back where they came from.
2016-08-25.headline_main: Donald Trump, Wavering on Immigration, Finds Anger in All Corners

2016-08-25.abstract: Students at the University of Texas at Austin have found a silly way to make a serious point.
2016-08-25.snippet: Students at the University of Texas at Austin have found a silly way to make a serious point.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: As America slogs through one of the most surreal and disturbing election seasons in recent memory, it’s sometimes hard to find much to laugh about. But students at the University of Texas have retained their sense of humor, and they are using it for good.
2016-08-25.headline_main: Fighting Campus Carry — With Sex Toys

2016-08-25.abstract: He weathered the recession by investing Travelers’ insurance premiums in stable vehicles, like fixed-income securities.
2016-08-25.snippet: He weathered the recession by investing Travelers’ insurance premiums in stable vehicles, like fixed-income securities.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: Jay S. Fishman, who steered the insurance giant Travelers through the financial crisis of 2008 and into the elite ranks of the companies that make up the Dow Jones industrial average, died on Aug. 19 at his home in New Jersey. He was 63.
2016-08-25.headline_main: Jay Fishman, Who Led Travelers Safely Through the Financial Crisis, Dies at 63

2016-08-25.abstract: Dani Menkin’s film follows a 60-year-old Israeli to New York and Canada, where he searches for the long-ago love of his life.
2016-08-25.snippet: Dani Menkin’s film follows a 60-year-old Israeli to New York and Canada, where he searches for the long-ago love of his life.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: “There is not one day in my life that I didn’t think, ‘What if?’” Ronnie (Alon Aboutboul) says in “Is That You?,” a bittersweet and lovely little movie. Most everyone else he meets has a story of regret, or a soft feeling of sorrow. Yet among this film’s surprises is that each scene still exudes affection.
2016-08-25.headline_main: Review: Pondering All of Life’s ‘What Ifs’ in ‘Is That You?’

2016-08-25.abstract: As the U.S. Open begins, the tennis player, who last reached the finals in 2014, tries to balance rest and fun with preparing for her next match.
2016-08-25.snippet: As the U.S. Open begins, the tennis player, who last reached the finals in 2014, tries to balance rest and fun with preparing for her next match.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: The Danish tennis player Caroline Wozniacki has a soft spot for the United States Open, which begins on Monday in Flushing Meadows, Queens. “The atmosphere is always spectacular,” said Ms.Wozniacki, 26, who last reached the women’s singles final in 2014 (she lost to her good friend Serena Williams). “The fact that it’s in New York makes it even more special.” Ms. Wozniacki travels frequently, but she considers herself a New Yorker. During the Open, she appreciates the nightly retreat to her apartment overlooking Union Square, which she shares with her Pomeranian, Bruno. The tournament is also nicely coordinated with another of Ms. Wozniacki’s favorite events: New York Fashion Week. Perhaps she’ll go with Ms. Williams, or someone else from her group of close-knit city friends.
2016-08-25.headline_main: How Caroline Wozniacki, Danish Tennis Player, Spends Her Sundays

2016-08-25.abstract: The film, written and directed by Clea DuVall, finds a group of 30-somethings gathering to encourage a married couple to break up.
2016-08-25.snippet: The film, written and directed by Clea DuVall, finds a group of 30-somethings gathering to encourage a married couple to break up.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: It would be folly to equate “The Intervention” with “The Big Chill,” but there are parallels. Both concern friends assembling at an opulent Southern mansion for a reckoning. But the prevailing issue in “The Intervention” is marriage, not a death: The friends gather to advise a husband and wife verging on divorce, the Type-A Peter (Vincent Piazza) and the sensible Ruby (Cobie Smulders), to break up, though it takes the group a while to arrive at the task.
2016-08-25.headline_main: Review: In ‘The Intervention,’ There’s a Big Chill in the Air

2016-08-25.snippet: American military officials reported four potentially dangerous episodes in the Gulf this week between United States and Iranian naval vessels.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: Iranian naval boats made dangerous maneuvers around United States warships in the Persian Gulf area on at least four occasions this week, Pentagon officials said Thursday, including one episode in which the Americans fired warning shots from a 50-caliber deck gun to prevent a collision.
2016-08-25.headline_main: Tensions Rise Between Iran and U.S. in Persian Gulf

2016-08-25.abstract: The visual for Hiatus’s “Nightjar” combines psychedelic paint swirls with a Bauhaus-style metropolis, shot through layers of glass.
2016-08-25.snippet: The visual for Hiatus’s “Nightjar” combines psychedelic paint swirls with a Bauhaus-style metropolis, shot through layers of glass.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: The erstwhile journalist Cyrus Shahrad, who records under the name Hiatus, sees his electronic music career as having begun long before the drum-’n’-bass nights he D.J.-ed in his smoke-filled basement room as a student at Cambridge University. Rather, he says, it germinated in his early childhood, “sitting in the back of the car on pre-dawn drives to visit my English grandparents in Dorset, listening to the warped cassettes of mournful Iranian music my dad would play to keep himself awake.” At the time, Iran seemed to him “an idea as much as a place,” he says: Shahrad was born in the capital just before the 1979 revolution, and his family promptly fled to the U.K. But in 2005, he returned for a stint covering the presidential election for the Sunday Times, discovered his father’s old record collection and realized that he’d been missing “half of home.”
2016-08-25.headline_main: A New, Mesmerizing Music Video to Get Lost in

2016-08-25.abstract: Mr. Morris, whose “Mozart Dances” is at Lincoln Center this week, is the exception when it comes to matching movement with the composer’s complexities.
2016-08-25.snippet: Mr. Morris, whose “Mozart Dances” is at Lincoln Center this week, is the exception when it comes to matching movement with the composer’s complexities.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: Throughout “Mozart Dances,” Mark Morris emerges as the most artfully musical choreographer alive. He has so many resources, devices and qualities with which to respond to a score: steps, gestures, patterns, fantasy, charm, humor. Most choreographers should steer clear of Mozart (Haydn and Beethoven, too) because the work can make the dances look crude. But Mr. Morris lets us know (boy, does he let us know) how keenly aware he is of the many aural layers here, and the subtle relationship between details and overall architecture.
2016-08-25.headline_main: Review: Choreographers Should Stay Away From Mozart. Except Mark Morris.

2016-08-25.abstract: Accounts of Donald J. Trump, among them some he wrote, describe a world where greed, arrogance and the sowing of discord are signs of leadership.
2016-08-25.snippet: Accounts of Donald J. Trump, among them some he wrote, describe a world where greed, arrogance and the sowing of discord are signs of leadership.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: Over the last year, we’ve been plunged into the alternate reality of Trumpland, as though we were caught in the maze of his old board game, “Trump: The Game,” with no exit in sight. It’s a Darwinian, dog-eat-dog, zero-sum world where greed is good, insults are the lingua franca, and winning is everything (or, in tangled Trumpian syntax, “It’s not whether you win or lose, but whether you win!”).
2016-08-25.headline_main: In Books on Donald Trump, Consistent Portraits of a High-Decibel Narcissist

2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: A cross between “Dexter” and “Encyclopedia Brown,” “I Am Not a Serial Killer” follows John Wayne Cleaver, a 16-year-old Midwesterner being treated for sociopathic tendencies  who is trying to resist his worst urges. Maybe John shouldn’t help out so much in the family business. His mother and aunt run a mortuary, and he’s really into prepping the corpses. He may not be a serial killer, but he sure likes studying them.
