2016-08-25.abstract: In Joshua Marston’s film, a man with a shaky marriage meets an unnerving old flame who has lived under a series of assumed personas.
2016-08-25.snippet: In Joshua Marston’s film, a man with a shaky marriage meets an unnerving old flame who has lived under a series of assumed personas.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: Joshua Marston’s “Complete Unknown” is a curious hybrid, teetering between a thriller and a romance only to land in a nebulous spot that is neither. The film concerns Tom (Michael Shannon), a New York agriculture lobbyist whose wife, Ramina (Azita Ghanizada), is weighing a move to San Diego for a graduate program. At a birthday party for Tom attended by, among others, their friends Clyde (Michael Chernus) and Sharon (Condola Rashad), he meets Alice (Rachel Weisz), who recently met Clyde at his office cafeteria.
2016-08-25.headline_main: Review: Rachel Weisz Toys With Identity in ‘Complete Unknown’

2016-08-25.abstract: With solid suspense, murky lighting and “gotcha!” scares, Fede Alvarez’s film will probably please fans intrigued by those elements.
2016-08-25.snippet: With solid suspense, murky lighting and “gotcha!” scares, Fede Alvarez’s film will probably please fans intrigued by those elements.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: People who go to see movies like “Don’t Breathe” — some of them, anyway — tend to laugh when people are killed onscreen. And when people believed to be dead open their eyes. Even I laughed when the watchdog, which the three attractive young thieves had drugged into slumber, appeared in the hallway, growling. Ha! Guess he woke up, dudes.
2016-08-25.headline_main: Review: ‘Don’t Breathe’: Whose Bright Idea Was It to Rob a Blind Man?

2016-08-25.abstract: “Remainders,” a body of work on display at Pioneer Works, is timeless, otherworldly and a little bit menacing. It has not been seen in public since 1995.
2016-08-25.snippet: “Remainders,” a body of work on display at Pioneer Works, is timeless, otherworldly and a little bit menacing. It has not been seen in public since 1995.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: Photography was the medium of choice for most art critics in the 1980s. Unlike painting, which thrived in a robust art market and came to symbolize the excesses of that era, photography could be used to critique mass media images, male-dominated art history — even photography itself. Despite the rise to prominence of so-called good postmodern artists like Nan Goldin and Cindy Sherman, however, there are still plenty of photographers being rediscovered today. One of them is Jimmy DeSana, who died in 1990 at the age of 40 from AIDS-related causes.
2016-08-25.headline_main: Revisiting an Artist’s Provocative Photographs

2016-08-25.abstract: The movie, directed by Jean-François Richet, finds the grizzled loner of a hero fighting to protect his daughter.
2016-08-25.snippet: The movie, directed by Jean-François Richet, finds the grizzled loner of a hero fighting to protect his daughter.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: Hobbesian to the max, “Blood Father” is unwaveringly nasty and brutish. It’s also short, a combination that pretty much gives you all that you could want from a pulp fiction in which Mel Gibson plays a grizzled loner inking skin in a spot called the Missing Link Tattoo. He’s Link, of course; first name John. A former bad, bad man with a wild beard and a deep well of cynicism, John lives in a trailer parked on one of those picturesquely godforsaken southwestern landscapes where John Ford-style homesteaders once circled the wagons. The dream of the Old West dies hard, especially in the movies.
2016-08-25.headline_main: Review: In ‘Blood Father,’ Mel Gibson Plays With Pulp Fiction

2016-08-25.snippet: “But a Storm Is Blowing From Paradise,” at the Guggenheim Museum, focuses on contemporary art from the Middle East and North Africa.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: Last spring, the Guggenheim’s board of trustees abruptly severed contact with the Gulf Labor Coalition, an international watchdog group monitoring the living and working conditions of migrant laborers in Abu Dhabi, capital of the United Arab Emirates, where the Guggenheim Foundation is building a new Frank Gehry-designed museum. The move, and the protests that followed, happened to coincide with the third and last of the museum’s UBS Map Global Art Initiative group exhibitions in New York, this one called “But a Storm Is Blowing From Paradise: Contemporary Art of the Middle East and North Africa.”
2016-08-25.headline_main: The Guggenheim Is Going Global. Kind Of.

2016-08-25.abstract: Nanni Moretti’s film, starring Margherita Buy as a movie director and John Turturro as an American star, makes a case for blurriness in art and life.
2016-08-25.snippet: Nanni Moretti’s film, starring Margherita Buy as a movie director and John Turturro as an American star, makes a case for blurriness in art and life.
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: Love, death, cinema — they’re all there in “Mia Madre,” bumping up against one another beautifully. It’s the story of a movie director, Margherita (Margherita Buy), who, while shooting a difficult movie about labor strife, learns that her mother, Ada (Giulia Lazzarini), may be dying. Yet even as tragedy surges, flooding scenes and tear ducts, Margherita’s featured performer, an outsize American star named Barry (John Turturro), enters laughing, bellowing, acting. The Italian director Nanni Moretti knows how to turn on the waterworks, but he also knows about that burlesque called life.
2016-08-25.headline_main: ‘Mia Madre’ Review: Mom’s in the Hospital. The Riot Scene Needs Retakes.

2016-08-25.snippet: Jonathan Jakubowicz’s film has scattered pleasures, like Mr. De Niro’s performance as Roberto Durán’s trainer. But the boxing scenes do not come within swinging distance of “Raging Bull.”
2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: Robert De Niro redefined film acting by subjecting himself to a reported 60-pound weight gain to play a gone-to-seed version of Jake LaMotta, the middleweight boxer, in Martin Scorsese’s 1980 film, “Raging Bull.” Mr. De Niro, lithe, lean and lethal as LaMotta in his prime, became a bloated, bulbous ball of hostility and confusion for LaMotta’s post-boxing life. (He won a best actor Oscar for his pains.) But as much as “Raging Bull” is an exacting portrait of an athlete and his sport, it is not a “boxing movie.”
2016-08-25.headline_main: Review: ‘Hands of Stone’ Returns Robert De Niro to the Ring but Pulls Its Punches

2016-08-25.lead_paragraph: MARTIN R. ANDERSON, 65, squints to appreciate the geometry of paintings at the museum. Kate Davis, 24, says the sunlight that bounces off museum walls and onto the art can’t be reproduced. Stan Kaplan, 65, flies across the country just to see a Leonardo da Vinci drawing “more beautiful” than the Mona Lisa. And an elderly woman posts to Facebook a selfie of herself beside a masterwork, presumably commencing an avalanche of social-media approval.

2016-08-26.abstract: A new book brings attention to the deadly 1971 prison uprising. Reporters for The New York Times and The Marshall Project describe what has changed since then, and what hasn’t.
2016-08-26.snippet: A new book brings attention to the deadly 1971 prison uprising. Reporters for The New York Times and The Marshall Project describe what has changed since then, and what hasn’t.
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: In her new book, “Blood in the Water,” Heather Ann Thompson offers the most detailed account yet of the historic uprising by inmates over squalid conditions at Attica Correctional Facility in western New York. On Sept. 13, 1971, Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller ordered state troopers, armed with rifles and handguns, to storm the prison and quash a four-day rebellion. By the time it was over, 39 people had been shot dead, including 10 prison employees. Four others died earlier.
2016-08-26.headline_main: Revisiting Attica Shows How New York State Failed to Fulfill Promises

2016-08-26.abstract: Friday solving fun with Andrew Kingsley.
2016-08-26.snippet: Friday solving fun with Andrew Kingsley.
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: FRIDAY PUZZLE — For those of you just joining us, Friday New York Times puzzles are usually themeless, which gives a constructor the opportunity to salt a grid with longer, livelier fill. They can do this because they are not constrained by setting a theme inside a grid and then trying to fill around it. That’s the thing about the late-week puzzles: You have to work to get the clues and the entries might be a bit tougher, but you will generally be rewarded with entertaining fill and cluing that you won’t see earlier in the week.
2016-08-26.headline_main: The World’s Catalog of Ideas

2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: There’s so much to like about the Mint Theater Company’s revisiting of “A Day by the Sea” that it’s hard to know what to single out for first-paragraph attention. Let’s go with this: Even secondary characters in this 1953 play by N. C. Hunter are given the chance to make an impression, and in this production they do.

2016-08-26.abstract: Leslye Headland (“Bachelorette”) has written a dark drama about infidelity and its unforeseen consequences, now playing at Second Stage Theater.
2016-08-26.snippet: Leslye Headland (“Bachelorette”) has written a dark drama about infidelity and its unforeseen consequences, now playing at Second Stage Theater.
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: Has anyone ever enjoyed a layover? Either it is nerve-janglingly short or grindingly long. “The Layover,” a disappointing new play by Leslye Headland that opened on Thursday at Second Stage Theater, achieves the novel feat of being both at the same time. Running a little more than 90 minutes, it doesn’t succeed in bringing us deeply into the lives of its principal characters. And yet we don’t exactly leave pining for more of their company.
2016-08-26.headline_main: Review: In ‘The Layover,’ Strangers on a Plane and Missed Connections

2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: Donald Trump has taken a strange turn lately. O.K., he has taken a lot of strange turns — that’s what happens when you nominate a short-attention-span candidate who knows nothing about policy and refuses to sit still for more than three minutes. But never mind what passes for Trumpian policy ideas. What’s odd is the shift in what the problem is supposed to be.

2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: Are you smarter than an immigrant? Can you name, say, all three branches of government or a single Supreme Court justice? Most Americans, those born here, those about to make the most momentous decision in civic life this November, cannot. And most cannot pass the simple test aced by 90 percent of new citizens.

2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: Lately I’ve been thinking about experience. Donald Trump lacks political experience, and the ineptitude caused by his inexperience is evident every day. On the other hand, Hillary Clinton is nothing if not experienced. Her ship is running smoothly, and yet as her reaction to the email scandal shows once again, there’s often a whiff of inhumanity about her campaign that inspires distrust.

2016-08-26.abstract: Marin Cilic, Grigor Dimitrov and Juan Martín del Potro are threats in the men’s draw, and Madison Keys, Karolina Pliskova and Mónica Puig stand out among the women.
2016-08-26.snippet: Marin Cilic, Grigor Dimitrov and Juan Martín del Potro are threats in the men’s draw, and Madison Keys, Karolina Pliskova and Mónica Puig stand out among the women.
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: Cilic, 27, won his first Masters 1000 tournament at Cincinnati on Aug. 21 and vaulted back into the top 10 with a straight-sets victory over Andy Murray, the reigning Wimbledon and Olympic champion. Cilic, who had three match points against Roger Federer in the Wimbledon quarterfinals, kept Murray off balance with a nearly unreturnable wide slice serve, followed by flat bombs up the middle. After parting ways with his longtime coach Goran Ivanisevic, Cilic hired Jonas Bjorkman to help strengthen his forehand and his return, both of which let him down in crucial moments against Federer at Wimbledon. Against Murray at Cincinnati, Cilic returned brilliantly. Cilic is seeded seventh at the United States Open, and his rising level of play suggests that he could be rounding into the kind of form that led him to the title in 2014.
2016-08-26.headline_main: Dark Horses Abound at the United States Open

Trump have yet to face off in their first debate, but both candidates have already moved teams into a plush marble-and-glass office building a block from the White House, where they are vetting résumés, sketching out organizational charts and otherwise planning the transition to a Trump or Clinton administration.

2016-08-26.snippet: Kelly Lewis, the founder of the Go! Girl Guides, on how women travel differently from men, staying safe and more.
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: After graduating from college in 2008, Kelly Lewis traveled the world solo. She spent a year in New Zealand and backpacked from one end of South America to the other. In the process, she relied on guidebooks. But they didn’t give her all the information she needed, especially as a woman. “I would have loved if someone would have told me it’s really hard to find tampons in Buenos Aires,” she said. “And why doesn’t anyone tell you this particular bus station is sketchy at night?”
2016-08-26.headline_main: Tips for Women Traveling Solo

2016-08-26.abstract: My daughter’s bike was a symbol of independence and growing up, the freedom of wheels that I hadn’t had at her age.
2016-08-26.snippet: My daughter’s bike was a symbol of independence and growing up, the freedom of wheels that I hadn’t had at her age.
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: When I outgrew my tricycle, my mother never replaced my wheels. Enviously I watched as the other kids in my neighborhood mounted their shiny Schwinns, confident cowkids on imaginary mares. They wobbled side to side on training wheels, inserted cards into the spokes as noisemakers, and sailed by with colorful banners flowing from handlebars. I was the one kid on the block with only feet as transportation.
2016-08-26.headline_main: You Always Remember Your First Bike

2016-08-26.abstract: How did marketers convince people that masculinity meant never being around sharp objects?
2016-08-26.snippet: How did marketers convince people that masculinity meant never being around sharp objects?
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: The first razor I can remember owning is one I received as a present for my 18th birthday. It came in the mail from Gillette. I don’t know how the company knew, but I was happy to be in its database. The Fusion, with its novel five-blade design, had recently hit the market. I was thrilled, and I cycled back and forth through the cartridges until they were all hair-­clogged and uselessly dull. When I found out the price of a Fusion blade-­refill box, I saw my whole life stretch in front of me.
2016-08-26.headline_main: Letter of Recommendation: Safety Razors

2016-08-26.abstract: Learn to climb safely. Always remain harnessed.
2016-08-26.snippet: Learn to climb safely. Always remain harnessed.
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: “Start low to the ground,” says Andrew Joslin, who first slept in a tree 10 years ago, when he was a tech worker who regularly slept in a hammock in his Boston backyard. Now 60, Joslin lives in rural Massachusetts, where he works as an arborist. If you intend to sleep 15 feet off the ground or higher, first learn to climb safely. You’ll need 150 feet of arborist rope, a harness, a helmet, carabiners and a special tree-­sleeping hammock, or a lightweight platform called a portaledge. Before you ascend, check the weather. You don’t want to be dozens of feet off the ground in the dark during high winds or lightning.
2016-08-26.headline_main: How to Sleep in a Tree

2016-08-26.abstract: Finding solace in Patna, India, after a personal loss.
2016-08-26.snippet: Finding solace in Patna, India, after a personal loss.
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: Gulshan showed up in our lives by chance. She was old, searching for work; Mom wasn’t looking to hire anyone. And even if she had been, Gulshan was Muslim and my family Hindu. When I was growing up, most families in India hired help within their own religion unless they could afford English-speaking, Catholic nannies. But there was something about Gulshan. True to her name, which means “garden” in Hindi, she created a kind of refuge around her. Before we knew it, she was in our kitchen making Mom’s favorite dessert, phirni — a bit like rice pudding.
2016-08-26.headline_main: Familiar Dish, Familiar Friend

2016-08-26.abstract: Even when finely translated, not all good books travel well across cultures.
2016-08-26.snippet: Even when finely translated, not all good books travel well across cultures.
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: It’s one world, we’re one community, and so we must all read the same books. Otherwise how could we talk about them to one another? Thus the logic of globalization: ever larger numbers of people worldwide reading the very best (or best-promoted?) authors. It’s good news for those authors and their publishers, not so encouraging for the increasing number of people who would like to make a living from writing. And of course it raises the intriguing question: Even when well translated, can we really understand what other cultures are talking about? Will a housewife in Tibet (assuming there are “housewives” in Tibet) make sense of Jonathan Franzen’s St. Paul, Minn.? Can other people truly get the hang of Bulgarian etiquette or courtship in Laos or street life in the Philippines? Are we interested? Does it make sense to be interested? In short, do all good books travel?
2016-08-26.headline_main: Tim Parks Laments the Excessive Influence of International Book Fairs

2016-08-26.snippet: In “The Hatred of Poetry,” Ben Lerner maintains that poetry is “often met with contempt rather than mere indifference.”
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: If you’re a poet, it’s easy to spend a lot of time worrying about how people feel about poetry. It’s also easy to dismiss how people feel because if you were to consider the blithe indifference with which most audiences actually regard poets and their poems, it would be depressing — and not depressing in the poetic way that, for instance, mortality is depressing, but depressing in the way that, Oh my goodness, we totally forgot you were even here, have you been sitting in this little cubicle all afternoon?
2016-08-26.headline_main: Do People Hate Poetry? According to Ben Lerner, Yes

2016-08-26.snippet: This recently reissued fixture, designed in 1972 by the Danish architect Louis Weisdorf, doesn’t merely illuminate a room.
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: Designed in 1972 by the Danish architect Louis Weisdorf, this shape-shifting brass pendant lamp doesn’t merely illuminate a room; the light it throws can also mirror your mood. Futuristic, with a Fritz Langian appeal, it is made up of two center cylinders encompassed by quarter-spherical shells that can pivot to change the fixture’s shape. Recently reissued by the Danish manufacturer Gubi, it is available in brass, chrome, matte white, black or French blue, and can be configured in multiple ways, turning any room into a true reflection of the happily divided self.
2016-08-26.headline_main: A ’70s Pendant Lamp From the Future

2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: Novelists have every right to use historical data to lend their works verisimilitude, and they are free to go beyond the facts, wherever their fancy leads them. Historians, though, are bound by circumstances, condemned to whatever partial, obstructed view their sources grant them. Their only recourse is to keep on looking and pray. Meanwhile, novelists can soar and gain an untrammeled vista.

2016-08-26.abstract: A red door leads to adventure, a curious mouse sends himself to the moon, and a lonely man gets a mysterious invitation.
2016-08-26.snippet: A red door leads to adventure, a curious mouse sends himself to the moon, and a lonely man gets a mysterious invitation.
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: For very young children, even a trip to a grocery store can be thrilling. Cheese samples, the fish department and the dewy surprise of automatic misting in the produce section: Lots of marvels are packed in those prosaic aisles. Some of the most enduring children’s books transform something ordinary — a purple crayon, a wardrobe, a red pebble — into vehicles for exhilarating journeys. Three new picture books follow the tradition. In space, at sea, in a twilight world — these books take readers on escapes so transporting it’s a pleasure to get lost.
2016-08-26.headline_main: Three Stunning Picture Books Take Children on Unusual Journeys

2016-08-26.abstract: Children climb typography mountains and craft their own adventures in four tributes to the power of storytelling.
2016-08-26.snippet: Children climb typography mountains and craft their own adventures in four tributes to the power of storytelling.
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: Many creators of picture books become so immersed in the lengthy process of bringing a book into the world, they can’t help pitching the idea of making a book about books. I can relate. I have three or four such books in a shoe box under my bed. Looking back, I think I created them for the exclusive amusement of my bookish colleagues. Was I showing off? Maybe. The truth is, the very best picture books appeal to several audiences at the same time. These include parents, fellow bookmakers, librarians, award givers and, one hopes, even children. Four new books about books manage to thread that needle.
2016-08-26.headline_main: Four New Picture Books Teach Children the Power of Stories

2016-08-26.abstract: The New York Times Stylebook is our canonical reference for how our newsroom uses language. During our recent Maker Week, we asked: how might we make the online Stylebook even more useful?
2016-08-26.snippet: The New York Times Stylebook is our canonical reference for how our newsroom uses language. During our recent Maker Week, we asked: how might we make the online Stylebook even more useful?
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: In 1895, the editors of The New York Times created the inaugural version of the paper’s Manual of Style and Usage — a guidebook to the publication’s particular rules of grammar, punctuation, spelling and capitalization that remains an essential part of our newsroom toolkit. Since then, it’s been updated regularly to reflect the changing times (the word email, for example, appeared as early as 1985 and was styled as “e-mail”). In 1999, the first online version of the manual, known as the Stylebook, became available on the NYT intranet.
2016-08-26.headline_main: Putting {Style} into the Online New York Times Stylebook

2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: Grandmaster Flash might easily have missed the hip-hop revolution. Born in Barbados and transplanted to the South Bronx as a child, he began his adolescence far from the city, in a group home for foster children in rural upstate New York. By the time he returned to the borough’s Fort Apache section in 1971, things were changing fast. Music was getting more percussive; teenagers with spray cans were scrawling hieroglyphic names and full-fledged murals on subway cars.

2016-08-26.abstract: Colson Whitehead, whose “The Underground Railroad” is No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list, cites “The Twilight Zone” as a key influence.
2016-08-26.snippet: Colson Whitehead, whose “The Underground Railroad” is No. 1 on the hardcover fiction list, cites “The Twilight Zone” as a key influence.
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: Fifth Dimension: Remember John Cheever’s story “The Swimmer”? Sure you do: That’s the one where a guest at a garden party decides on a lark to make his way home by water, swimming one by one across his neighbors’ pools only to find that a year or more seems to pass in the space of a single afternoon. As a surreal gesture — the journey not just through geography but through time — that premise has something in common with Colson Whitehead’s novel “The Underground Railroad” (No. 1 in its third week on the hardcover fiction list), in which a runaway slave encounters various examples of racism on her flight north that could come only from a more contemporary America. Yet Whitehead was influenced less by Cheever, he told me via email, than by “another ’60s artifact of pop fabulism”: “I can work back through my life,” he said, “and pick out key moments where I was exposed to some new fabulist gesture — ‘One Hundred Years of Solitude’ in 12th grade, the ‘Battle Royal’ chapter of ‘Invisible Man’ in a ­seventh-grade English class — but my earliest immersion into the fantastic was probably reruns of ‘The Twilight Zone.’ Slave girl Cora emerging from the literal underground railroad and seeing a skyscraper: That’s a quintessential ‘Twilight Zone’ moment, where you take a step in the wrong direction and suddenly you’re in a world a little off to the side.”
2016-08-26.headline_main: Inside the List

2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Back in June, Kanye West was rumored to be playing a secret concert at the New York club Webster Hall after Hot 97’s Summer Jam festival. Well after midnight, the street was filled with hundreds of young people waiting for a chance to see their hero. The show itself didn’t happen, but at one point, a car drove past, and Mr. West poked his head out of the sunroof. The crowd surged and surrounded him; after a minute or two, the car pulled away from the throng, leaving a trail of fans chasing it up Third Avenue.
2016-08-26.headline_main: Review: Kanye West, Both Close and Out of Reach at His Tour Opener

2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: Restaurants are notoriously short-lived, but Restaurant Bricco, a West Hartford mainstay since 1996, is not only alive, but thriving. How many dinners have crossed the counter from the open kitchen whose wood-burning stone ovens greet arriving guests? Assume an average of 275 covers per night, and Billy Grant, its chef and owner, is somewhere around serving Bricco’s two millionth meal. And this is only one of three restaurants he owns.

2016-08-26.abstract: Our reporter shares selections from his visual, digital diary of New York.
2016-08-26.snippet: Our reporter shares selections from his visual, digital diary of New York.
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: Central Park, central Harlem, Centre Street, the Crossroads of the Worlds at the city’s center in Times Square, outside the historic Central Synagogue in Midtown in the blaring heat of August: These iPhone pictures (taken, by coincidence, mostly in those locations over a month of regular daily outings, and then posted to Twitter) constitute an informal diary of the ways that, even as strangers, we are at the unacknowledged center of one another’s existence. Like it or not, there is intimacy in our daily encounters with the millions who share our city, even if its duration is no longer than a glance or a shutter’s click.
2016-08-26.headline_main: Around the City in 10 Tweets

But by luck, he had recently made the acquaintance of Franz Schuritz, a trombonist who also happened to be the inventor of Ansatz-Crème, an invigorating lip balm. Armstrong was an immediate and lifelong convert.

It wasn’t in a suburban backyard but at Grand Central Terminal, where it had been set up for “Action Heroes,” a dance production by the daredevil choreographer Elizabeth Streb. Ms. DeLuca’s friend, a member of Ms. Streb’s company, had invited Ms. DeLuca to jump while the trampoline was free.

2016-08-26.abstract: A man and his family return to their old stamping ground, now past its heyday, and the memories of swimming and dancing and summer fun come rushing back.
2016-08-26.snippet: A man and his family return to their old stamping ground, now past its heyday, and the memories of swimming and dancing and summer fun come rushing back.
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: The memories started flooding in as we hit Route 145 in East Durham, N.Y., the thoroughfare that winds through the part of the Catskills known as the Irish Alps. We made this drive every summer of my childhood — my father steering a ridiculously large Oldsmobile, unlit Tiparillo cigar clenched in his teeth (he only ever smoked them once we had arrived), my sisters and I fighting over imagined back-seat borders, legs sticking to the scorching pleather.
2016-08-26.headline_main: The Last, Sweet Days of the Irish Alps in Upstate New York

2016-08-26.abstract: The performance artist shares what she’s learned as she approaches 70 and what her next project — “dying seven times for love” — will entail.
2016-08-26.snippet: The performance artist shares what she’s learned as she approaches 70 and what her next project — “dying seven times for love” — will entail.
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: Marina Abramovic has lived without privacy at Sean Kelly Gallery for 12 days on nothing but water; she’s invited strangers to use 72 random objects (including a gun with one bullet) on her in any way they want; she’s walked half the 5,500-mile length of the Great Wall of China to confront heartbreak. Her life as a whole has involved pushing herself to her physical and mental limits, and then going further. So it’s a surprise when, in person, she’s anything but intimidating. Within seconds, she’s asking about my right arm (in a sling from tennis-induced rotator cuff surgery) and then about the scar I have on the same arm (souvenir keloid from a childhood dog attack). “This is good,” she pronounces. “Scars I find the most interesting. I see no point in not asking right away — what happened?”
2016-08-26.headline_main: Five Questions for Marina Abramovic

2016-08-26.abstract: Tapping sales of a dish that hails from hard-hit Amatrice, Italy.

2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: New York City’s Italian restaurants have started fund-raising to help the town of Amatrice and others in central Italy devastated by an earthquake Wednesday. They hope to attract customer support for the effort by donating funds from orders of pasta all’amatriciana, the popular specialty of Amatrice.
2016-08-26.headline_main: Pasta From New York Restaurants Aids in Earthquake Relief

2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y. — There is a full field of 14 entered for the 147th running of the Travers Stakes on Saturday, including the Preakness victor Exaggerator and the Belmont champion Creator. Still, the Midsummer Derby, as the race is known, is a wide-open affair in a year in which the crop of male 3-year-olds seems evenly matched. The morning-line odds were set by Travis Stone of the New York Racing Association. The comments are by Joe Drape of The New York Times.

2016-08-26.snippet: Think long and hard before heading to or staying in South Florida, use repellent, and make it harder for mosquitoes to breed.
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: Zika has a foothold in the continental United States now that mosquitoes in parts of Miami-Dade County, Fla., have infected people with the virus. Zika can cause harrowing brain damage in the developing fetus of a woman who is infected during pregnancy, so it is vital that pregnant women minimize that risk. Here’s some advice on how to do that.

The National Park Service celebrated its 100th birthday last Monday at Brooklyn Bridge Park, with Bill Nye, Questlove and other park lovers. 2016-08-26.abstract: A latecomer to the HBO series, Mr. Sapochnik talks about the challenges of staging outsize historical battles.
2016-08-26.snippet: A latecomer to the HBO series, Mr. Sapochnik talks about the challenges of staging outsize historical battles.
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: The British director Miguel Sapochnik didn’t start working on “Game of Thrones” until the fifth season, but he’s since overseen several of the show’s best episodes. These include the zombie-raid extravaganza “Hardhome,” in Season 5, and the final two last season, all of them game-changing installments that combined epic sweep with indelible moments. (Think the Night’s King’s highly meme-able Wildling resurrection in “Hardhome,” or King Tommen’s shocking, macabrely beautiful suicide in “Winds of Winter,” last season’s finale.)
2016-08-26.headline_main: Miguel Sapochnik on ‘Game of Thrones,’ and Making 70 Horses Feel Like 3,000

No, he’s just hanging out in a flawed digital backdrop of Rio de Janeiro, trying to forget his blood-spattered résumé.

2016-08-26.abstract: The Republican presidential candidate has shown a lenient side in the vetting of campaign officials who turn out to have come with red flags.

2016-08-26.abstract: Mr. Harper, whose governing coalition was soundly beaten in a general election last year, said he would give up his seat in Parliament and leave politics.
2016-08-26.snippet: Mr. Harper, whose governing coalition was soundly beaten in a general election last year, said he would give up his seat in Parliament and leave politics.
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — He led his government to a crushing defeat at the polls last October, then ceded his office to Justin Trudeau and largely vanished from public view. Now, 10 months later, Stephen Harper, the former Conservative prime minister of Canada, says he is giving up his seat in Parliament and quitting politics.
2016-08-26.headline_main: Stephen Harper, Former Prime Minister of Canada, Quits Politics

2016-08-26.snippet: On Friday, workers at Ellen’s Stardust Diner said they had formed a union to fight new policies that they say led to many firings and fundamentally altered what had been a haven for performers.

No, we ain’t gonna take it! Oh, we’re not gonna take it anymore!”

2016-08-26.abstract: An exhibition at the Old Stone House in Brooklyn celebrates the clash, also known as the Battle of Long Island, which spared General Washington from capture.
2016-08-26.snippet: An exhibition at the Old Stone House in Brooklyn celebrates the clash, also known as the Battle of Long Island, which spared General Washington from capture.
2016-08-26.lead_paragraph: Usually, history celebrates the victories in war — Ulysses S. Grant crossing the Mississippi River on the way to Vicksburg, Theodore Roosevelt and the Rough Riders charging up San Juan Hill, the American troops storming ashore at Normandy.

2016-08-26.abstract: The ruling against the law, which restricted restroom access, is an indication that the measure will continue to face a difficult road ahead.

The ruling was the first judicial rebuke of a statute that has been condemned as discriminatory and, with lawsuit after lawsuit, has deepened the national debate about transgender rights.

2016-08-26.abstract: Few of the residents hold any hope of returning. Before they evacuated Friday, they kissed the ground and visited the graves of relatives for the last time.

2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: Paul R. LePage, the ever-combative Republican governor of Maine, refused on Friday to apologize to a Democratic state lawmaker for leaving a threatening and expletive-studded voicemail message that was criticized by some state Republicans and left top Democrats suggesting that Mr. LePage should resign.
2016-08-27.headline_main: Profane Phone Message Has Gov. Paul LePage of Maine in Hot Water Again

2016-08-27.abstract: Ted Giannoulas has spent more than 40 years as the man behind arguably the most famous mascot in sports. But he staves off the future, one night at a time.
2016-08-27.snippet: Ted Giannoulas has spent more than 40 years as the man behind arguably the most famous mascot in sports. But he staves off the future, one night at a time.
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: DES MOINES — Ted Giannoulas’s arrival was delayed four-plus hours; some of his luggage had not arrived. Now, in a brightly lit, empty drive-through restaurant outside of downtown, he savored a double burger as closing time neared. It was a late Sunday night in early August. The surrounding suburban strip malls offered little for sale but boredom.
2016-08-27.headline_main: The San Diego Chicken Heads Into a Sunset

2016-08-27.abstract: A letter to incoming freshmen professed no support for “trigger warnings” or limits on what kinds of speech should be condoned on campus.
2016-08-27.snippet: A letter to incoming freshmen professed no support for “trigger warnings” or limits on what kinds of speech should be condoned on campus.
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: The anodyne welcome letter to incoming freshmen is a college staple, but this week the University of Chicago took a different approach: It sent new students a blunt statement opposing some hallmarks of campus political correctness, drawing thousands of impassioned responses, for and against, as it caromed around cyberspace.
2016-08-27.headline_main: University of Chicago Strikes Back Against Campus Political Correctness

2016-08-27.abstract: The ruling against the use of a new method of analyzing genetic data dealt a blow to prosecutors trying to convict a former coach of strangling the 12-year-old boy in Potsdam, N.Y.
2016-08-27.snippet: The ruling against the use of a new method of analyzing genetic data dealt a blow to prosecutors trying to convict a former coach of strangling the 12-year-old boy in Potsdam, N.Y.
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: A judge presiding over a trial in the 2011 murder of a 12-year-old boy in northern New York State said on Friday that the prosecution could not use a cutting-edge and controversial method of analyzing DNA data, dealing a blow to its efforts to convict a former soccer coach accused of the crime.
2016-08-27.headline_main: Judge Rejects DNA Test in Trial Over Garrett Phillips’s Murder

2016-08-27.abstract: Quotation of the day for Saturday, August 27, 2016.
2016-08-27.snippet: Quotation of the day for Saturday, August 27, 2016.
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: “Elephants can live everywhere; that’s not our problem here. There are no jobs in this country. Zero, zero, zero.”
2016-08-27.headline_main: Quotation of the Day

2016-08-27.abstract: Bobbleheads honoring Matt Harvey and lunch bags touting Steven Matz, two pitchers sidelined by injuries, were to be doled out this weekend at Citi Field.
2016-08-27.snippet: Bobbleheads honoring Matt Harvey and lunch bags touting Steven Matz, two pitchers sidelined by injuries, were to be doled out this weekend at Citi Field.

2016-08-27.abstract: Varner, one of the few African-Americans to join the tour, is playing at the Barclays, seeking his fifth top-10 finish of the year.
2016-08-27.snippet: Varner, one of the few African-Americans to join the tour, is playing at the Barclays, seeking his fifth top-10 finish of the year.
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: FARMINGDALE, N.Y. — With a 7:20 a.m. starting time for the second round of the Barclays, Harold Varner III was up before sunrise Friday. But three people in his small gallery were awake well before Varner, a PGA Tour rookie and one of six first-year golfers in the FedEx Cup playoffs.
2016-08-27.headline_main: Harold Varner III, PGA Tour Rookie, Says, ‘I Want to Inspire Everybody’

2016-08-27.abstract: A hacker apologized in federal court in Manhattan and expressed regret for his misdeeds, but emails he has sent from jail since suggest otherwise.
2016-08-27.snippet: A hacker apologized in federal court in Manhattan and expressed regret for his misdeeds, but emails he has sent from jail since suggest otherwise.
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: When Alonzo Knowles pleaded guilty in May to hacking into the email accounts of celebrities and athletes, gaining access to unreleased movie and television scripts and trying to sell them for thousands of dollars, he apologized in court, saying he knew what he had done was wrong.
2016-08-27.headline_main: Apologetic Hacker? Not if You Peek at His Emails

2016-08-27.abstract: I’m a venture capitalist. I should pay the top rate on “carried interest.”
2016-08-27.snippet: I’m a venture capitalist. I should pay the top rate on “carried interest.”
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: My fellow venture capitalists and private equity investors are paying close attention to the heated election-year rhetoric about the future of “carried interest,” which is the performance fee we charge to manage other people’s money. Carried interest is the fund manager’s share of the earnings from a profitable investment, normally paid on top of a much smaller management fee.
2016-08-27.headline_main: Close My Tax Loophole

2016-08-27.abstract: A satisfying Saturday puzzle from Jim Page.
2016-08-27.snippet: A satisfying Saturday puzzle from Jim Page.
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — If you’re planning a pub crawl this weekend, you could do a lot worse than starting off with a trip to a KARAOKE BAR. Jim Page and Will Shortz/Joel Fagliano highly recommend it with the fabulous clue, “Where to belt one down and belt one out.” It’s also a fairly easy and welcoming opening to one of our weekend puzzles.
2016-08-27.headline_main: As Long as You Love Me So

2016-08-27.abstract: The president is displaying a late-blooming enthusiasm on the environmental front.
2016-08-27.snippet: The president is displaying a late-blooming enthusiasm on the environmental front.
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: Bill Clinton was like a kid with a new toy when, fairly late in his presidency, and to the great annoyance of Congress, he discovered his powers under the Antiquities Act to create national monuments with a stroke of the presidential pen — and then busily set about protecting areas of great scenic, environmental or historical significance that might otherwise be ignored by Congress or threatened by development. President Obama, to the delight of conservationists, is now very much on the same schedule.
2016-08-27.headline_main: National Monuments From Mr. Obama

2016-08-27.abstract: Statistics this year show Brooklyn is the most dangerous borough for cyclists, despite its bike-friendly reputation and high number of bicycling commuters.
2016-08-27.snippet: Statistics this year show Brooklyn is the most dangerous borough for cyclists, despite its bike-friendly reputation and high number of bicycling commuters.
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: The statistic was alarming enough on its own: The number of cyclists killed by motor vehicles on New York City streets in 2016 had matched 2015’s total just eight months into the year.
2016-08-27.headline_main: Brooklyn’s Bicycling Culture Doesn’t Ease Risks for Riders

2016-08-27.abstract: High rents are pushing out our most beloved retail outlets. Can anything be done?
2016-08-27.snippet: High rents are pushing out our most beloved retail outlets. Can anything be done?
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: My laptop was acting up, dispatching emails before I hit “send,” so I set off for Tekserve. It’s my neighborhood computer-repair store, and it’s been serving Manhattan for decades — “the Apple Store in New York City before there was such a thing as an Apple Store,” The Times called it. When I arrived, a clerk told me it was about to close, permanently. The rent had doubled.
2016-08-27.headline_main: New York’s Disappearing Storefronts

2016-08-27.abstract: The union representing the employees, who had threatened to strike, sought a raise that would put their wages on par with workers employed directly by the state.
2016-08-27.snippet: The union representing the employees, who had threatened to strike, sought a raise that would put their wages on par with workers employed directly by the state.
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: The company that runs a call center for Access-A-Ride, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority’s service for people with disabilities, and the union that represents its workers have reached an agreement to raise their wages to at least $15 an hour by 2018, the union announced on Friday.
2016-08-27.headline_main: M.T.A. Contract Workers Will Earn Higher Wages by 2018

2016-08-27.abstract: She joined her husband, Benjamin C. Thompson, in planning festival marketplaces including Faneuil Hall, the South Street Seaport, and Harborplace in Baltimore.
2016-08-27.snippet: She joined her husband, Benjamin C. Thompson, in planning festival marketplaces including Faneuil Hall, the South Street Seaport, and Harborplace in Baltimore.
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: To imagination-starved American households that needed a dash of style in the 1950s and ’60s, and to moribund urban waterfronts that needed a dose of hope in the ’70s and ’80s, the designers Jane and Benjamin C. Thompson brought vibrancy and variety, colors and textures, and (nice) smells.
2016-08-27.headline_main: Jane Thompson, Designer Who Helped Transform Waterfronts, Dies at 89

2016-08-27.abstract: Sanchez hit his 10th home run since being called up 20 games ago as the Yankees gained ground on the Orioles in the wild-card race.
2016-08-27.snippet: Sanchez hit his 10th home run since being called up 20 games ago as the Yankees gained ground on the Orioles in the wild-card race.
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: As Gary Sanchez jogged around the bases at Yankee Stadium on Friday night, he heard only silence. Sanchez had just cracked another home run, his 10th this month, settling the extraordinary into the routine, and yet his emotions swelled so high that now his ears were betraying him. An entire stadium erupted with glee and he could not take it in. He just kept jogging — at least his legs had not stopped churning.
2016-08-27.headline_main: As Gary Sanchez Ascends, Yankees See Their Fortunes Beginning to Rise

2016-08-27.abstract: Many companies that receive federal contracts have gotten away with cheating and harming workers — until now.
2016-08-27.snippet: Many companies that receive federal contracts have gotten away with cheating and harming workers — until now.
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: As the nation’s chief executive, the president gets to set standards for companies that do business with the government. In 2014, after a Senate report found that many federal contractors had been repeatedly cited for cheating, harassing and injuring their employees, President Obama ordered federal agencies to check how well companies have complied with labor laws before awarding contracts.
2016-08-27.headline_main: Fair Pay, Safe Workplaces, Republican Objections

2016-08-27.abstract: Ms. Del Deo, a bohemian writer nicknamed the Muse of True History, helped ensure that Provincetown, Mass., would continue to appear much as it did in the days of Thoreau.
2016-08-27.snippet: Ms. Del Deo, a bohemian writer nicknamed the Muse of True History, helped ensure that Provincetown, Mass., would continue to appear much as it did in the days of Thoreau.
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: Josephine Del Deo, a writer and preservationist who helped safeguard the embryonic Cape Cod National Seashore in Massachusetts and preserved the historic character of Provincetown, at the cape’s tip, died on Thursday in Provincetown. She was 90.
2016-08-27.headline_main: Josephine Del Deo, Who Fought to Preserve Cape Cod Shoreline, Dies at 90

2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: Juan Deleon was standing in the lobby of the Harlem apartment building where he lived on Feb. 11, 1990, arguing with the mother of his two young daughters, when gunshots, at least eight of them, rang out. 2016-08-27.snippet: Altercations in a co-op, timing on buying an apartment and a withheld security deposit.
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: Two  neighbors on my floor employ the same maid. Another condominium owner and I have both had verbal altercations with this maid. She swore at each of us and, in my case, pushed me aside during a conflict about who could use a common washing machine. Neither of her employers fired her. When I emailed the managing agent about my concerns, I was told to “just keep me posted.” Shouldn’t the condo association do more? What responsibilities and authority does it have to resolve a matter like this?

2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The feud between two police families from the village of Daku, on the northern Afghan Shomali Plain, goes back so far no one really knows what started it. Six dead bodies later, no one sees an end to it, either.

Roosevelt, an avid angler, did on a getaway from the White House in 1937.

The logger points to a clearing down the slope and, with one final, quick slash, sends the tree falling, exactly where he pointed.

2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: In the 1970s, I quit college and enlisted in the United States Marines. I was young, and there was a war on. As it turned out, I spent a decade on active duty. 2016-08-27.abstract: In his first aerial battle, Mr. O’Keefe downed five Japanese planes over Okinawa; he later entered Mississippi politics as a staunch opponent of segregation.
2016-08-27.snippet: In his first aerial battle, Mr. O’Keefe downed five Japanese planes over Okinawa; he later entered Mississippi politics as a staunch opponent of segregation.
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: Jeremiah J. O’Keefe, who earned ace status in his first aerial battle when he downed five Japanese planes over Okinawa during World War II and later entered Mississippi politics as a staunch opponent of segregation, died Tuesday at his home in Biloxi, Miss. He was 93.
2016-08-27.headline_main: Jeremiah O’Keefe, Ace in His First World War II Battle, Dies at 93

2016-08-27.abstract: A new ad titled “Everything” offers an answer to Mr. Trump, who has sought support from minority voters by asking, “What the hell do you have to lose?”
2016-08-27.snippet: A new ad titled “Everything” offers an answer to Mr. Trump, who has sought support from minority voters by asking, “What the hell do you have to lose?”
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: The presidential contest between Hillary Clinton and Donald J. Trump this week was marked by accusations — from both sides — of racism and bigotry. The Clinton campaign is pressing the issue of race in a new ad titled “Everything,” which offers an answer to Mr. Trump, who has sought support from minority voters by asking, rhetorically, “What the hell do you have to lose?”
2016-08-27.headline_main: Hillary Clinton Ad Pushes Issue of Race Against Donald Trump

2016-08-27.abstract: Donald Trump doesn’t quite make the cut.

2016-08-27.abstract: Better relations could put the Middle East on a more positive course. But the Palestinians could be left in the dust, a worrisome prospect.
2016-08-27.snippet: Better relations could put the Middle East on a more positive course. But the Palestinians could be left in the dust, a worrisome prospect.
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: Israel and Saudi Arabia have no formal diplomatic relations. The Saudis do not even recognize Israel as a state. Still, there is evidence that ties between Saudi Arabia and other Sunni Arab states and Israel are not only improving but, after developing in secret over many years, could evolve into a more explicit alliance as a result of their mutual distrust of Iran. Better relations among these neighbors could put the chaotic Middle East on a more positive course. They could also leave the Palestinians in the dust, a worrisome prospect.
2016-08-27.headline_main: Can Israel and the Arab States Be Friends?

2016-08-27.abstract: How two of his least celebrated accomplishments shaped the battle between Clinton and Trump.
2016-08-27.snippet: How two of his least celebrated accomplishments shaped the battle between Clinton and Trump.
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: “Dr. King’s dream began to be realized when President Johnson passed the Civil Rights Act,” Hillary Clinton claimed during her 2008 campaign against Senator Barack Obama, before adding, “it took a president to get it done.”

2016-08-27.abstract: We know what shouldn’t happen to women at work. Now can we get rid of it?
2016-08-27.snippet: We know what shouldn’t happen to women at work. Now can we get rid of it?
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: Two high-profile lawsuits against Roger Ailes, the former Fox News chairman, have painted a shocking picture of brazen sexual harassment at the network. In her bombshell complaint against him, the former Fox host Gretchen Carlson said that he told her, “I think you and I should have had a sexual relationship a long time ago.” Last week, another former Fox host, Andrea Tantaros, filed her own lawsuit, stating that Mr. Ailes told her to turn around so he could “get a good look” at her and that she was harassed by other employees and even show guests.
2016-08-27.headline_main: Sexual Harassment Training With Roger Ailes

2016-08-27.abstract: Did I learn from all those gaffes? Sort of.
2016-08-27.snippet: Did I learn from all those gaffes? Sort of.
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: I worried constantly about making mistakes, which, it turned out, did not prevent them. It was 1997, the summer I’d graduated from college, and I was interning with The Charlotte Observer, a daily newspaper in a city where I knew almost no one. I was a general assignment reporter earning $525 a week. If I performed well, I’d be considered for a permanent position.
2016-08-27.headline_main: A Summer to Make Mistakes

2016-08-27.abstract: Subtract Trump’s celebrity and his crudely articulated approach doesn’t fly. Just ask the candidates parroting him.

2016-08-27.abstract: It is now possible and practical to provide a significant part of the nation’s power needs from ocean winds.
2016-08-27.snippet: It is now possible and practical to provide a significant part of the nation’s power needs from ocean winds.
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: The first offshore wind farm in American waters, near Block Island, R.I., was completed this month. With just five turbines, the farm won’t make much of a dent in the nation’s reliance on fossil fuels, but it shows the promise this renewable energy source could have. When the turbines start spinning in November, they will power the island, which currently relies on diesel generators, and will also send electricity to the rest of Rhode Island.
2016-08-27.headline_main: The Unlimited Power of Ocean Winds

2016-08-27.abstract: How do you square the image of the transcendent, unchanging champion with the fact of a player who is growing old?
2016-08-27.snippet: How do you square the image of the transcendent, unchanging champion with the fact of a player who is growing old?
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: He heard a click. That was how Roger Federer discovered the knee injury that cost him most of his 2016 season. He was running a bath for his daughters — and since he is Roger Federer, we have to assume he was running a gorgeous bath, possibly the greatest bath of all time, perfect temperature, immaculate bubbles, faint scent of lavender, business as usual.
2016-08-27.headline_main: Even Roger Federer Gets Old

2016-08-27.snippet: The battle against the emerald ash borer needs more ammunition.
2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: The emerald ash borer is a luminescent green insect that probably arrived in the Detroit area more than 15 years ago. These small Asian beetles, possibly coming to this country on wooden packing materials, have been devouring millions of ash trees as they eat their way from Michigan across the Midwest.

He will regress into the promising player he was assumed to be when the Yankees called him up this month, rather than the dominant force he has become since joining them. Sanchez will, most likely, stop hitting like Barry Bonds in pinstripes.

2016-08-27.lead_paragraph: TORONTO — Canada’s prime minister, Justin Trudeau, is due in China on Tuesday for a much anticipated visit, hoping to reset what had been an up-and-down relationship under the previous government. Closer ties, Mr. Trudeau says, would release untapped prosperity at home and promote Canadian values like good governance and the rule of law in China.

Arrogate required patience and often tried the patience of those charged with transforming him into a racehorse. Every now and then in the mornings, however, Arrogate would flash at what might come, pumping those long gray legs like pistons and chugging down the track like a steamroller.

Mr. Velardo watched the man tap the screen of an iPad. He heard the man chuckle and say: “You’d think I would know this. I wrote it.” And then, with even more of a chuckle, “Didn’t see that twist coming.”
2016-08-28.headline_main: Now Arriving on the New York Subway: Free E-Books, Timed for Your Commute

2016-08-28.snippet: A sign announcing Amtrak and New Jersey Transit trains will be replaced by smaller LCD screens, upsetting those who view it with nostalgia but pleasing commuter advocates.
2016-08-28.lead_paragraph: The large Amtrak departures board in Pennsylvania Station in Manhattan draws masses of commuters to the floor beneath it, where they stare up as if in a trance. The slightest movement of the sign inside the country’s busiest train station sets off a variety of reactions — despair after the appearance of the word “delayed” or, even worse, “canceled”; relief and elation after a track is assigned and people rush to the trains below.
2016-08-28.headline_main: ‘It Is a Piece of Penn Station’: An Exiting Departures Board Inspires Strong Emotions

2016-08-28.snippet: The 86-year-old author will become one of the few living writers recognized by the Library of America, and she did it on her terms.
2016-08-28.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore. — If you’re a big-deal American writer, you hope for a couple of things to cement your legacy. Finding out one fine October morning that your presence is being requested in Sweden would be ideal. Almost as good is enshrinement in the Library of America, the closest thing to immortality between hardcovers.
2016-08-28.headline_main: Ursula Le Guin Has Earned a Rare Honor. Just Don’t Call Her a Sci-Fi Writer.

2016-08-28.abstract: Steve Coleman, a bandleader-saxophonist coming to a residency at the Stone, fuses his scholarship of nature’s rhythms and those of ancient cultures.
2016-08-28.snippet: Steve Coleman, a bandleader-saxophonist coming to a residency at the Stone, fuses his scholarship of nature’s rhythms and those of ancient cultures.
2016-08-28.lead_paragraph: Steve Coleman is the most important jazz musician that many fans have never heard of. He’s been the leader on 30 albums in the last three decades and the mentor to a dozen younger artists now making headlines, yet he’s remained an underground figure, content to burrow his own pathways. Lately, though, his profile’s been rising. In the last two years, he’s won a trifecta of arts prizes: a Guggenheim fellowship, a Doris Duke performing artist award and a MacArthur genius grant.
2016-08-28.headline_main: After 30 Albums and 3 Recent Prizes, a Jazzman Flirts With the Mainstream

Shear and Julie Hirschfeld Davis, White House correspondents for The New York Times, went to see “Southside With You,” the new feature film that is a fictionalized account of President Obama’s first date with the woman who would become his wife. The movie, set in 1989 in Chicago, stars Parker Sawyers and Tika Sumpter as Barack Obama and Michelle Robinson.

2016-08-28.abstract: Spaniards can’t agree on who should rule the country, but they are united in one thing: disgust for politicians.
2016-08-28.snippet: Spaniards can’t agree on who should rule the country, but they are united in one thing: disgust for politicians.
2016-08-28.lead_paragraph: MADRID — On Jan. 2, 1492, Isabella of Castile and Ferdinand of Aragon — known as the Catholic Monarchs — occupied Granada, completing their conquest of Moorish Spain. Ever since, Spain has always had a government — and occasionally two, when Napoleon invaded in 1808, and during the 1936 to 1939 civil war that split it. But never during those more than five centuries was it ever without any. That is, until Dec. 20 last year, when elections failed to give any party the majority needed to form a government and all attempts at a coalition failed.
2016-08-28.headline_main: Spain: A Country With No Government

Two decades later, Alberto Uribe’s son, Álvaro, would serve as Colombia’s president, from 2002-10, leading the government in a civil war against the rebel group he held responsible for his father’s death.

2016-08-29.abstract: Some ugly politics is local.
2016-08-29.snippet: Some ugly politics is local.
2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: Something terrible has happened to pregnant women in Texas: their mortality rate has doubled in recent years, and is now comparable to rates in places like Russia or Ukraine. Although researchers into this disaster are careful to say that it can’t be attributed to any one cause, the death surge does coincide with the state’s defunding of Planned Parenthood, which led to the closing of many clinics. And all of this should be seen against the general background of Texas policy, which is extremely hostile toward anything that helps low-income residents.
2016-08-29.headline_main: States of Cruelty

2016-08-29.abstract: My son is experiencing the same fears of death that I did as a child. What should I tell him?
2016-08-29.snippet: My son is experiencing the same fears of death that I did as a child. What should I tell him?
2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: As a child, I was terrified of death. It was often in the twilight hours, between the moment of lying down and the imperceptible instant of slipping off to sleep, that the terror would arise. The thought of vanishing completely from the world, of being engulfed in ineradicable darkness, would seize upon me and crush with it the very existence of the world. It was not simply that I would no longer be there. It was that reality itself would collapse, devoid of any point of apprehension. Petrified before a void so vast that it could not be contained within thought, let alone a thinking being, it was impossible to know how long it would take to drift off into the abyss that silently beckoned me.
2016-08-29.headline_main: Why We Never Die

2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: The pediatric wisdom is that it’s often the mother who asks the question. But she usually says the question comes from the boy’s father.
2016-08-29.headline_main: As Boys Get Fatter, Parents Worry One Body Part Is Too Small

2016-08-29.abstract: The suspended president took the stand and fiercely argued that she was innocent of the charges of manipulating the federal budget.
2016-08-29.snippet: The suspended president took the stand and fiercely argued that she was innocent of the charges of manipulating the federal budget.
2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: BRASÍLIA — Brazil’s suspended president, Dilma Rousseff, took the stand on Monday at her impeachment trial in the Senate, delivering a last-ditch defense to prevent her final removal from office.
2016-08-29.headline_main: Dilma Rousseff of Brazil Says She Won’t Be Silenced in Impeachment Trial

2016-08-29.abstract: Testing with varnishtest made a huge impact when working with VCL. There is a bit of a learning curve to get started, so I wanted to share what I’ve learned in my work.
2016-08-29.snippet: Testing with varnishtest made a huge impact when working with VCL. There is a bit of a learning curve to get started, so I wanted to share what I’ve learned in my work.
2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: I work on the Content API team at the New York Times and we have a lot of legacy code. Over the past year I spent months modernizing our platform for our continuous delivery initiative. If you have a lot of legacy code, and the people before you weren’t developing with continuous delivery practices, chances are you have your own fair share of challenges. One of the tougher challenges I faced was learning how to test the systems I inherited, and one of those platforms I inherited was our Varnish stack.
2016-08-29.headline_main: Testing Varnish Using Varnishtest

2016-08-29.abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: An American theater company arrives in Paris in August 1891.
2016-08-29.snippet: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: An American theater company arrives in Paris in August 1891.
2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: The Daly Company open their Paris season tomorrow evening at the Vaudeville Theatre, with ‘‘As You Like It.’’ They will play for a week, varying the programme every night, and giving in succession ‘‘The Railroad of Love,’’ ‘‘The School for Scandal,’’ ‘‘A Night Off,’’ a piece written by Mr. Daly himself; ‘‘The Taming of the Shrew’’ and ‘‘The Lottery of Love.’’ This is the third time the Daly Company have visited Paris, but their last appearance was three years ago. It is owing to the fact that Mr. Daly’s theatre in New York is undergoing reconstruction, that he has found time to make a European trip. — The New York Herald, European Edition, August 30, 1891
2016-08-29.headline_main: 1891: American Comedians Arrive

2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: Q. What’s the best way to manage business cards? There used to be a great system called CardScan that allowed someone to scan a card and the information could then be transferred to a contact database. Is CardScan out of business?

2016-08-29.abstract: A team of scientists recently concluded that Lucy, a hominid whose skeleton was discovered in 1974, died from a long fall — but their study has divided experts.

2016-08-29.abstract: Mr. Hammer, who wrote a 2015 biography of James Merrill, discusses the poet’s mysticism, the biographer’s job — and the Ouija board.
2016-08-29.snippet: Mr. Hammer, who wrote a 2015 biography of James Merrill, discusses the poet’s mysticism, the biographer’s job — and the Ouija board.
2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: Langdon Hammer’s most recent book, “James Merrill: Life and Art” (2015), is among the best literary biographies of the decade. It traces the career of Merrill, the poet, from his pampered childhood — his father was a co-founder of Merrill Lynch — through his success as a writer of coy, formal, witty American verse. Merrill won a Pulitzer Prize, two National Book Awards and a National Book Critics Circle Award.
2016-08-29.headline_main: About That Ouija Board: How Langdon Hammer Summoned a Poet’s Spirit

2016-08-29.abstract: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: China builts a missile-firing submarine in August 1966.
2016-08-29.snippet: From the archives of the International Herald Tribune: China builts a missile-firing submarine in August 1966.
2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: Communist China now has a ballistic missile-firing submarine, but does not yet have missiles for it, a high ranking U.S. naval officer said yesterday. Vice-Adm. Charles E. Weakley, commander of antisubmarine warfare, Atlantic Fleet, told newsmen that China had patterned the sub after a Soviet model, but built it in China. The 1965-66 edition of ‘‘Jane’s Fighting Ships,’’ an authoritative source on world shipping, lists China as having one ‘‘G-Class’’ sub, of which it says the Russians have 30, as capable of firing 3 ballistic missiles at a time. — New York Herald Tribune, European Edition, Aug. 30, 1966
2016-08-29.headline_main: 1966: China Has Missile Submarine

2016-08-29.abstract: Cocktail Kingdom is now selling elegant reproductions of 19th-century punch bowls, ladles and glasses from the author David Wondrich’s collection.
2016-08-29.snippet: Cocktail Kingdom is now selling elegant reproductions of 19th-century punch bowls, ladles and glasses from the author David Wondrich’s collection.
2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: Reproductions of elegant 19th-century punchware — silver ladles, a roomy stoneware bowl and stemmed glasses — from the drinks expert David Wondrich’s personal collection are available in plenty of time for holiday entertaining. They are made and sold by Cocktail Kingdom: David Wondrich Classic Collection From Cocktail Kingdom, $24.95 to $64.95, cocktailkingdom.com.
2016-08-29.headline_main: Classic Punchware for Entertaining

2016-08-29.abstract: This event at Hauser Wirth & Schimmel in Los Angeles was meant to highlight the visibility of working female artists in that city.
2016-08-29.snippet: This event at Hauser Wirth & Schimmel in Los Angeles was meant to highlight the visibility of working female artists in that city.
2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A group of 733 female artists gathered on Sunday in the sunny courtyard of the Hauser Wirth & Schimmel gallery for “Now Be Here,” which its organizers call the largest group portrait of working artists taken in this city’s history.
2016-08-29.headline_main: ‘Now Be Here’ Takes a Portrait and Makes a Gender Statement

2016-08-29.abstract: The crepe known as tapioca is now available at Oca in NoLIta.
2016-08-29.snippet: The crepe known as tapioca is now available at Oca in NoLIta.
2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: The Rio Olympics have come and gone, but tastes of Brazil linger. In NoLIta, a group of Brazilian entrepreneurs has opened a new spot that serves freshly made tapioca crepes. Lacy and crisp-edged, made from cassava flour and naturally gluten-free, they enclose combinations like scrambled eggs, tomatoes and mozzarella or bananas, feta and mint. There are tropical milkshakes alongside, all to devour at a few tables on the premises or to take away: Oca, 250 Mott Street (Prince Street), 212-966-0622, ocastore.com.
2016-08-29.headline_main: Gluten-Free Crepes From Brazil

2016-08-29.abstract: “Abraham Entertaining the Angels,” a small oil painting from 1646, is the subject of an exhibition opening in May 2017.

2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: Rembrandt’s “Abraham Entertaining the Angels,” a small oil painting that is rarely on public view, will be the focus of an exhibition at the Frick Collection opening in May.

2016-08-29.abstract: Salty water from the sea is now available for boiling at home.
2016-08-29.snippet: Salty water from the sea is now available for boiling at home.
2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: They say it’s best to cook lobsters and shrimp in water as salty as the sea. Without getting your feet wet in the Rockaways, you can simmer potatoes, boil penne or poach cod fillets in a portion of the Mediterranean Sea. Purified seawater from Spain is sold in pouches to use, diluted somewhat, for cooking. It might sound crazy — buying seawater? — but my potatoes and pasta cooked in it were delicious: Mediterranea Seawater, $9.99 for 1.5 liters (about 51 ounces), $49.99 for 10 liters from Kalustyan’s, 123 Lexington Avenue (28th Street), 212-685-3451, kalustyans.com.
2016-08-29.headline_main: The Mediterranean Diet’s Secret Ingredient

2016-08-29.abstract: As the income gap in the United States has widened, luxury and discount retailers have become increasingly deft at drawing people at separate ends of the income spectrum.
2016-08-29.snippet: As the income gap in the United States has widened, luxury and discount retailers have become increasingly deft at drawing people at separate ends of the income spectrum.
2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: The fashion brand Kate Spade is most known for luxury handbags. But it is also banking on gold-accented staplers, monogrammed planners and $30 ballpoint pens to help buoy sales during the increasingly important back-to-school shopping season.

2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: Michael Klug, the chef for L.A. Burdick Handmade Chocolates, has joined the macaron party, making a delicate, whisper-light version in five flavors: apricot, chocolate, lemon-blueberry, pistachio and cherry, with ganache, buttercream and jam fillings. All are made without artificial coloring. Buy them separately or in gift boxes of a dozen: Macaron Collection, $2.50 each, 12 for $30, L.A. Burdick stores, burdickchocolate.com.

2016-08-29.abstract: The evening to salute the late chef, at Chelsea Piers, will raise money for a new scholarship at the Culinary Institute of America.
2016-08-29.snippet: The evening to salute the late chef, at Chelsea Piers, will raise money for a new scholarship at the Culinary Institute of America.
2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: Roger Vergé, the great French chef who died last year at 85, will be remembered for how he lit up the South of France with his Michelin three-star restaurant, Le Moulin de Mougins. On Sept. 12, he will be honored by chefs, most of whom worked with him, including Daniel Boulud, Terrance Brennan, Emeril Lagasse, Dean Fearing and Francis Mallmann, at a fund-raising dinner for a new Vergé scholarship to be awarded to a student at the Culinary Institute of America. The event will include a cocktail hour and four-course dinner: Roger Vergé Scholarship dinner, Sept. 12 at 6:30 p.m., Lighthouse at Chelsea Piers, 23rd Street and West Side Highway; tickets, $995 from blog.resy.com/verge-tribute-dinner.
2016-08-29.headline_main: A Dinner to Honor Roger Vergé

2016-08-29.abstract: The author Tama Matsuoka Wong and the restaurateur Claus Meyer are offering a series of foraging classes.
2016-08-29.snippet: The author Tama Matsuoka Wong and the restaurateur Claus Meyer are offering a series of foraging classes.
2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: An essential element of the new Nordic culinary style is wild, foraged ingredients, including herbs, roots, mushrooms and seaweed. Tama Matsuoka Wong, whose organization, Meadows and More, specializes in foraging, has teamed up with Claus Meyer, the owner of the Great Northern Food Hall and Agern restaurant in Grand Central Terminal, to organize a series of foraging classes. Each excursion will be held within 90 minutes of the city and includes a meal prepared by Joe Yardley, the chef de cuisine at Agern: Sea, Sept. 11; Field, Oct. 1; Forest, Nov. 6; each class $125, agernrestaurant.com.
2016-08-29.headline_main: Where the Wild Things Are

2016-08-29.snippet: The Securities and Exchange Commission settled its last remaining case against a former Fannie Mae chief executive, accepting a token payment.
2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: One source of great frustration from the financial crisis has been the dearth of cases against individuals over subprime lending practices and the related securitization of bad loans that caused so much financial havoc. To heighten the frustration, I offer Aug. 22, 2016, as the day on which efforts to pursue cases related to subprime mortgages were put to rest with no individuals — save perhaps the unfortunate former Goldman Sachs trader Fabrice Tourre — held accountable.
2016-08-29.headline_main: Prosecution of Financial Crisis Fraud Ends With a Whimper

Weiner of New York apparently deleted his Twitter account in the wake of a New York Post report that he had been involved in another sexting episode with a woman online last year, his wife announced that the couple were separating.

2016-08-29.abstract: In the 65th District of Manhattan, one of New York’s most ethnically diverse, six candidates are vying for the Assembly seat that Mr. Silver had held for nearly four decades.
2016-08-29.snippet: In the 65th District of Manhattan, one of New York’s most ethnically diverse, six candidates are vying for the Assembly seat that Mr. Silver had held for nearly four decades.
2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: The six would-be inheritors of Sheldon Silver’s political legacy on the Lower East Side of Manhattan sat on a dais last week and introduced themselves in the neighborhood’s native tongues. “Hola!” two said, in Spanish. “Nei ho!” two said, in Cantonese. “Sholem aleykhem!” said another, in Yiddish.
2016-08-29.headline_main: Race to Replace Sheldon Silver Reflects His District’s Ethnic Diversity

Buffett. These days, his decade-plus obsession with the struggling retailer Sears resembles Captain Ahab’s with Moby-Dick.

2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The Israeli military said Monday that a soldier was under investigation for the death of an unarmed Palestinian man who was shot in the Israeli-occupied West Bank on Friday. Questions about the shooting are feeding a stormy debate about open-fire regulations and the use of force during a wave of violence that began in October but appeared to have been waning recently.

2016-08-29.abstract: The leftist government plans to auction off four new TV licenses on Tuesday, spurring a sharp debate and struggle for media power.
2016-08-29.snippet: The leftist government plans to auction off four new TV licenses on Tuesday, spurring a sharp debate and struggle for media power.
2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Since Greece opened its media to private broadcasting in the 1980s, the market has been an almost unregulated scrum. Licenses are given out on an ad hoc basis. Media outlets have proliferated. The chaos ushered in hundreds of millions of dollars of debt and invited the undue influence of banks, media barons and successive governments.
2016-08-29.headline_main: In Greece, a Fierce Battle Over TV Licenses

2016-08-29.abstract: Readers tell of dishes that remind them where they came from.
2016-08-29.snippet: Readers tell of dishes that remind them where they came from.
2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: While friends went off to camp or passed weeks by the beach, I had a very specific variety of immigrant-kid summer, moving in with my grandparents in Nairobi, Kenya, and filling long unstructured days with books and food — lamb samosas that my grandfather folded neatly into delicate triangles, stuffed potatoes my grandmother tied with string.
2016-08-29.headline_main: Savoring the Foods and Family Traditions of Summers Past

2016-08-29.abstract: With a new striking suite of pieces inspired by 3D-modeling software glitches, Christopher Stuart is one to watch.
2016-08-29.snippet: With a new striking suite of pieces inspired by 3D-modeling software glitches, Christopher Stuart is one to watch.
2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: Last year, Christopher Stuart, an ex-welder based in Indianapolis, captured the attention of the design world with a deceptively simple piece of furniture called the U Bench, made from four conjoined, smoky black sheets of steel. Earlier this year, he got his first show, “Constructs & Glitches,” at the Future Perfect, featuring a striking suite of furniture inspired by snags he encountered while using 3D modeling software. Rather than troubleshoot the bugs — which added surface anomalies and amusing protuberances to his renderings — Stuart incorporated them, challenging the bedrock design principle that form follows function. “Function doesn’t always need to be utilitarian,” he says. “Isn’t the way something makes you feel also a kind of function?”
2016-08-29.headline_main: A Furniture Designer Who Incorporates Anomalies

Up until now, what should have been an edition with a couple of compelling story lines has been a weekly helping of image-friendly mush. Football fans would have done better to spend their time on a gritty Netflix interloper, “Last Chance U.”
2016-08-29.headline_main: Football Intrigue? Don’t Look at the N.F.L.

2016-08-29.abstract: Mr. Love’s memoir of his long Beach Boys career offers lots of inside information but tends to be overpowered by boasts and grudges.
2016-08-29.snippet: Mr. Love’s memoir of his long Beach Boys career offers lots of inside information but tends to be overpowered by boasts and grudges.
2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: “Good Vibrations” is the inevitable feel-good title for an autobiography by Mike Love, who has spent 55 of his 75 years as the frontman of the Beach Boys. But it runs counter to the competitive, score-settling spirit of this frequently bilious book. If Mr. Love’s public persona is that of a peace-loving perpetuator of summer fun, his private side is much angrier. And although he writes extensively about the role that Transcendental Meditation has played in his life, it hasn’t kept him from remembering all the bitterness of the Beach Boys’ history. It has kept him, he says, from killing people.
2016-08-29.headline_main: In ‘Good Vibrations,’ Summer Fun Soured by Mike Love’s Score Settling

2016-08-29.lead_paragraph: INVERNESS, Calif. — At the height of California’s fierce wildfire season, the Sierra Nevada and North Coast forests are choked with tens of millions of dead and dying trees, from gnarly oaks to elegant pines that are turning leafy chapels into tinderboxes of highly combustible debris.
